contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $51,205 as tested (including destination charge) 
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6 
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
  Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Push-button shift 
Option I can’t live without: Inflatable rear seatbelts  ($195)
You might also be considering: Audi A4, Buick Regal, Cadillac CTS, Lexus ES350 

See more specs on the MKZ in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

It has been almost sixteen years since I have really taken notice of a Lincoln. It was the debut of the Navigator in 1997 that demanded I pay attention. The Navigator was a game changer in the luxury SUV market, and its sales helped catapult Lincoln over Cadillac in annual sales volume. Times have changed. The Lincoln brand has plummeted, and Cadillac is on the upswing in sales. However, Lincoln has repositioned itself as the Lincoln Motor Company, and the new MKZ is poised to give Cadillac a reason to keep its eyes on the rearview mirror.

The MKZ was completely redesigned for 2013, including all-new choices in available engines. The vehicle I tested had the Preferred Equipment group (a $5,330 option), which included nineteen-inch polished aluminum wheels, a rearview camera, navigation, a blind spot information system with cross-traffic alert, rear heated seats, and a THX premium audio system. It also had a jaw-droppingly fabulous retractable panoramic roof ($2,995).

I spent the past week getting to know the MKZ. Every time I drove it, I discovered another feature that made me slowly fall in love. The standard push-button transmission kept me on my toes—I constantly reached for the windshield wiper control stalk as I tried to switch from park to reverse to drive. But with time, I grew fond of the buttons and how they were seamlessly designed into the center console. As always, I enjoyed the ability to shift manually while in sport mode using the paddles behind the steering wheel.

The center console swoops at armrest height between the driver and the front-seat passenger. It incorporates the best-looking, most self-explanatory set of controls that I have seen. The convenience starts with an eight-inch LCD touchscreen for the Sync with MyLincoln Touch system, which is located at the ideal height and distance for the driver. I have heard complaints from fellow automotive journalists about how difficult the MyFord Touch system is to use, but I found the Lincoln version intuitive and user-friendly. I synced my phone easily and enjoyed using the integrated speaker to communicate with my posse. My husband did complain that he couldn’t hear me when the fan was on high, but his audiologist says he is nipping at the need for hearing aids.

The stereo volume and fan speed are controlled by long horizontal bars that you run your finger over to change, and the remaining controls also require just a touch to engage—no knobs here. The open shelf area underneath the center console is genius: it’s lined with a rubbery coating to grab and hold your various accessories.

The exterior styling is unique in the premium mid-size segment. Starting with the split-wing grille—which honestly makes me think of animal whiskers—to the stylishly elongated rear, it has taken a giant step in the right direction. The sleek design has improved the aerodynamics by ten percent over its predecessor.

The MKZ sports LED lamps in the headlights that turn in unison with the steering wheel. In the rear, thin LED taillights stretch across the entire width of the car. The combination of the panoramic roof and the distinctive taillights makes this car a standout not only in this segment but also in the entire sedan world.

The MKZ is rife with standard safety features, but my favorite is the MyKey system, which can be programmed to limit speed and stereo volume. It could be a major disappointment to my teenage daughter but a possible life saver as well. I also was intrigued by the optional inflatable rear seatbelts, which seem like a prudent investment, as do the optional lane keeping system, blind spot information system with cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, and collision warning with brake support. All put together, they make a very pretty face.

I was happy to be driving the V-6 version and played with the standard Lincoln Drive Control, which offers Sport, Normal, and Comfort modes that affect the suspension, steering, and noise control systems—basically how the ride feels. I would also like to spend a little time in the hybrid version, which is available only with front-wheel drive and the four-cylinder engine. On the plus side, it costs the same as the gasoline-engined version. It also gets 45 mpg both in the city and on the highway. By comparison, the front-wheel-drive MKZ with the four-cylinder gets 22/33 mpg, and the V-6 that I drove achieved 18/26 mpg.

I very much enjoyed zipping around town in the MKZ. I did find the road noise a little distracting, and I pondered whether it was the tires, the glass roof, or possibly a combination of both. Speaking of the panoramic roof, it blocks a good portion of the back window when in the fully open position,  but I think it is worth it. However, you should spring for the blind spot monitoring to compensate. On my summer drives I wasn’t able to appreciate the all-wheel drive, but I am sure that it would be a plus when winter rolls around.

The Verdict:

I am not a person who owns luxury-class cars. My driveway generally has much more prosaic vehicles in it. But I have to say that I loved spending a week inside the MKZ, and I wish I had a second week with it. I felt special the whole time and found myself looking for more errands to give me an excuse to drive it more.

In this segment, it is going to be the style that swings a buyer to put down the money. For me, the MKZ has risen to the occasion and could have a spot in my driveway. Best of luck to Lincoln in marketing this vehicle so that it gets the sales it deserves.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott: I liked the simplicity of the MKZ’s interior. I didn’t feel overwhelmed by too many electronics. The only thing that I truly disliked is that, when you fully open the panoramic roof, you can’t really see through the back window very well because the frame of the roof gets in the way. I would get my MKZ without that panoramic roof.

Christina: I was impressed with the design of the MKZ and couldn’t wait to drive it. When I did, I was, for the most part, pleased. The only thing that really bothered me was the distance I had to reach, when comfortably seated, to operate the controls for the side mirrors. Other than that, I loved the sleek controls in the center console and the way the natural light filtered in through the panoramic roof.

Annie: I really like the way the redesigned MKZ looks and was impressed with the package as a whole. There's plenty of technology, some unique features (like the push-button shift), and the interior is comfortable and attractive. But I couldn't get over the price. Options accounted for just about a quarter of the price of this vehicle, and while I loved the panoramic sunroof and the driver assistance technology (including active park assist, lane keeping system, and adaptive cruise control), I'm not sure I loved the prices. If I were buying an MKZ, I'd get one with fewer options. But if I wanted to spend $50,000 on a car, I wouldn't buy an MKZ.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $195,125
This car’s price: $231,535 (prices include $2,725 destination charge and $1,000 gas guzzler tax)
EPA fuel economy: 14 mpg city/24 mpg highway (with twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8 engine that makes 500 horsepower and 487 pound-feet of torque, plus eight-speed ZF transmission with shift paddles)
Safety features: This Bentley has unusual safety items such as aquaplane detection and drag torque control, along with the safety amenities you’d expect such as a rollover protection system, electronic stability control, and traction control; adaptive cruise control and a rearview camera are part of a $3,810 Convenience package
Tech features: Twin figure-eight tailpipes, wind deflector ($535), power trunk ($920), seat ventilation and massage ($840), neck warmer ($980), Naim for Bentley premium audio system with CD changer ($7,155)
Style features: Cross stitching on interior ($3,540), veneered door and rear quarter inserts ($1,110), embroidered Bentley emblems on headrests ($610), crafted veneer case in center console ($560), carpet in trunk that matches interior carpet ($535), duo-tone hide-trimmed steering wheel ($430), deep pile carpet overmats in front and back ($390), jeweled fuel filler cap ($255)
Chief competitors: Since this isn’t like shopping for a Toyota Camry, where every penny counts, here’s a fun competitor list:
• 2014 Aston Martin Vanquish Volante (base price $300,820, including destination charge and gas guzzler tax), on sale in early 2014
• 2013 McLaren MP4-12C Spider (base price $268,250 including destination charge; no gas guzzler tax)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/CuExQk2Z16g?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• There is a Celebrity Cars Blog that tracks what the stars are driving. It frequently shows the famous filling up their vehicles in Hollywood. Among those shown with their Bentleys: David Beckham, Sylvester Stallone, Ludacris, and Lisa Vanderpump from The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills.
• On a classier level, the Bentley has long been the ride of queens. Queen Elizabeth II, who is celebrating her sixtieth year on the throne, has a state Bentley estimated by the voracious British media to be worth more than $15 million. It was a gift from the automaker on the occasion of Her Majesty’s Golden Jubilee, in 2002. Curiously, that car stalled this January as the queen was leaving a church service at Sandringham.
• It’s not unusual for this to be a chauffeur-driven vehicle.
• The elephant in the room with the Bentley? The V-8. An exclusive British car like the Bentley typically comes with twelve cylinders.
• You could argue that the V-8 is a more respectable choice. For one thing, it doesn’t squander as much fuel: 14/24 mpg is decent for a luxury convertible, even if the Continental doesn’t escape the gas guzzler tax. Plus, it saves the customer probably close to $20,000 to choose a Bentley with a V-8 as opposed to a W-12.
• Power is not an issue: Bentley says the V-8 engine sprints from 0 to 60 mph in less than five seconds and has a top speed of more than 180 mph.
• Huge amounts of optional creature comforts are on board, including massaging front seats, wonderful deep pile carpeted floor mats, and embroidered Bentley headrests. In fact, there are sixteen options or packages on the Bentley I drove, which added up to $36,410 over the base price of the car.
• The super rich can go beyond even these substantial option choices and create a one-of-a-kind Bentley Continental GTC. Have a favorite lipstick or handbag? All you have to do is let the Bentley artisans borrow it to create a custom exterior shade to match.

metaDescription: Toyota & Lexus Design Contests: Know any budding car designers? Read about the upcoming Toyota and Lexus art contests at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: For as long as there have been cars, there have been people imagining their dream cars. Sometimes a dream car is one that already exists—a Ferrari or a Lamborghini or a vintage muscle car—and sometimes a dream car is just that: a dream. Maybe it can fly, or maybe it’s gold plated, or maybe flowers come out of the exhaust pipes. People sketch out their dream cars because they are not likely ever to find one like it in the showroom.

Most of the time, nothing comes of these drawings. They are scribbled on napkins and thrown away or scrawled over notes from a calculus lecture and forgotten. But now, Toyota and Lexus are offering two contests aimed at amateur artists, giving car lovers a chance to see their car art turn into something more.

Customize the 2014 Lexus IS F Sport

Lexus is partnering with deviantART, an online community where artists can share their work, for the Lexus IS Design Contest. The contest asks deviantART users to submit their vision for a custom design of the new 2014 Lexus IS F Sport. A winner will be chosen on August 16, and the winning design will be turned into a show car for SEMA, the annual aftermarket and specialty car equipment trade show in Las Vegas. The top design also wins its author a one-year lease on the 2014 IS F Sport. So far, entrants have submitted designs ranging from a relatively reserved IS F Sport with matte gold paint and modified exhausts to one outfitted with rally car headlights, a massive rear spoiler, and off-road tires. Submit your design by August 12 for a chance to see your dream IS F Sport come to life on the floor of SEMA. Or just browse other people's entries.

Look What These Kids Made

Toyota’s contest, the seventh annual Toyota Dream Car Art Contest, is aimed at kids and asks budding artists from around the world to submit a drawing of their dream car. Entrants must be fifteen years old or younger, and are asked to hand draw a picture of their dream car and its surrounding environment. World contest winners (ten from each age group for a total of thirty winners) are invited to an award ceremony in Japan, where they can see their art displayed and spend several days traveling around Japan with their parents. Winning designs from last year were fantastical, including one car that could act as a babysitter to a dozen children at once and a solar-powered model with a tree growing out of the roof. The Silver award last year went to a girl in Vietnam whose design (right) was a car that could "rescue people in flood area[s]."

This year’s contest is already over—winners will be announced at the end of August—but keep an eye out for the 2014 contest.
Not an artist but still fantasize about an unrealistic dream car? Tell us about it in the comments below.

title: Protect Kids from Hot-Car Tragedy
subTitle: Take the time to think about heatstroke danger in cars. Yes, it can happen to you.
promoTeaserSmall: Take the time to think about heatstroke danger in cars. Yes, it can happen to you.
promoTeaser: Take the time to think about heatstroke danger in cars. Yes, it can happen to you.

metaDescription: Protect Kids from Hot-Car Tragedy: Take the time to think about heatstroke danger in cars. There's more you can do. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

homepage.title: protect kids from hot car tragedy

pageElements.text: If there’s anything more gruesome or upsetting than the idea of a child dying of heatstroke, unattended, inside a parked car, I don’t want to know what it is. But the fact is, it’s a problem we all have to face and think about. It’s the number-one cause of non-crash vehicle fatalities for children fourteen and under, and it is something that happens with upsetting regularity around the United States—even when temperatures are what we might think of as reasonable.

In the first half of 2013 alone, twenty children died in this terrible way in the United States. One of them died within thirty miles of where I am sitting right now. Are you sure you know enough about the issue to make sure it never happens to you or anyone you know?
On days when the outdoor temperature is a pleasant 72 degrees, internal vehicle temperature can reach 117 degrees within sixty minutes.

Think about this for a minute: Even when the weather outside is 60 degrees Fahrenheit, the temperature inside your car can reach 110 degrees, and cracking a window does very little to stop that rise in temperature. The American Academy of Pediatrics published a study showing that on days when the outdoor temperature is a pleasant 72 degrees, internal vehicle temperature can reach 117 degrees within sixty minutes, with most of that increase happening in the first half hour. Don’t allow yourself a false sense of security if it doesn’t feel hot outside to you.

You may ask, who would leave their baby in a car and just walk away? We’ve all heard the stereotypes about irresponsible parents who abandon their kids in the car to go play video poker. But this tragedy has also happened to many caring people who made a terrible mistake. So what you can do as a parent is put your cell phone, your purse, or your computer right back there next to the child riding with you. That way, you will always look into the back seat before exiting the car.

What you can do as a citizen is look at the back seats of vehicles when you are walking through a parking lot or structure. If you do see a child in distress due to heat, call 911 immediately and get that child help. 
Safe Kids says to spray the child with cool water to cool him or her down quickly. Children’s bodies have less ability to regulate temperature than those of adults, and they heat up three to five times faster than adults’ bodies.

Here’s something else to think about. Last July, a two-year-old in Wisconsin got the key to a car, opened the trunk, climbed in—and died of heatstroke. So, teach the children in your life not to play in or around cars. Keep your keys out of children’s reach. Show them where the trunk release latch is on your car in case the unthinkable happens and they close themselves into a trunk. If you can’t find your child, immediately look inside every car in the area, and open up the trunk, before you go any farther afield.
It should (but won’t) go without saying: Do. Not. Leave. Your. Kid. In. The. Car. Ever. Talk about this issue with the parents, grandparents, and caregivers you know.

relatedArticles.title: 2013 Toyota Camry

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $32,090 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Ten airbags, including side curtain and rear seat-mounted side airbags; sporty-looking front mesh grille and integrated underbody spoilers
Option I can’t live without: Blind spot monitor ($500)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Passat

What I Think:

The Toyota Camry has a reputation as a solid, practical, smart choice in a five-passenger sedan. It’s rated as the top mid-size car in the J.D. Power Initial Quality Study. It is a Top Safety Pick of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Wait, keep reading! Yes, as with so many things that are solid, practical, and smart, you can be excused for feeling a little bored and reluctant about the Camry. Lentils and carrot juice are similarly good choices, but you probably don’t want them for your birthday dinner.

But don’t sell this fine car short. The reason so many people choose the Camry—ten million of them since the mid-size sedan went on sale thirty years ago—is that they can count on it. It will go and go, and then it will sell at a nice value-retaining price later. Toyota says almost six and a half million of all the Camrys sold are still out there on the road. You probably parked next to one last time you went to the store, although you probably didn’t give it a second glance.

It may be uncool to look at a car as an appliance. But let’s face it, to most people a car is exactly that: it is made out of metal, it has moving parts, and it makes their daily lives easier. With the amount of money a car costs, I think it’s perfectly reasonable to want to buy the longest-lived, most reliable car you can find.

Do you want to have some fun while getting where you want to go, though? Well, you might want to look at the Toyota I looked at: the one with a V-6, eighteen-inch wheels and tires, a sporty grille with mesh accenting and fog lamps, dual chrome exhaust….Yes, on a Camry. It even came in a fetchingly sporty shade of Barcelona Red that I’m calling Verbal Warning Red, since no Camry could ever wear Arrest Me Red, could it?

That depends. Take it on the expressway, as I did, and hit it. The car’s 268 horsepower is more than adequate for everyday driving, and all the Toyota quality and solidity you’d expect can be felt whenever you hit the gas. You do give up some fuel economy with the V-6, but it’s a free country: go ahead and get the 178-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder instead, mated to the same six-speed automatic transmission. Doing that, you can pick up 4 mpg (to 25/35 mpg). Or get the Camry Hybrid, with that same four-cylinder engine making 156 horsepower and getting an even better 43/39 mpg. Up to you.

But let’s talk about the interior. I get what Toyota is going for: predictability and simplicity. You could also call it excessively sober, but there is no doubt where the controls are or how to operate them, and the matte black flush surfaces are stress reducing and not distracting. On the minus side, I dislike the thready-looking silver surfaces (right), which are actually supposed to be an upgrade on the SE model. The leather seats look like something designed by a committee to appeal to male buyers. They’re okay, but they feel stiff and therefore aren’t terribly comfortable. Since people buy the Camry at least in part for reliability, I would think details like the flimsy-feeling sun visors would be turnoffs to prospective buyers.

Among the interior options I liked are a Display Audio package ($650) that includes a 6.1-inch touchscreen display with backup camera, navigation, seven speakers, and HD radio, plus a ninety-day free trial of SiriusXM. The optional blind spot monitor would be $500 well spent. The Camry I drove had a power tilt/slide moonroof that cost $915. I wouldn’t pay that much to get one—but you might want to.

The Verdict:

I’ve heard it said that children are happiest if they have a common first name, even if it makes them one of three Jacobs or Jessicas in their classroom. So go ahead, be like millions of other appliance buyers, and get yourself a Toyota Camry. That’s if you are more interested in reliability and sturdiness than excitement, and if you don’t care that you are driving the same kind of car as millions of other people.

Personally, if I made that decision, I’d probably go with the lower-end Camry with the more fuel-efficient four-cylinder engine. Since the base Camry starts just over $22,000, that choice would save me a few thousand dollars that I would spend to make myself stand out in some other way.
But there’s no doubt that the V-6-powered Camry SE was pretty fun to handle, even if it’s no midlife-crisis treat. You probably can’t go wrong either way.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Camry is simply a vehicle to get you from Point A to Point B without getting in your way. It is perfectly fine to drive but will not impress you. I am a fan of excess, so perhaps I’m not the best critic for this daily driver, but the interior really is numbingly dull. I find myself wondering, why is the Camry America's number-one-selling vehicle? I cannot answer that.

Scott: I thought the Camry was super boring, but I’m really happy that it was, because most cars I test for this website are flashier and have a distracting number of perks and luxuries. The Camry was simple, so I could focus on driving it. It looks outdated compared with a lot of fancier cars, and I prefer that. Some cars are like a trip to Universal Studios. I enjoy going to amusement parks, but I don’t want to live there.

Annie: Color me impressed! I wasn't expecting to have a lot to say about the Camry, but I was pleasantly surprised by the SE's powerful V-6 engine. The Camry isn't going to turn any heads, but it's also not likely to leave you stranded on the side of the road somewhere. If you're looking for reliability with a touch of sportiness, the Camry SE is worth looking at.

Jean: The Camry is the gold standard of reliability and resale. You don’t have to search long to hear a story from someone who’s sold his or her five-year-old Camry for $15,000. This is not, in itself, a reason to recommend a car. Here are the reasons I recommend the Camry SE V6: It’s tight. It’s fast—I spun the wheels from a stop. It’s very nice inside. It has great seats. The steering is surprisingly connected. The console and controls are elegantly executed.

The brakes are not as responsive as I would like, and the body—despite the addition of a little tail spoiler and deep go-fast-looking panels front and rear—is ho-hum and slab sided compared with the competition. If you loved your entry-level Camry over the years and you’re convinced that to stray from the gold standard is a risk you don’t want to take, then by all means move up into a new, loaded Camry SE V6. It’s a honey. A zillion Camry owners out there can’t be wrong.

title: Car Insurance Fail!
promoTeaserSmall: Beware of flying tires—and the fine print on your insurance policy. I learned the hard way.
promoTeaser: Beware of flying tires—and the fine print on your insurance policy. I learned the hard way.
metaDescription: Car Insurance Fail! Read your insurance policy before a flying piece of tire hits you. I learned the hard way. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

promoLarge.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

promoSmall.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

header.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

homepage.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

pageElements.text: I had just a split second to react as the snakelike retread spun off the wheel of the semitruck in front of me on I-275 in Michigan one recent afternoon.

Because my Honda CR-V was hemmed in on either side by other cars, I had little choice but to grip the steering wheel and plow into the huge piece of rubber at about 70 mph. It felt like hitting a chunk of concrete. The retread wound itself around my front tires, taking down the bumper and the wheel arch on the left side. I managed to get the car to the side of the road, my hands still shaking from the ordeal. Of course, the truck driver never stopped.

I was grateful that I was unhurt and that the tire tread didn’t smash into my windshield. My younger son was in the car with me at the time; he managed to disengage the rubber pieces and push the front end back into place temporarily. We immediately headed toward the local car dealership and put in a call to my insurance company.

An Interesting Way to Define "Accident"

I told the insurance company that a large piece of a tire from a semitruck had struck my vehicle. But that’s not how they interpreted the accident. According to their rules, the accident was my fault because I hit something while driving! Keep in mind that I live in Michigan, a so-called no-fault insurance state.

AAA, my insurance carrier, explained that since the accident was not the result of a collision with another vehicle, it fell under the comprehensive portion of my insurance policy, rather than the broad form portion. This is a critical distinction, since, if the accident fell under the latter, it would have meant the deductible would be waived. And, as it turns out, the deductible ran into the hundreds of dollars.

An Even More Interesting Way to Define "Damage"

The insurance company told me that if my vehicle had been damaged in a parking lot, even if I was not inside it at the time, the damage would have been covered and the deductible waived under the broad form section of the policy.
AAA said damage from flying tires is “always” covered under comprehensive, which means the owner must always pay the deductible.
When I threatened to cancel my policy and switch insurance carriers, I was told that this is “industry policy” and it would be pointless to make the change.

Since the accident, I have noticed that every highway I travel is littered with tires and the retreads from semitrucks. They serve as a constant reminder of how unfair this crazy policy is to consumers. It makes me double my effort to steer clear of the big rigs on the road.
The author has chosen to remain anonymous, but she wonders (and so do we), Have you looked at your own insurance policy recently? And do you think this is fair?

title: Decoding Your VIN
promoTeaserSmall: The vehicle identification number tells you so much about your car. Let's crack the code together.
promoTeaser: The vehicle identification number tells you so much about your car. Let's crack the code together.
metaDescription: Decoding your VIN: What does your car's VIN mean? Find out what all those numbers and letters are trying to tell you. The story is at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: No math required, but I am going to be hurtling numbers at you, so be prepared to duck. Just as each U.S. citizen has a nine-digit Social Security number, our vehicles each have a seventeen-character vehicle identification number (VIN). If you are anything like me, you are grabbing your pillow right about now to get comfortable for this snorefest. Well, put your pillow away, because those numbers are actually quite interesting.

The practice of assigning VINs began in 1954. Each manufacturer had its own formula, so, as you can imagine, they were confusing. In 1981, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration developed a standard for all over-the-road vehicles. The current method for assigning VINs in the United States is based on standards set by the International Organization for Standardization. The European Union uses the same standards but applies them differently. The U.S. VINs now each have seventeen characters, and here is a little-known gem—they do not include the letters I, O, or Q.

You may be asking yourself, “Why should I care?” Well, you should care because knowing the VIN for a vehicle can reveal all the deep, dark secrets of a car’s life.  Throughout the life of a vehicle, the VIN is used to record important information such as lemon history, airbag deployments, service and repair information, relevant recalls, and even if the vehicle was used as a taxi. Examining VIN-related records is like reading someone’s personal diary. Especially useful is the title, as it may reveal flood damage, salvage details, or other insurance-related information.

One more thing you need to know is where to locate this magical number. It is on the very top of the dash where it can be viewed through the windshield from outside the vehicle. It is also on a sticker on the driver’s-side doorjamb. There is not an industry standard, but it is also sometimes on engines, hoods, and other parts.

Nerds probably already guessed it, but there is a hidden code in each VIN. This is where the lesson really gets exciting.
    • Positions one to three are the World Manufacturer Identifier.

<ul>
o	Position one identifies the country where the vehicle was manufactured (for example, K for Korea, W for Germany, and 1, 4, or 5 for the United States).
o	Position two is the manufacturer code (for example, T for Toyota or Lexus, D for Mercedes-Benz, and 6 for Cadillac).
o Position three can be used to identify a division or vehicle type. If it is not needed, a nine is used.

• Positions four to eight identify the vehicle’s attributes, such as platform, model, and body style. It is at the discretion of each manufacturer to use this section as it pleases. The eighth digit is commonly used to identify the engine.
• Position nine is a check digit, the result of a crazy mathematical equation that checks to see if there is an error in the VIN.
• Position ten is the model year. Every year is assigned a code character. (The character for 2013 is D.)
• Position eleven is the plant code, which identifies the plant where the vehicle was built.

• Positions twelve to seventeen are the production sequence. This number is given to the vehicle as it comes off the assembly line. Since there is no fixed standard for this number, each manufacturer may use it differently.

So if, for example, you are looking to find out all about a used car before you buy it, a quick way to access knowledge is the VIN. You can find many websites with a quick Google search that let you enter a VIN and find out information about a vehicle. Congratulations! You are now one of a small segment of the population that knows the secrets a VIN can reveal.

metaDescription: Have a Maserati Day! For Charity. The Danville d'Elegance Foundation honors racing legend Phil Hill with a concours, tour, and gala auction in Sonoma, California. Do your part by bidding for a chance to drive a new Maserati and attend a Maserati Trofeo series race as a VIP. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Do you have a recurring dream in which you are piloting a Maserati along California roads, making your way toward a racetrack for an afternoon of action? Here's your opportunity. As part of the Danville d'Elegance Concours and Tour d'Elegance, one lucky bidder will get the chance to get into a new Maserati for a rally drive, followed by watching Maserati Trofeo MC Series cars on the track at Sonoma Raceway from the comfort of the Maserati VIP hospitality area, for you and a guest. The winning bidder gets to drive a 2013 or 2014 Maserati Quattroporte, GranTurismo, or GranTurismo Sport. Best of all, the auction proceeds will go to support Parkinson's research and care.
The event takes place on Saturday, August 24. It all starts at the showroom of event sponsor Maserati of Walnut Creek. Auction bidding started today, August 2, and will continue for seven days.
You can bid at this link.

Why Parkinson's? This charitable connection is in honor of the late Phil Hill, the great American racing legend, whose first Grand Prix race, in 1958, was in a Maserati 250F. Hill, who died in 2008 from complications of Parkinson's, was a supporter and participant in the Danville d'Elegance festivities. The Danville d'Elegance Foundation has given more than half a million dollars to Team Fox, the grassroots wing of the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's research. The Danville organization also gives generously to the Parkinson's Institute of Sunnyvale, California. The weekend activities are led by volunteers, many of whom have a Parkinson's connection in their own lives. So what's keeping you from bidding?

metaDescription: 2014 Nissan Versa Note is an all-new version of the small car that could be a good choice for the bargain hunter. See my short, sweet video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2014 Nissan Versa Note S

Base price: $14,780 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $14,780 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 31 mpg city/40 mpg highway (with 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine plus five-speed manual transmission; a continuously variable automatic transmission, or CVT, is optional)
Safety features: Six airbags, vehicle dynamic control, traction control, tire pressure monitoring system
Tech features: Easy Fill Tire Alert system, optional on the SV (the horn beeps when you hit the correct tire pressure while refilling); Active Grille Shutter to cut aerodynamic drag (in the $760 Sport Value package on the S Plus and SV models); SL Tech package for the SV ($800) includes Around View monitor, navigation, Nissan Voice Recognition for audio and navigation, hands-free text messaging assistant, and heated side mirrors
Chief competitors: Ford Fiesta S hatchback, Honda Fit, Kia Rio LX
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/bz-J9CR9cTE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• Consumers may find the nomenclature confusing. The Note is the name of the car in other markets—it’s the Versa Note in the United States and Canada and just the Note in Mexico, Japan, Europe, and elsewhere. Nissan is trying to make a “global connection” and signal that this hatchback is different from its predecessor, the 2012 Versa hatchback (there wasn’t a 2013).

• The redesign packs a bigger visual punch than the outgoing Versa hatchback. Details include taillights like those on the sporty Nissan Z.
• Here’s a nice surprise: the Versa Note is $670 cheaper than the outgoing Versa hatchback (which started at $15,450, including $780 destination).
• The Versa Note also gets better gas mileage than the 2012 Versa hatchback, which topped out at 28 mpg in the city and 34 mpg on the highway.

• There are two transmission choices and one engine on all Versa Note models: a 1.6-liter four-cylinder that makes 109 horsepower, and the choice of a five-speed manual transmission (on the base S only, as seen in the video) or a continuously variable Xtronic automatic transmission.
• The 2014 Versa Note went on a major diet compared with the 2012 Versa hatchback, shedding 281 pounds (it’s 2,412 pounds, compared with the old model’s 2,693 pounds).
• The Versa Note is undeniably a bargain, but it’s not the cheapest subcompact hatchback. That honor is reserved for the Kia Rio, with a 2013 base price of $14,600, including $800 destination. The Kia’s 2014 price hasn’t yet been announced, though.
• Nissan is in the midst of an aggressive pricing strategy that’s rocking the auto industry. For instance, the automaker cut the price of the 2014 370Z coupe by more than $3,000 and cut prices on seven key models earlier this year.

• The Versa Note has some class-exclusive features, including the optional Around View Monitor, a camera system to make parallel parking easier, and an aerodynamics-improving Active Grille Shutter (part of the $760 Sport Value package on the S Plus model).
• It’s easy to get the price up close to $20,000, especially if you order the top Versa Note 1.6 SV and start adding options. Among them: sixteen-inch alloy wheels ($700), a rear roof spoiler ($310), a chrome package ($290), a rear cargo cover ($90), and an interior illumination package ($455).
• Inside, the Versa Note has ample cabin space and amazing cargo capacity behind the rear seats. The downside is that the interior looks dated, with too much plastic.

metaDescription: Queen's Daimler up for Auction: Her Majesty's Daimler will be up for auction soon. Read about the royal car at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: “One Careful Lady Owner.” Now there’s an auction listing for a vintage car that should draw some attention. In this case, the Lady Owner of the car, a 2001 Daimler V8 Super LWB, is none other than Queen Elizabeth II. Once her personal vehicle, the Daimler, clad in British racing green paint, is a member of the Jaguar family. The car is going up for auction by Historics at Brooklands in the U.K. on August 31.

And you thought Prince William’s star turn in a Range Rover, when he actually drove his wife and newborn princeling child home from the hospital last week, was all the car news you were going to get on the British royal family. Not a bit of it.

The queen had this car built specifically for her own private use, meaning she herself was the one behind its regal wheel. Her Majesty racked up 11,000 miles over three years, mainly driving it between Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace, a distance of some twenty miles each way. She kept the car until 2004, and it is now being held by the Jaguar Daimler Heritage Trust. It currently has 15,242 miles on the odometer and was last publicly displayed at the 2012 Goodwood Festival of Speed, as part of the Cartier Royal Jubilee display.

The Daimler has lamb’s-wool rugs and a full leather interior, along with all the expected luxuries. However, imagine you were queen and could choose whatever extra amenities you like. True to her no-nonsense nature, Elizabeth II’s custom choices include a center armrest with a slide-out section for her legendary handbag, as well as switches to allow her to operate all the windows from either side. The monarch got those because she wanted extra fresh air but specified she doesn’t enjoy having it blow directly on her face. Well, who does?

Another interesting touch on the car is a set of communication equipment to put Her Majesty directly through to the Home Office or to the prime minister at No. 10 Downing Street. Sadly, that feature is disabled, so the next owner will have to get in line like anybody else. However, still operational is a set of blue lights hooked up behind the rearview mirror to tip off security forces about which car held the queen. There are also strobe lights that, the auction house points out, provide the bonus of extra visibility in the unlikely event of a smoke attack.
The Daimler has a supercharged 4.0-liter V-8 that makes 375 horsepower. Because Elizabeth II, as is well known, likes horses quite a lot.
The auction house is looking to get somewhere in the $40,000 range for the car. Ready to place your order for it? Go peruse the Historics at Brooklands listing and register to bid.

title: '14 Chevrolet Volt Dips under $35K
promoTeaserSmall: By cutting $5,000 from the plug-in hybrid's price, Chevy is keeping up as competitors' prices fall.
promoTeaser: By cutting $5,000 from the plug-in hybrid's price, Chevy is keeping up as competitors' prices fall.
metaDescription: '14 Chevrolet Volt Dips under $35K: Chevrolet has cut $5,000 off the price of its plug-in, following the lead of other EVs like the Nissan Leaf. Read the details on JeanKnowscars.com.

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Volt is getting closer in price to traditionally powered sedans, not to mention its plug-in competition, now that General Motors has cut its price by $5,000 for 2014.

The plug-in Volt will now start at $34,995 including destination charge. Subtract the federal tax credit of up to $7,500, and you're looking at a price that you don't have to be an EV early adopter to like.
Read More on EV Prices Unplugged: Interested in going electric, but stopped by the MSRP? Check out price cuts from major EV makers.

Don Johnson, U.S. sales and service vice president for Chevrolet, says the automaker has "made great strides in reducing costs as we gain experience with electric vehicles and their components." The Volt was eagerly anticipated at the time of its launch in 2010, when its base price was $41,000. It offers 98 MPGe on electric power for up to thirty-eight miles, plus 35 mpg city/40 mpg highway on gasoline power.

Competitors have made similar moves. Nissan cut pricing on its 2013 Leaf, which now starts at $29,650 before tax credits, while the plug-in Toyota Prius starts at $32,810. Currently there are several lease deals on EVs that reflect both the improving cost of the technology and automakers' response to less than spectacular sales figures. Of the plug-ins on the market, GM notes, the Volt is the top seller.
The 2014 Volt will reach dealerships by summer's end. The only changes over the current model: a leather-wrapped steering wheel and two new colors, Ashen Gray Metallic and Brownstone Metallic.

The Car:

Price: $35,345 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter inline four-cylinder, 181 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/34 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Semi-automatic convertible roof
Option I can’t live without: Mini Wired package, including voice command, navigation, Bluetooth, and USB/iPod connectivity ($750)
You might also be considering: Audi TT, Fiat 500, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Volkswagen Eos

See more specs on the Mini Cooper in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I think everyone in America would agree that the Mini Cooper S Roadster is cute. The question is, could you live with one as your daily driver? At least at this time of year, the idea is tempting. After all, summer is short in Michigan, so you have to take advantage of every second. So, when I was offered a chance to drive the Roadster, I said, “Hell, yes!”

My first moments with the Roadster were frustrating. I attempted to put the top down without reading the manual and was stymied. I could see easily that there was a manual latch on the roof and a button at the top of the windshield, but I undid the latch and button, and then nothing happened. I consulted the manual, but it did not shed light on the subject. The answer is actually hidden in the description: semi-automatic cloth top. It was trial and error that solved the mystery:

1. Unlatch the roof.</br>
2. Slightly open the roof manually. (This was the part I had been missing.)</br> 
3. Press the button.</br> 
4. Voilà! The roof opens.</br>
It was raining slightly, but I relied on aerodynamics to whip the water away. I prayed to the traffic gods to make all my lights green so I wouldn’t get rained on, and my prayers were answered.

It is exhilarating to be in a convertible, especially a two-seater, so it is tough to have a critical eye. However, I do have some issues with the general layout of the Roadster’s instrument dials—round dials like Mickey Mouse ears that are mounted on the top of the steering column. Meanwhile, the speedometer is in the center of the vehicle. It is not intuitive to look over to the center to check your speed, and on top of that, the speedometer is not easy to read. I realize that a center speedometer is part of the Mini heritage, but you could achieve the same feeling by putting something less essential in the center position—for instance, the Openometer, a dial that monitors how long the roof has been open over the life of the vehicle as well as on the current drive. (I am sure that number becomes a bragging stat to share with fellow Mini enthusiasts.)

In general, the Roadster’s interior reminds me of Apple products. Everything  is tactilely pleasing and design focused. The subtle checkerboard motif is present on the seats and on the dash, and the two-tone steering wheel is so exquisite that it could hang on a wall at MOMA. A tiny joystick is placed directly behind the shifter so that you can easily operate the radio, navigation, and other settings. And, as with Apple, you are either a believer or you are not.

Since this is a British car at heart, I like to call the trunk a boot. The boot is similar to Beyoncé’s, and it can seriously twerk. (You may need to Google that.) The boot holds 240 liters (8.5 cubic feet). To clarify, there is enough room for two people’s luggage for a two-week vacation, which is much better than the 5.3 cubic feet you’ll find in a Mazda MX-5 Miata, but you will still have to leave your bike at home.

This four-cylinder engine is a hoot to drive, thanks to the energetic turbo. As I was cruising down the highway and needing to pass a vehicle or get a pesky tailgater off my Beyoncé boot, slight pressure on the accelerator, and boom! I was gone. Not all turbos deliver as immediately as this one does.

On my smooth highway route, the ride was sublime, and I enjoyed the beautiful 360-degree view with the top down. The engine sound is perfect. It is not so obnoxious that heads turn, yet it implies that the Roadster is fun to drive. However, because of the short wheelbase and the low-profile tires, the Roadster has a very tight suspension that delivers a very harsh ride. A lot of steering correction is required, as the car is a bloodhound for imperfections in the road.

For days when driving with the top down is not an option, I would recommend riding your bike, taking public transportation, hitchhiking, or just staying home. The thin cloth roof makes for a very loud ride. It also makes a better door than a window—as in huge blind spots.

The Verdict:

Living in Michigan, I would need to use the Mini Cooper S Roadster as my summer-fall car because it is not practical for our four seasons. The designers have definitely led with form over function, but I am a believer. So, if I was choosing a two-seater, it would be a “Hell, yes!” for the Mini over the Mazda Miata so that I could fill the boot up to the brim.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott: This car looks to me like the Cloud Car from The Care Bears. Although flying in a cloud in the sky as a Care Bear would be very cool, I would like a more reasonable car down here on the ground. I also wouldn’t feel comfortable, safety-wise, owning a fabric-topped car. Driving the Mini Roadster is like listening to today’s Top 40 pop music. It was too bubblegum for me.

Annie: I mostly love the Mini Cooper S Roadster. It's cute, it's quick, and the top comes off. What more could you want? Well, for $30K-plus you might want a fully automatic convertible top and better radio controls. I know I did. I also found myself wishing for a more intuitive dashboard setup. I was driving for at least ten minutes before I finally located the fuel gauge under the giant, center-mounted speedometer. All flaws I could get over easily if the reward was driving the Roadster every day. It's pure fun.

Laura: I am not in either demographic that would go for the Mini Roadster: the pampered student and the midlife-crisis shopper. So, no, I would never even consider buying one. On the other hand, I see what people love about it. Heads turn when it goes by, which is kind of fun. And when you sit behind the wheel, you find yourself in an intensely personal, cocoon-like space, which is really fun. This is a car you would hog to yourself and not let your friends or relatives drive, a car you would name (Nigel? Philippa?) and go out driving in at six a.m. for the hell of it. It’s a life-is-short car. Yes, it’s a bit twee, and its stylists are trying too hard, but if you are the right person to fit it, you won’t care.

Jean: The Mini Roadster has been controversial from the beginning, so I would say that, no, everyone in America might not find it cute. I do, though. I also love the extra silliness baked into the interior (the Openometer??) mixed with standout features like the two-tone leather-wrapped steering wheel in dove gray and black and the little multicontroller knob on the floor that controls the infotainment system. But can you live with it day in and day out? The trunk is a yawning cavern, and the turbocharged engine is so powerful and quick that you’ll be totally satisfied with the automatic transmission. The steering, however, is too light at center, followed by a startling bite as you corner. This you can learn to live with. But there is no living with the Mini Roadster’s buckboard of a suspension if you travel on rough roads regularly. Live on a dirt road? It will break your teeth.

pageElements.text: It’s a whole new car-shopping world out there. It used to be, you’d go out to the dealership and pay cash for a new car or finance it over a couple of years. Gradually, as car prices have increased and more luxurious choices in transportation have become available, those finance terms have started to grow until, today, it’s not unusual to see five-year or even six-year finance contracts.

So it’s not so surprising that people have started to see leasing as a viable alternative: get a nice new car, take on an affordable monthly payment, and repeat every few years. It seems counterintuitive that, in a marketplace where the average age of cars on the road is eleven years, leasing should be so strong (every month this year, J.D. Power and Associates reports, at least 22.5 percent of deals have been leases). Behind both statistics, you’ll find the same reason: cost saving.

When you lease, you’re using that new car for a set length of time and then giving it back. In that way, it’s like renting a house instead of buying one: it’s yours, but it’s not really yours. The benefit is that you are getting a brand-new vehicle—and probably one that is fancier than you would have been able to afford to buy—and only worrying about fuel and insurance, not long-term maintenance and resale.

Once reluctant to lease rather than buy, today women are increasingly interested in leasing, according to a study just released by the trading website Swapalease.com. More than 67 percent of women surveyed said they are “likely” or “extremely likely” to consider a lease next time they shop for a vehicle.

The study also reports that women are more practical and rational about leasing.  More than 44 percent of women surveyed are looking for monthly payments at or below $299 per month, compared with only 24.7 percent of men. And they are looking more often to lease from brands such as Honda and Toyota than brands such as Cadillac and BMW.

While leasing is especially popular for luxury and high-priced vehicles, it’s increasingly popular for more mainstream cars, too. Take, for example, the Toyota Camry, available in August at a $199-per-month lease rate over twenty-four months, with $999 due at signing. How can they afford to offer such a deal? It’s because the residual value of that car is so high; Toyota has no doubt its dealers will find buyers willing to pay good money for the two-year-old, low-mileage Camrys it will have on its lot at the end of the lease term.
You might be one of those people looking for a great lease deal as a way to get more car than you could otherwise afford. What do you need to know to do it right? Here are some guidelines.

1. Don’t let the monthly payment be the only number you think about.

Leasing is a kind of financing, too. For one thing, you might want to buy the car outright at the end of the lease, and you’ll then be held to the price you have signed for. You want to make sure the car is going to be worth that number in the end. In dealer speak, the total price of a leased car is the “capitalized cost,” which should be close to the price you’d pay if you were buying it. Negotiate the total price of the car, just as you’d do as a buyer, and only then let the salesperson break it down into lease numbers.

Now, if you are getting a great deal like the one on the Camry mentioned above, you might not be able to negotiate anything about the total price. These are called “subsidized leases,” and the low price you’re getting will probably be a good enough deal as is, as long as the dealer doesn’t add a bunch of fees on top of it.  Which leads us to:

2. Pay attention to fees.

Document fees, title and registration fees, an acquisition fee, a disposition fee (to be paid if the lessee doesn’t buy the vehicle at the end of the lease), even a tire fee showed up on the lease agreement a New York Times reporter signed for a new Infiniti G37x. Each of these fed into the overall lease payment and nudged it upward.

3. Don’t just take the lease language for granted.

A big sticking point for many people considering a lease is that the number of miles you can drive the car is limited, usually to less than 15,000 miles per year. Consumer Reports suggests you negotiate that number or ask about buying extra miles up front, with the understanding that the money you put down will be refunded if you don’t go over the limit. You should also negotiate the down payment, known in leases as the “capitalized cost reduction.”

However, there's one thing you probably can't negotiate: the length of the lease. There’s usually a big penalty if you turn the leased car in before the term ends. That explains the proliferation of lease-swapping websites. Uncomplicate your life, and don’t impulsively sign on to a lease you may not want to follow through on.

The bottom line is, ask yourself if you are a thirty-nine-month person or an eleven-year person. Are you the kind of person who can feel good about turning in a car after a few years and starting fresh with a new one, or would you prefer to stick with one car and build equity over several years? Interest rates are low, and residual values are high as cars continue to improve in quality and longevity. Both of those trends mean it’s a good time either to buy or to lease a car—it’s up to you how you go about it.

title: 2014 Ford Mustang GT
promoTeaserSmall: Fast, fun, unrefined: what's not to love? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: Fast, fun, unrefined: what's not to love? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: Fast, fun, a little unrefined: that's the 2014 Ford Mustang GT, all right. Read my review, and the responses from our Peanut Gallery, on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $37,525 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: LED sequential taillamps
Option I can’t live without: GT Track package ($2,495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Camaro, Dodge Challenger
See more specs on the Mustang in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

If you hang around long enough with people who like cars, you’ll eventually hear someone say, “It’s better to drive a slow car fast than a fast car slow!” to general nods of agreement. I’ve said it myself, and I never miss an opportunity to drive my slow car with reckless abandon. But after spending a weekend in a 2014 Ford Mustang GT, I can report with certainty that the best thing of all is to drive a fast car fast.

The Mustang GT may have four wheels and an engine, but, like all Mustangs, it’s more than just a car. It has fifty years of pony car heritage behind it. It’s the kind of car little kids imagine they’ll own some day, the kind of car people ask for rides in and take pictures of. And the 2014 Mustang GT deserves that respect. It’s not that there’s nothing to complain about—ask anyone who’s tried to squeeze into the back seat. It’s just that it’s so @#*%@ fun that you don’t care.

The 2014 Mustang comes in three flavors: V6, GT, and Shelby GT500. All three are available as coupes or convertibles, and the V6 and GT variants can come as base or Premium models. Premium Mustangs come equipped with a few more comfort features than the base models, including a power passenger’s seat, a Shaker sound system, Sync with AppLink, and a 4.2-inch LCD message center. Options on the Premium model include heated front seats (Comfort package, $650) and navigation (Electronics package, $2,340). The V6 models get their power from a 305-horsepower V-6 engine. All GT models use a 5.0-liter V-8, while the ultra-performance Shelby GT500 models use a 5.8-liter supercharged V-8 to make an astounding 662 horsepower.

The Mustang GT’s key feature is its V-8 engine, which makes 420 horsepower and 390 pound-feet of torque. The engine produces an intoxicating, burbling exhaust note that I liked so much that I often avoided shifting into the higher gears when cruising around town, just so I could hear the engine noise in the cabin.

Our test car came with the GT’s standard manual transmission, which was smooth and easy to operate. The GT is available with an automatic transmission, but I wouldn’t give up the control and engagement of a stick for anything, not even the three extra city mpg that drivers of automatic GTs get.

The manual Mustang GT is rated at 19 mpg combined, a figure I didn’t quite manage during my weekend. (I averaged 18.6 mpg with a mix of city and highway driving.) A more sedate driving style would likely solve that problem, but then you’d miss out on the full-throttle accelerations that make this car worth all the minor inconveniences. I didn’t get the chance to do much cornering in the Mustang, but I could tell that it would be a dream donut car with the traction control turned off.

Like most small sports cars, the Mustang GT is far from practical. It has a rear seat, but it’s really more of a luggage rack than anything else. The Mustang's rear-wheel-drive setup means it might not be a wise choice for drivers who have to weather snowy winters—although it's worth noting that I drove it through heavy rain completely without incident. The interior wouldn’t pass muster in any other $37,000 car; it’s a study in black plastic. The $1,595 Recaro sport seats may keep driver and passenger from sliding around on tight corners, but they’re not particularly comfortable or attractive. The radio and CD player look like something straight out of 2005. That might be a blessing in disguise, though: Ford’s MyFord Touch infotainment system has endured tough criticism since its introduction in 2011.

The Verdict:

So, should you buy it? No, probably not. It’s not practical, it’s not efficient, and it’s not comfortable. On the other hand, neither are any of its direct competitors. If you’re looking for practical, comfortable, and efficient, you’re already looking elsewhere. If you’re looking for fast, fun, and, yes, a little unrefined, look at the Mustang GT. If you love the way Mustangs look but can't quite get over the fuel economy ratings, the V6 model, with its 31 mpg highway, could be worth a look. As for the Shelby GT500: 662 horsepower seems gratuitous, but then again, that's kind of the point.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Mustang made its debut the year after I was born. By the time I was in high school, 1960s muscle cars, especially Mustangs, gave their drivers a lot of street cred in my small rural hometown. In fact, I dated one guy specifically because he had a Mustang. (It was summer.) The interior of the 2014 Mustang GT has kept the candle burning for the original aesthetic, so much so that I think I can still smell smoke in the air. But, since the 2005 redesign, Ford has been honing this thoroughly modern Mustang. The choice of speedometer and rpm dials perfectly incorporates the design cues of the car's forefathers. I regret that I did not get to drive it at night to see them glow. The massive black dash seems sort of cheap in comparison with some modern materials that are available to designers, but I appreciate the nod to the old-school style. I believe that the choice of materials will help this car lend itself to being someone's collector Mustang.

Laura: My dad bought one of the first Mustangs in 1965. Because of the commercial that was everywhere at the time, in which people on the street corner shouted "Mmmustang!" as the lucky driver went past, I remember people actually doing that to us when we drove by in our white six-cylinder coupe. At the time, our family included three kids aged ten and under, so it was a stretch to fit everyone inside. (That's okay; our other family car was a Corvair.) This early experience and a life lived in southeastern Michigan make me like the Ford Mustang almost automatically. I appreciate the black-on-black styling of the one we tested, and I would definitely get the 5.0-liter GT or not get a Mustang at all. The sound it makes probably still says "Mmmustang!" to some people; I felt Mmmortified at the racket I was kicking up, but there's no doubt it sounds just as exciting as it feels. No false advertising here!

Jean: Until just a few years ago, Mustangs were old shoes with big motors. Rude, crude, and a laugh riot to drive. Now they are as hot to look at as they are to drive. Make mine a 5.0 GT or a Shelby. The Mustang logo ought to have a cartoon Road Runner cyclone around its hooves. Giddyup!
