contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: There’s a ritual about car buying that can look a little frightening when viewed from the outside. If you read enough online advice and talk to enough people at the water cooler, you can start feeling downright paranoid about the intentions of the sales staff. Are they looking to trick you? I asked successful saleswoman Beth Bashert from Dunning Toyota in Ann Arbor, Michigan, some questions about finding a comfortable shopper-salesperson relationship. I think you'll find her insights interesting.

metaDescription: Bright colors are coming back! The latest BASF study on automotive color trends reveals that North Americans are feeling optimistic and will soon want brighter-colored cars. See the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Are you driving a white or silver car but feeling an urge for bright green coming on? Well, two to three years from now, apparently, we will all be buying cars in brighter colors and with more interesting paint textures. That’s according to the annual automotive color trend survey from paint supplier BASF. Green and yellowish-green are going to be big, and matte finishes or special effects that make color look three-dimensional will be popular, or so it says.

Jewel Tones, Anybody?

The company has released a new palette of sixty-five colors for automakers and designers. For North America, the BASF color groups are called Aspire, Dequalize, Multiverse, and Syncopace. Good thing this company is only updating the car color lexicon, not the dictionary! From the way people chose among the colors, BASF sees “optimism” in our future: 60 percent of North American consumers are currently driving a silver, black, or white car. But what 49 percent liked best on the BASF future-color wheel were jewel-toned shades of red and blue.

Europe Feeling Rational

In the Asia-Pacific region, the survey shows that neutral colors are going to stay on top, but “sophisticated intermediate” shades such as olive green and bluish gray will gradually gain popularity, says BASF. In Europe, which is struggling through economic and energy challenges, rationality wins the day. A subtle metallic color called Particular Gray was popular, but survey respondents also liked black as well as “courageous colors” including red and green. But, perhaps departing from rationality for a minute, Europeans also went for Fiberphyllic, described as "a bold yellowish-green offering a more expressive coarse feel."

More Matte to Come?

You can already buy limited-edition matte paint on the Hyundai Veloster Turbo (right, in Matte Gray), the BMW M3, and several models of Mercedes-Benz. The flat look is unusual and, in my opinion anyway, gorgeous, but it’s reputedly much harder to care for than the glossy kind. Will we all be driving matte-paint cars, or chartreuse crossovers, five years from now? And won't the street scene be more interesting if we are?

Here are more color stories for you, leaving little doubt as to where we stand on bright colors for cars.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: The most common questions I get asked about my job as an automotive journalist are “Can you drive stick?” and “Are you scared?” The first (also the most common question men in bars ask when they find out I write about cars) has legitimate practical applications. The second is almost always asked when I’m behind the wheel of a fast car, and it completely baffles me. It has never occurred to me to be scared of driving fast. Poisonous spiders are what I’m scared of. Fast cars are what I dream about.

Most recently, the question was posed by Jean Knows Cars videographer Scott Allen while he was filming me from the pit lane of a driver development track. We were at the famous Canadian Tire Motorsport Park, outside Toronto, Ontario, where I was participating in Bridgestone’s two-day racing academy. At that precise moment, I was sitting behind the wheel of a tiny Formula SCCA open-wheel racing car, waiting for my first turn around the mile-long track.

I guess it was a fair question, though, since I was sitting just a few inches off the ground, with nothing but a helmet and a five-point harness to protect me if I sent my car spinning into a wall. Not that I was planning on that. I’d never driven an open-wheel car before, and I had resolved to spend my first few sessions on the track taking my time and familiarizing myself with the car. This strategy landed me squarely in the slower of the two groups of auto journalists, but I didn’t mind; I’ve always preferred exceeding low expectations to disappointing high ones.

Our cars were 1,000-pound rockets: Van Diemen Formula SCCA cars, with 2.3-liter, 170-horsepower engines capable of going from 0 to 60 mph in four seconds. The cars were fitted with Bridgestone's Potenza RE-11 performance tires, which can also be fitted to your street car. Our instructors said that top speeds for those cars on that track would top out around 70 to 80 mph, achievable on the long straight stretch just before the last, sharpest corner. In lieu of a speedometer, we had digital tachometers in the steering wheel, with a row of lights that glowed green in the power band between 4,500 and 6,500 rpm, then red as the engine neared redline.

I focused on hitting the apex cones at each corner and experimented with braking later and hitting the gas harder. We were driving in groups of three, following an instructor. I don’t have much experience on the track, so for the first few sessions I was glad to have a guide. But by the end of our first day, I was itching to circle the track at my own pace.

Day two brought with it unforgiving heat, with temperatures heading into the nineties. Not the kind of day you want to spend zipped into a full-body racing suit. With just a few hours left before my racing car turned into a pumpkin, though, I wasn't about to complain.

The instructors still went out on the course with us, but we weren't playing follow the leader anymore and could move at our own speed. And by the time lunch rolled around, we were on the track alone, and our laps were being timed.

If I was holding back before, letting my desire to perfect my technique overpower my love of pure speed, all it took was one look at my group's lap times to set me straight. I was the second slowest of our five-person group. Priorities rearranged, I got back in the car for our second set of timed laps.

This time, I pushed the car as hard as my skill would allow. I braked later, accelerated harder, and took the corners faster. On the back straightaway, where (we'd been warned during our first class) inexperienced drivers often got nervous and spun out, I pressed the accelerator flat to the floor. The car zoomed forward at what felt like a reckless speed, the wind lifting at my helmet, my heart pounding, my eyes wide.
Yes, that's what I've been looking for, I thought to myself. More of that, please.

My new attitude brought with it a new ranking, with my little racing car turning in our group's second-fastest lap during the second session. During our final timed session a spinout slowed me, and I fell back in our group's rankings, but I’d gotten what I came for. Two days on the track gave me my first performance driving experience, and I came away with a dose of speed strong enough to satisfy my lead foot for a while.

Your Turn!

Luckily, you don’t have to be a journalist to get access to a track. Bridgestone runs this two-day racing school every year to give auto journalists a chance to test the company’s high performance tires in a track setting (and the Potenza tires performed admirably, keeping me and my car squarely stuck to the track under very enthusiastic driving). But they also have sessions that you can sign up for.

Drivers can experience the Bridgestone Racing Academy in half-day, full-day, two-day, and three-day courses. All courses include time with an instructor and laps in one of the school’s open-wheel racing cars. Time on the track is directly related, as you might expect, to the price you pay. The half-day course costs $295 to $595 Canadian, and the most expensive three-day course earns drivers a racing license and costs $3,995 Canadian. Check out the details on the Bridgestone Racing Academy website, and don't miss the academy's Welcome Americans! page.

If Toronto’s too far to go to satisfy your craving for speed, don’t fret. There are plenty of racing and performance driving schools in the United States, too. A Google search should point you to nearby tracks, and then it’s just a matter of squirrelling away your extra cash until you can afford seat time.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I have watched the telecom industry’s powerful It Can Wait texting-while-driving public service ad series several times. Each time, it moved me to tears. And then it gradually faded from memory. I know that the personal tragedies that occur at the rate of more than 100,000 each year from texting while driving never fade. That 100,000 number? It’s on the rise even as our driving skills diminish and we find it increasingly impossible to separate our hands from our cell phones.

Now, the famed documentary filmmaker Werner Herzog (Even Dwarves Started Small; Grizzly Man) is having a go at the message. He’s filmed a thirty-five-minute mini-documentary, using subjects from the spots, one of which he directed. (This documentary is co-sponsored by the four major cell phone providers: AT&T, Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile.)

I was loath to commit an entire thirty-five minutes online to watching the newest emotional onslaught against texting and driving, but this was Werner Herzog, and I was having my own battle with phone addiction, if not texting, then talking and glancing. And if you don’t think that was a hard sentence to write, read the mail I get every time I admit it. I’m hoping that you’ll admit it, too. And I’m asking you to watch this movie, as hard as I promise you it will be.

The film opens with a woman’s empty hand and dark, haunting music. “I had my brother in my hand, and all of a sudden my hand was empty,” says Aurie, beginning the story of how a young girl ran through a four-way stop while texting and smashed Aurie's little brother Xzavier from her grasp. He lived, but it is difficult to watch that diminished life.

It is equally awful to watch Chandler Gerber’s haunting and excruciatingly detailed description of the day he smashed through an Amish buggy while texting with his wife on his way to work. He was driving into the sun. He wasn’t speeding. He thinks he was reading a text. Watch him tell about what happened, and imagine how easily it could be any one of us.

“I felt like it was just a dream. For weeks, I thought, did I dream that accident?
I’m just a young guy. I got a wife and a daughter on the way. I’m just a guy. This couldn’t have happened to me. That can’t be real. I had to have just dreamed that."
Gerber hit the buggy from behind and ended up 430 feet past the impact.

“My head snapped up, when I…I saw…the windshield just…glass broke…and screeching...and my head. It happened in about a second. As I started coming to a stop, I saw a body come down from off the top of the van. And I thought, ‘Oh my gosh, what have I done?’

“It was totally silent outside the van. At that second in time, there was nobody else coming or going. I walked around back and looked in the ditch. There was bodies just laying there. It was just silent, just quiet. The only sound I heard, the only thing I saw moving was the horse. It was severely wounded, it was moving around on the ground a little bit. No one else was around. Just me and the family that was laying in the ditch, and the horse, and just silence.”
“I wish so bad I could go back to that day. Please don’t do it. Don’t ever text and drive. You get one chance and you live with the choices you make.”
I'm thinking very clearly about the choice I'm going to make.

pageElements.text: They’re already the most stylish toy cars out there, for parents who want to bring up children with a sense of quality and an appreciation for fine soft wood, not brittle plastics. Now Automoblox has gone above and beyond as a toy maker, with a lineup of emergency response vehicles that you won’t want to wait until the holiday season to buy for the children in your life.

Automoblox was founded by an industrial designer, Patrick Calello, whose stated aim was “to teach kids how to think in 3D.” And indeed, Automoblox toys are an aesthetically pleasing combination of building blocks and model cars that kids can put together, take apart, and mix and match. They’re also so beautiful that even grownups will want to play with them. And get this: the cars have their own VINs that kids can register to gain access to posters, decals, cards, and other swag from the Automoblox Owners Club. It’ll be a short hop to the Corvette or Porsche owners’ clubs later in life for many of these kids, no doubt.

Foremost on the new additions list is the T900 Rescue Truck ($50), with a V-shaped light bar, oversize tires that spill out of the wheel wells, a flat black front push bar, and a pair of shiny silver rescue driver figurines, one of each gender.

The X9 Fire SUV ($45) is the sleekest of fire trucks, with a slim red light bar, a set of rugged wheels, a trunk-mounted spare tire, and a cowcatcher grille. And the low-slung S9 Police Cruiser ($45) has a polycarbonate light bar that appears lit up from inside (although it’s not; there’s no electronic gadgetry here).

But don’t let these three newbies be the end of your Automoblox shopping. The lineup includes every body style, from sports cars and hot rods, plus their trailers, to a highly stylized pickup truck. There are mini cars, too, most of which are priced at $30 for a three-pack.

These are not the battery-ravenous gewgaws you can buy at Toys R Us. They’re a whole different kind of toy: one that requires a suspension of disbelief and a commitment to pretend play on the part of its user. What’s that? Kids have to use their imaginations? Great.

metaDescription: Fiat Lust: Decisions...Decision. In Part 4, I'm ready to commit to a Fiat. Deciding which one brought out the deliberative side of my personality. Find out how I found the One and made a commitment. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: My story began in the winter with Part One, when I first started considering whether I could justify replacing my Honda Odyssey with a Fiat 500. It continued in Part Two, when I overcame envy of others driving Fiats and made my own shopping list. In Part Three, I started the test-driving experience. And the saga continues:

A colleague of mine bought a car recently. In less than a week, he had picked his make (Toyota), model (Camry Hybrid), accessories (none), named his price (low), and taken delivery. Exceptional efficiency, driven in part by necessity, given that his engine had fried, but I suspected that there was more to it than that. I suspected pragmatism, and I asked how he ordered food at a restaurant. “I look at the menu, decide what I want, and order.” Wow. It’s that simple?! If only…

Restaurant patrons fall into two categories: the determined and the deliberative. The determined make their dining decisions with startling ease, and, often, food is fuel for them, not an experience. The deliberative (you know who you are) pore over the menu, ponder, ask questions, ruminate, ask more questions, deliberate further, and then—finally—decide, often on what seems an arbitrary whim. If the decision doesn’t hit the spot, regret overshadows the meal. If the decision is spot on, the dining experience is beyond divine. The deliberative require patience. Their waiters, I might add, deserve a rather generous tip.

You can imagine, then, what it is like for a deliberative to make a car decision, particularly with such a myriad of possibilities of models, accessories, and color combinations. Apparently, being deliberative is a characteristic of Fiat customers.  “You are a special breed,” my saleswoman, Corky, cried on my fourth visit. “I’ve got six of you who have been trying to make a decision for over two months!”

I liked to believe that I was just doing things in the slow, contemplative Italian way, employing the careful consideration with which one might approach a languorous meal in the Tuscan countryside. A friend of mine shattered my dreamy Italianate fantasy by rather bluntly suggesting that my inability to decide on a vehicle and my excuses of being too busy with work and children to focus on my purchase paralleled my apparent excuses of why I couldn’t start dating. Perhaps I had a fear of commitment?

Fear of commitment seems a little harsh, but she was on to something. I have never engaged in a purchase of this magnitude on my own before. It seemed extravagant, so I was hesitant. Moreover, on top of my general deliberative nature, trepidation of an extra financial burden certainly weighed on my mind. However, the rise in gas prices in May and June and the subsequent $300 I spent on fuel for my Honda Odyssey each month, coupled with the fact that the Odyssey was tripping over 170,000 miles, spurred me into action. Extravagance became necessity.

Which Fiat 500?

The first step required deciding between the new Fiat 500L and the traditional 500. On an intellectual and practical level, the 500L had real appeal. Intellectually, the factors that drove the design—Cinquecento history and modernist aesthetic—spoke to my academic sensibility. Practically, the design fits my life—it has four doors and can easily seat five with plenty of room for bags, groceries, and even our Bernese mountain dog. It is fun to drive, although one does have to hope Fiat works on the comfort of the seats in future models. Clearly, the 500L was the sensible choice.

As functional and quirky as the 500L is, however, it simply did not speak to me the way the Cinquecento did. Twice I went to the dealership to test drive a 500L and a 500, trying to convince myself that I wanted the 500L. No matter how I wished it, the 500L did not evoke that sense of association with La Dolce Vita so dear to me that the Cinquecento did. If emotion is not supposed to drive car purchasing decisions, I have spectacularly failed the test.

Back to the Dealer

So there I was with three children in tow, once again, to see if they could all fit in a Cinquecento. We took a number of spins, changing seats along the way. My eldest, Sarah, is presently the tallest; she staked out her front seat privilege immediately. Her brother, Nico, however, will soon be little in birth order only, a fact he gleefully announced with a wicked glimmer in his eye. My youngest and smallest child, Stephanie, ever the sly diplomatic one, extolled the comfort and benefits of the back seat. Maybe Sarah and Nico should both consider its excellent features, like the headrests, and, since Stephanie is the smallest, she could sit up front with the seat pulled forward and there would be plenty of room for both of them in the back! With thoughts of the 500L in the back of my mind, I reasoned that the times all four of us will drive around town will be limited. Plus, their seat negotiations will provide me no end of amusement. The Cinquecento was the way to go.

Back at the dealership, Corky and I sat down to discuss the financial realities. She, too, is in the unenviable club of having been through a bitter divorce. As a female sales associate in an automobile dealership, she is a woman making it in a world still dominated by men. We are both women who work long hours to provide as best we can for our children, and in their own way, our respective associations with Fiat represent the new lives we are each building. I certainly felt that gender played into the reception I had at the dealerships of other brands in a negative way. I like to believe that I would have gotten a Fiat regardless, but the fact that my salesperson was a woman in a position not unlike my own certainly added to my comfort with the decision.

When I explained how my credit rating took a hit during some financial machinations during the separation, she understood the implications on a larger level and immediately called in the finance manager so we could review all the options. My decision to get a Fiat was more than an issue of reducing fuel costs; it was also becoming a means to restoring my financial foundations—an unexpected bonus.

Financial Decisions

Should I lease or should I buy? I had intended to lease, but I wanted to review the implications of both options. With a lease’s lower monthly payment, my debt-to-income ratio would be lower. Leasing it was.

What about pricing? Many employers and associations enable preferred pricing—automatic discounts with verification of employment. It is astounding how many people in Ann Arbor are not aware of preferred pricing programs, which save not only money but also hassle on negotiations. It’s always worth checking. What were my possibilities: university association? Chrysler’s Friends program? We went through the options and identified the best program for me.

What about dealer incentives? Suddenly, as if on cue, we heard the sound of an engine starting and an exclamation from a vehicle inside the showroom: “I didn’t know it would do that!" We looked over to see my twelve-year-old grinning sheepishly, holding a key. He had been amusing himself with the Abarth videos at the video terminal and had hopped into one in the showroom to see what they were like. The previous customer had been testing out the key functions; Nico wanted to see the dash lights in action. Mental note: when I actually come to purchase a specific car, leave the children at home.

Dealer incentives—these are the lucky lottery elements of Fiat purchasing.   They are fleeting, coming and going at a moment’s notice. Some are model specific, such as for the Pop; some are regional; some are seasonal. There are incentives for leasing and purchasing, and with them, the savings can be significant. With incentives in play, could they run numbers on the different models? I wanted to be sure of my options. Patience being a part of Fiat sales, Corky agreed and laughed as she said, “I’d hate to see you in a restaurant!” Little did she know…

Finding the One

Armed with my pricing information, I then needed to narrow down to the model and color. I run a benevolent dictatorship in my house, so the children’s opinions are welcome, but I am the ultimate arbiter. Sarah and Stephanie voted for the convertible, the 500c, but cost and the complete loss of trunk space ruled it out. Nico advocated strongly for the Abarth—such a dude car. The cost, however, was prohibitive, and vroom, vroom, vrooming all over town held little appeal for me. They all wanted Beats Audio. I did, too, but Corky gently pointed out that one does lose cargo space with the woofer. Beats Audio might have to wait for the next Fiat.

I test-drove all viable possibilities: Pop, Sport, Lounge, and Turbo. Compared with the others in drive and ride, the Pop just didn’t grab me, and it doesn’t have leather seats—which I considered a must. The Lounge seemed too extravagant, so I couldn’t consider it; the Sport had the right drive, yet the Turbo had the feel I liked. If we could find a Turbo that worked financially, that would be the car. If not, the Sport was the most practical option, so I thought.

And, color? Stephanie voted for yellow, but the canary-and-black contrast was too much for me. Nico wanted black with red leather (too many Abarth videos, clearly). And Sarah, my sixteen-year-old? “Mom,” she tossed out sardonically, “if you’re going to drive a sexy car, you can’t do a half-assed job of it. Red.”

Color became the hang-up, and this was the one place Fiat’s marketing didn’t work for me. In what could be considered an eco-friendly move, Fiat is not big on traditional brochures, so most of my looking was done online. The girls now away on summer adventures, Nico and I spent an evening on the sofa watching every Fiat video on the website to try to decide on color and model. We learned a great deal about the history of the Abarth, Abarth racing, and the fact that the scorpion logo was due to Carlo Abarth’s astrological sign (a fact my Scorpio child loved). For days after, we would giggle and spontaneously burst into the “Sexy People” Fiat song, quite a moment in the middle of Whole Foods, but our evening on the computer didn’t help narrow down the choice. The website simply doesn’t offer much in terms of color insight. One can pick the exterior color there, but the colors displayed are a far cry from the actual colors of the vehicles.
“What about that light blue?” Nope. On the website, Fiat’s Luce Blu appeared too close to Carolina Blue. As a Duke alum, there was no way I was going to drive a Carolina Blue car.

Interiors? One can’t sample their various configurations. Dashboard and seat color combinations change depending on make, model, and accessories, such as cloth or leather seats. At present, the way one can play with those configurations on the website is quite limited. To find “the one,” I was going to have to see it in person, and I would know it when I saw it.

A week later, Corky called. Fifteen new vehicles had just been delivered, including a number of Sport models, and it was now the end of July. Some of the incentives were ending on the thirty-first. I phoned Marley, my sitter. Could she meet me at the dealership with Nico? With August and all the impending camp driving it entails almost upon us, I had to take the plunge, and I wanted to test-drive different color options—Rosso Brillante, Bianco Perla, and Nero—one last time.

Nico had his hockey stick with him, as hockey boys do, and I realized that we had measured fitting the hockey bag in the trunk, but what about the stick? Moreover, with Marley standing next to him, it occurred to me that I hadn’t taken anyone on a test drive who was taller than five feet, five inches. Marley is five feet, nine inches, and long in the torso. So there we were, Marley, Nico, the hockey stick, and me, test-driving a black Sport with a sunroof. It all fit, but Marley looked a little cramped and had only a couple of inches to spare. The sunroof takes away 1.3 inches of headroom. Suddenly, I realized, I was looking at getting a vehicle that would require passengers to pass an amusement park test: You must be under six feet tall to get on this ride. As one of my dear friends is more than six feet tall, that didn’t seem particularly considerate.

I walked into the showroom to ask Corky if there were models without sunroofs, and then I saw it. There, in front of me, was the one! It was everything I had said I wouldn’t consider: a Luce Blu Lounge with cloth seats and a fixed glass moonroof. The creamy-white steering wheel and radio contrasted beautifully with the pale metallic blue and black of the dash in a mod throwback to the 1960s. The white-and-black checked seats and the subtle red stitching of the 500 logo added to the cool retro feel.

We hopped in. The moonroof provided a whole new dimension of spaciousness, adding height and opening the interior volume. I hadn’t considered the Lounge because it tends to come with all the trappings, which elevate its cost, generally to around the $23,000 range. Yet, this one, without leather seats and Beats Audio, had a sticker price of $19,700. It really was the one.

A deposit reserved it for me, and the next day, Corky and the finance manager agreed to stay late so we could close the deal. As luck would have it, Fiat had just announced a new incentive for leasing that had not been there the night before. This car was meant to be. All of the financial legwork I had done in the preceding months paid off. Signing the forms was the most painless part, but it was not without trepidation that I put pen to paper. I was committing.

A Moment of Reflection, Then Contentment

As I drove off the lot, I realized that I had done everything backward. I started shaking. Emotion drove the brand; emotion drove the choice. Price established the parameters, but brand and color dictated the car. Reason may have set the boundaries, but passion drove the decision. This was not the pragmatic way to purchase a car!

Then a calm descended. It took four months of deliberating, but the calm washing over me was that same lovely feeling one has after a long, languorous meal in a Tuscan village, where the setting sun gives way to the candlelit table of friends bathed in moonlight, relaxing contentedly with palates sated.  Serenity.  My decision was spot on, and it was simply divine.

title: Crash Tests for Dummies
promoTeaserSmall: What do you need to know about crash testing? Here's that simple explanation you were looking for.
promoTeaser: What do you need to know about crash testing? Here's that simple explanation you were looking for.
metaDescription: Crash Tests for Dummies: at last, a simple and clear explanation of how cars are crash tested and what it all means to you as a shopper. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) has just released its crash test ratings on twelve new small cars, including the Honda Civic, the Ford Focus, and the Volkswagen Beetle. Six of the cars tested earned the IIHS’s Top Safety Pick Plus rating, while some were rated Marginal or Poor in some of the tests. (See the ratings here.) What does all of that mean?

Obviously, when you’re shopping for a new car you want the safest possible vehicle. But with two ratings agencies running multiple crash tests to provide separate ratings, you'll need to spend a little time to go through all the results. Here’s a rundown of the different ratings and tests, so you can be fully informed next time you’re looking for a new car.

Why Are Two Agencies Running Crash Tests?

It may seem odd that there are two agencies doing crash tests, rather than just one. But they are different—one a government agency, one a nonprofit sponsored by insurance companies—and their tests differ somewhat. You should look at results from both to get a complete picture. Having said that, these two groups choose to test a sample of vehicles that they expect will sell in large volumes or that have been recently redesigned—and they buy the vehicles from dealerships themselves.
Every model on the market doesn’t get tested, but every vehicle sold in the United States does have to meet federal motor vehicle safety standards.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation. This is the group that provides the starred reviews you see on a new car’s window sticker. NHTSA rates cars from one to five stars in frontal crash, side crash, and rollover tests and also provides an overall safety score. You can find NHTSA’s ratings online at safercar.gov.

The IIHS is a nonprofit research group sponsored by the insurance industry. It assigns cars Good, Acceptable, Marginal, or Poor ratings for rear crash, side crash, rollover roof strength, and two types of front crash tests. The IIHS also awards cars that perform particularly well with Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick Plus ratings. You can find IIHS ratings online at iihs.org/ratings.

How does that Good, Acceptable, or Marginal rating on a 2013 model compare with the overall safety of, say, a 2007 or earlier model? That’s a good question, because IIHS has recently toughened up its front crash testing, and NHTSA stiffened its testing criteria for 2011 and newer models, leading to lower ratings in some cases. The bottom line is, vehicles are getting better, and to some extent, that’s because these crash test ratings incentivize manufacturers to improve their products and get higher scores. As NHTSA says, “The intention of the new ratings and tougher crash tests is to encourage manufacturers to build the safest vehicles possible.”

NHTSA’s Testing

NHTSA performs one front crash test and two side crash tests on all cars it chooses to rate.

Front Crash: NHTSA’s front crash test is a full-frontal crash that slams cars into a solid barrier. It's a simulation of a head-on crash in which both vehicles are traveling at the same rate of speed, 35 mph. Driver and front passenger dummies help measure the forces that create chest deflection, neck extension, and femur and foot injuries. A recent tweak to the test replaced a male passenger dummy with a smaller, female dummy.

Side Crash: The side crash test simulates being hit from the side by a 3,015-pound car traveling at 38.5 mph. As the agency says, it's a simulation of an intersection-type crash. NHTSA collects data on chest, head, abdomen, and pelvis injuries sustained by the driver and head and pelvis injuries sustained by the left rear passenger. The driver dummy represents an average-size male, while the rear passenger dummy represents a female.

The side crash test also includes a sideways-into-pole test, which slams the vehicle into a pole 25 centimeters (about ten inches) in diameter at 20 mph at a 75-degree angle. This is a simulation of a crash into a fixed object, such as a utility pole or a tree. The pole hits at the driver’s seating location, and the test measures the head and pelvis injuries to the driver and the front passenger. NHTSA combines the ratings of the two side crash tests for its overall side crash score.

Rollover: NHTSA also performs rollover testing on most SUVs, pickups, and minivans. It runs the vehicles through a fishhook maneuver, starting at 35 mph with speed increasing until the car either fails (two wheels lift off the ground) or passes without incident at 50 mph.
You can search NHTSA's safercar.gov database by vehicle make and model, manufacturer, and vehicle class to narrow down the car that’s right for you or look up the ratings for a car you already own.

IIHS’s Testing

IIHS conducts two front crash tests, a side crash test, a rollover test, and a rear crash test. Their tests differ significantly from NHTSA’s, so it’s worth looking at both when you’re shopping for a car.

Front Crash: IIHS performs both moderate overlap and small overlap front crash tests. While NHTSA’s tests crash a car’s entire front end into an immobile barrier, IIHS simulates crashing just part of a vehicle’s front end into a car of a similar weight. In moderate overlap tests, 40 percent of a car’s front end hits a deformable barrier at 40 mph. The small overlap test engages just 25 percent of a car’s crumple zone, with test cars hitting a rigid barrier with the front left corner of the car.
Both front crash tests record forces to test the dummy’s head, neck, chest, legs, and feet. These tests sometimes cause cars to spin, which might engage side curtain airbags as well as front airbags.

Side Crash: The IIHS side crash test is similar to NHTSA’s, but it uses a heavier barrier (3,300 pounds instead of 3,015 pounds) and a higher point of impact, which aims to simulate being hit by a truck or an SUV. The test uses a female dummy in the driver’s seat and a twelve-year-old child dummy in the rear passenger seat. The rest of the IIHS tests use adult male dummies.

Rear Crash: For rear crash tests, the IIHS first evaluates a car’s head restraints. If they are improperly designed or positioned, the car automatically fails the test. Cars with head restraints that could effectively protect a driver’s head and neck in the event of a collision are hit from the rear by a similarly sized car traveling at 20 mph.

Rollover: IIHS uses roof strength as a measure of rollover safety in cars. The test involves pressing a metal plate against one side of a car’s roof until the roof gives way. Cars that earn a Good rating must withstand four times their own weight before the roof reaches five inches of crush.

In addition to ratings for individual tests, IIHS awards the best performers with a Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick Plus designation. Top Safety Picks must earn a Good rating in the moderate overlap front, side, rollover, and rear crash tests. Small overlap results are not taken into account for the Top Safety Pick award. To earn Top Safety Pick Plus, cars must earn a Good rating in four of the IIHS’s five tests and at least an Acceptable rating in the fifth. Small overlap results are considered for the Top Safety Pick Plus designation.

The Fine Print

NHTSA and IIHS are both careful to specify that shoppers shouldn’t compare crash ratings across vehicle types (don’t compare a Honda Fit to a Chevrolet Tahoe, for instance) or compare vehicles subjected to different crash tests. NHTSA and IIHS have both updated their tests in recent years to make them more stringent, so make sure to compare crash test ratings only among cars that were subjected to the same tests.

Heard enough about crash tests for one day? Let's close this out with a fascinating short video from IIHS, all about the dummies that are used in testing.

title: A Music App That Keeps You Focused
promoTitle: A Music App That Keeps You Focused
promoTeaserSmall: The focus@will streaming music app is one thing it's OK to do with your smartphone while driving.
promoTeaser: The focus@will streaming music app is one thing it's OK to do with your smartphone while driving.
metaTitle: A Music App That Keeps You Focused - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Music App That Keeps You Focused: New focus@will app, based on deep scientific research, plays up to 100 minutes of music to keep you deeply engrossed in your work and driving. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Calling Brain Area 39! Calling Brain Area 39! I have just discovered a free streaming music app for Android, iPhone, and computer called focus@will that is designed to extend your ability to concentrate, so you can get things done. It does that by appealing to Brain Area 39, which, they say, is the part that handles verbal creativity, reading, calculating, situational context, focused auditory attention, and a lot of other things you need to get you through the day.

Based on a deep dive into the latest neuroscience research—explained in exhausting detail on the website—the app plays a carefully curated stream of sound that you are not supposed to pay any attention to. Download the free app, or surf over to the website and click Play, and you’ll be rewarded with up to 100 minutes of the kind of concentration that lets you get stuff done.

Like Elevator Music with a Graduate Degree

You can choose among Classical, Focus Spa, Up Tempo, Alpha Chill, Acoustical, Cinematic, and Ambient, and a low, medium, or high intensity level. The philosophy is "DJ in the Sky," the company says. This is less elevator-musicky than it sounds. The two founders are a “pop soul” trumpeter with two #1 Billboard hits and a music producer/engineer, and they have employed a music supervisor and a music analyst with serious-sounding music industry credentials.

Now, as the mother of four musical teenagers, I think I know a thing or two about streaming music. My kids are experts in using Spotify, Pandora, and any other streaming app.  I asked my jazz guitarist son to try it. “I would never use this,” was his feedback. “If this is what I wanted to hear, I’d just play Enya.” (It’s worth noting that focus@will deliberately does not have a Jazz setting, believing that jazz is not something you can or should listen to unless you are paying attention to the music.) My violinist daughter, ever the Type A personality, found it impossible to listen to music in the background while reading. “Oh my gosh, Mom, I can't do it,” she texted me. “I tried all the different channels on all different settings, and I just ended up reading the same paragraph ten times. I can't listen to music and read at the same time; I just completely focus on the music.”
So much for the multitasking teenagers we keep hearing about.

I Think It Really Works for Me!

But for those of us who are not musicians and can let music fade into the background while we work on other things, does this “attention-enhancing music stream” really work? I tried it at my desk; I tried it while out driving. I think it actually did help me think in a more calm and linear way. Even if the greater focus was due strictly to the power of suggestion—knowing I had my “concentration” background music on, which made me want to concentrate—that’s still a net concentration gain in my book.

The focus@will people say it can increase concentration by 300 to 400 percent for most users. It's optimized to use while you are on a laptop or desktop computer, trying to meet a deadline or get through your e-mail folder. I can only imagine the amount of homework it will encourage students to get done. (Well, apparently students other than my own kids, that is.)

Trying It in the Car...

So, I asked myself, wouldn’t this be a great distraction reducer in the car? It would also give your phone a task, and that just might help you keep your addicted mitts off the cell phone while you are driving. I tried it and found that it did help me remain calm and focused while driving.

In particular, the Classical setting was brilliant while out in traffic. Anyone who likes classical music in the car knows how hard it is to listen to while you drive, for sound-level reasons. Put in the nine symphonies of Beethoven on CD, for example, and you’ll spend three-quarters of your listening time adjusting the volume way up, then way down, then way up again to accommodate the dynamic range. The focus@will app remains within a listenable area, which is not as dull as it sounds. It was all “real” classical music, not the 101 Strings and Mantovani. Yet it was not the well-known warhorses that would draw your attention by their familiarity, either. On the downside, over a long freeway haul, I think I might find the app a little too calming and predictable, and I might want to play something a little rowdier.

...and They're Working on the Right Mix for Driving Right Now

I checked on that with the founder and CEO, Will Henshall. He told me that the startup has not yet adapted the app for driving, even though some users have reported they already like it as a driving companion. Henshall stated what we all know, that “the part of your brain used for driving is quite different than the part of your brain used for most work and study, and as a result the mechanism for anti distraction using an audio stimulus when driving will be different, too.” Luckily, they’re working on it: "We are actively looking into the recipe for reducing distractions when driving," he said.

How long until we see focus@will’s 
“DJ in the Sky” methodology as an option on higher-end cars’ audio systems? I am predicting it will be sooner than you think.

title: 2012 Toyota Prius Four
promoTeaserSmall: I got no thrills, except when I checked out my fuel economy! But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I got no thrills, except when I checked out my fuel economy! But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2012 Toyota Prius Four: I'll tell you what I thought about this iconic hybrid, and recommend whether you should buy it. The Peanut Gallery will weigh in, too. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $33,118 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.8-liter Atkinson cycle four-cylinder with electric motor, 134 net system horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel Economy: 51 mpg city/48 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Multi-information display
Option I can't live without: Deluxe Solar Roof package, including solar roof panels with power moonroof ($3,820)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Ford C-Max, Honda Insight
See more specs on the Prius in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The Toyota Prius wasn't the first hybrid to hit the U.S. market—that honor belongs to the Honda Insight—but it is the best-selling hybrid vehicle on these shores and one of the most instantly recognizable. That geometric glass rear greenhouse has become part of the design language for alternative-fuel cars across the market.

I've always been a little dubious of the Prius's "Look at me, I'm green" styling, but here in Ann Arbor, it looks like I'm the only one. There's a Prius on every street corner in this old hippie town and often more than one. Driving a hybrid down the streets of Ann Arbor was like being part of a slightly self-righteous club. It may not be that way everywhere, but it's easy to imagine how Prii could spread like wildfire in certain parts of the country.

The Prius comes by its earth-friendly image honestly. There are four Prius models for the 2013 model year, and none of them is rated below 40 mpg on the highway. The Prius Four we tested is the "normal" Prius. It falls in the middle of the family’s price range and is rated at 51 mpg in the city and 48 mpg on the highway. I was very impressed when the Prius returned an indicated 53.1 mpg on a two-and-a-half-hour highway drive without my making any particular effort to get good gas mileage. Better yet, with a starting price of $24,200 (although the one shown here started at a still reasonable $28,235), it won't take years of gas savings to make up the difference in price between a Prius and a similar traditional gasoline car.

Of course, gas mileage that good comes at a cost, and in the case of the Prius, that cost is driving enjoyment. You won't get a thrill from pressing the accelerator, and I don't recommend throwing the Prius around tight corners. But for drivers who are just trying to get from Point A to Point B, the Prius's 1.8-liter 98-horsepower engine (which gets help from the small electric motor to make 134 horsepower under heavy acceleration) will be perfectly adequate. It's also a little addictive to try to drive as efficiently as possible. The Prius has a B position on the shifter that increases regenerative braking, best for use in city driving: it increases the energy recaptured by the battery when the car is slowing down.

If you desperately want a Prius but the Prius Four isn't quite the variety you're looking for, you may just find the hybrid of your dreams in the Prius c, the Prius v, or the Prius Plug-in. The Prius c is smaller and cheaper than the Prius Four, so it might be a little better suited to drivers living in a cramped city. The Prius v is for customers who think the Prius could stand to be just a little bigger, and while it doesn't get quite the gas mileage of its smaller siblings, it still does better than just about any non-hybrid vehicle at 44 mpg city and 40 mpg highway. The Prius Plug-in allows drivers to experience up to eleven miles of electric range, thanks to a slightly larger battery that can be fully charged in an hour and a half at a 240-volt outlet. That model earns 95 MPGe.

The Verdict:

There's a reason Toyota has sold millions of Prii worldwide since the automaker brought the car to the U.S. market. The Prius does exactly what it says it will do: deliver excellent fuel economy in a practical package. The interior is comfortable and relatively attractive, the exterior is distinctive and often worn as a badge of honor, and the hybrid powertrain will let you blow past gas stations like they've gone out of style.

If you're looking for a car with great driving dynamics, this isn't it. The Prius has plenty of worthy competition in the hybrid market (check out the Ford C-Max), but it's still the best-selling hybrid nameplate in the country, and there are enough flavors of Prius that you're almost certain to find one that suits you.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: I have said it before and I'll say it again: the back end of the Prius looks like the back end of a Pontiac Aztek. The first concept Prius made its debut in 1995, and the Aztek concept followed four years later. Coincidence? I think not. The Aztek has repeatedly been crowned as one of the ugliest cars of all time, and I think they should make room on the podium next to it for the Prius. That being said, it is a perfectly adequate car that makes a lot of environmental sense.

Scott: I'm afraid to say that I like the Prius because of all the negative comments I have heard about the car, but I do like it. I was pleased with how big the interior is, and the controls were easy to navigate. I felt like it was very open inside, yet it also felt very safe. When I drove the Prius around town, I found that the steering was easy and smooth, and the car didn't feel underpowered at all, which was not what I expected. If I had to discredit the car, I'd say that, for how big the rear window is, it's still hard to see out the back. For the nearly $30,000 this costs, I'd buy a Honda Accord instead and keep the change.

Laura: The Toyota Prius is as much a symbol as it is a car: the Converse All-Star sneaker, the Campbell's soup can, the I Love Lucy of hybrids. Well, those things didn't get their status by being unpredictable, and neither did the Toyota Prius. An expanded list of sizes and price points, plus Toyota quality and predictability, put the Prius into a very special position among hybrids. Who wants to argue with that? You say Prius drivers are self-satisfied? They are getting better fuel economy than most people. People drive too slow in the Prius? They're just trying to get even better fuel economy than they already are. The car is boring? Toyota doesn't make these things for the same people who buy the Porsche Boxster. I appreciate the Prius for what it is: an icon. Yes, I used the I word. If I were shopping for a hybrid, it would be ridiculous not to give it serious consideration.

title: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
promoTitle: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
promoTeaserSmall: Its EPA numbers had been calculated based on Fusion Hybrid. Revised C-Max mpg: 45/43/40.
promoTeaser: Its EPA numbers had been calculated based on Fusion Hybrid. Revised C-Max mpg: 45/43/40.
metaTitle: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
metaDescription: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG: Ford has announced it has cut the fuel economy numbers on the popular crossover. Find out why at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In the pageant that is fuel economy, the hybrids are the glamorous contestants, offering the complete package: the peace of mind of a gasoline engine along with the cost- and fuel-saving qualities of a battery. When it came onto the stage last year, what could have been more promising an entrant than the Ford C-Max Hybrid? It boasted neat, tidy, and damned impressive EPA fuel economy numbers of 47 mpg in town, 47 mpg on the highway, and 47 mpg combined. On every form of media from radio to YouTube, there has been a barrage of advertising about how that 47/47/47 was better than the C-Max’s archrival, the Toyota Prius V, which “only” claims 44/40/42 mpg.

Apparently 47/47/47 was a little too neat and tidy. This afternoon, Ford downgraded its numbers for the C-Max Hybrid. Henceforth, the C-Max Hybrid gets a combined 43 mpg, according to the automaker. Its full set of fuel economy numbers: 45 mpg in town, 40 mpg on the highway, and 43 combined.

Here’s How It Happened

In a press conference today, Ford’s spokesman said it all started when the company tested the Fusion Hybrid, a sedan, and used its fuel economy numbers on the label for the C-Max Hybrid, which has a crossover body style. That was not an error or a deception on Ford’s part. As Ford explained, the EPA rules work on a “general label” principle, requiring auto companies to test only one vehicle in each family so that every single variant of every car doesn’t have to be tested. The automaker is supposed to define a family by common engine, transmission, and weight class, and then test the highest-volume vehicle.
There are no plans to change the Fusion Hybrid’s 47/47/47 mpg label.

The C-Max Energi plug-in hybrid and the Fusion Energi count as a family, too, but of that pair, Ford tested the C-Max Energi, not the Fusion, because the C-Max is a bigger seller. Ford’s spokesman said. For that reason, the Fusion Energi could very well be getting better fuel economy than its label states, he noted.

Cash Going Out to 2013 C-Max Hybrid Owners

Ford will make one-time payments to 2013 C-Max Hybrid buyers: $550 for buyers and $325 for those who have leased the vehicle. Letters are going out to everyone who got a C-Max Hybrid with a 47/47/47 mpg sticker.

And Changes Coming for the 2014 Model

Ford said it will make changes to the 2014 model, out later this year, including transmission changes and modifications to make the C-Max Hybrid’s body more aerodynamic.

Just a month ago, Ford issued a “software upgrade” to help its C-Max, Fusion, and Lincoln MKZ hybrid models get better fuel economy. Among those were an increase in top speed in electric-only mode, to 85 mph from the previous 62 mph, and some climate control changes such as shortening engine warmup time and reducing the electric fan’s speed to cut energy consumption.

This Has Been Known for a While...

You could have figured that out sooner, though, by simply visiting the My Fuel Economy section of the EPA’s fueleconomy.gov website. Here, 100 C-Max Hybrid owners have reported their actual fuel economy in the real world: an average of 39.1 mpg. Now, let’s consider what kind of person would keep that kind of close track and go report it to an EPA database. I would stereotype him or her as a detail-oriented person with a deep personal interest in fuel economy, or what you might call a careful driver. And they came up with an 8-mpg differential.
Consumer Reports, too, tested the 2013 C-Max Hybrid and reported 37 mpg overall, which it called “excellent but well short of the EPA's 47 mpg.”

Hyundai/Kia Have Been Here Before

Ford is not the first automaker to have this problem. Hyundai and Kia lowered fuel economy numbers late last year on 900,000 vehicles sold between 2010 and October 31, 2012. The wrong numbers were blamed on faulty calibration of ratings back home in South Korea, and the adjustment reduced the whole lineup’s average fuel economy by three percent, from 27 mpg to 26 mpg. The biggest impact was cutting the 40-mpg highway mileage claims on the Hyundai Accent, Elantra, and Sonata HEV and Kia Veloster. They’re all now in the high 30s.

The company went a step further and offered to pay owners back for the extra gas they had to buy, plus a fifteen percent penalty—a move that could cost Hyundai/Kia a total of $100 million by the time it’s all over.

More about How EPA Testing Works

The EPA is also reportedly looking at changes to the way it figures fuel economy. The way it stands now, the automakers themselves test for fuel economy, and the EPA confirms that by actually testing about fifteen percent of the cars on the market itself, under lab conditions, but also reviews test data from the automakers to spot potential problems. The EPA said Ford followed the rules and is not at fault for this C-Max issue.

A check of the EPA testing parameters shows that “city driving” is tested at an average 21.2 mph, while “highway driving” is tested at an average of 48.3 mph. The EPA also states that “your mileage may vary” is not just a saying. What kinds of roads you drive on, how you accelerate and brake, how fast you go, what the weather and terrain are like, and what you might be carrying or towing can all have a big effect on your fuel economy.

Should You Care?

Well, or how much should you care? Yes, you might buy the C-Max Hybrid because of the great fuel economy, and be disappointed that it hasn't quite gotten where the claims led you to believe, but it’s still probably so much better than whatever you probably drove before. The bottom line may be that you should choose your next car based on a whole lot of factors, not just on one selling point, no matter how compelling it looks at the time.

metaDescription: Smart Electric City Tour: I spent an afternoon piloting one of those tiny little La-Z-Boys on wheels! Who knew I'd love it? Read about the adventure on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Smart invited a bevy of local journalists to spend time in the brand-new 2013 Electric Drive, the EV version of the Smart ForTwo. It was billed as a City Tour, which I thought meant we would be limited to driving it only in an urban setting. But actually, City Tour referred to the campaign of introducing the Electric Drive to the media in select cities throughout the country. I had never driven a Smart before, and I was prepared to feel like a giant in a Lilliputian vehicle or like I was driving a covered La-Z-Boy.

The Electric Drive is currently only available in states that have a zero-emission-vehicle mandate (California, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, and Rhode Island), but this winter, this itsy-bitsy buggy will be more widely available.

About the Smart Electric Drive

Let's talk price, since it's the first thing that came to my mind when looking at the Smart. The Electric Drive coupe is priced at $25,750, and the cabriolet costs $28,750, including destination. Subtract from that a federal tax credit of up to $7,500. Alternatively, in a program heavily promoted by the Smart people, you can purchase the coupe for $20,740 or the cabriolet for $23,740 and rent the lithium-ion battery for $80 per month. This is called the Battery Assurance Plus program. It guarantees you a battery with a capacity of at least 80 percent and includes an annual battery checkup.

Smart is also offering thirty-six-month Electric Drive lease packages that will make the penny pinchers among us pay attention. The coupe is $139 per month and the cabriolet $199; they both include Battery Assurance Plus.

The Electric Drive can be charged from any household socket but may require as much as fourteen hours to go from a zero charge to a full charge. A 240-volt Bosch Keba charging station will do the charging job in six hours. It's sold separately, by Bosch Service Solutions, and costs $1,322 plus installation, but your local utility company may offer incentives that will pay for some or all of that cost.

Thoughts along the Road

It had been raining lightly all morning, but as if on cue, the sky cleared when we finished our lunch. I snagged one of only two cabriolets Smart had along for the drive. Winning!

Our route for the day was well within the sixty-eight-mile range that is touted for this Smart, so I did not suffer any range anxiety. As I drove the bucolic twenty-mile loop around Ann Arbor, thinking about what kind of person would actually buy such a tiny city car and who the target buyers must be, my mind wandered to my personal vehicle plight. I wondered, perhaps I am the target buyer for an Electric Drive? I am, as they say, at a crossroads in my personal transportation life. The very tired vehicle that I drive needs to go toward the bright light.

For three years, I walked to work every morning and home every night. It was one mile each way, and I often would take longer routes to run errands. I loved it. I really felt like I was living an urban life, even though Ann Arbor only has about 114,000 residents. When I needed to go anywhere else in the city, I happily hopped on one of the buses. I even got a Zipcar membership for situations when I needed to get somewhere at a specific time. It altered my shoe selection, since I had to make sure that my shoes were comfortable for long walks. I also needed to be able to carry everything for the day, so I switched from a purse to a backpack. I never left home without first checking the weather forecast. Four seasons on foot tend to make one very sensible.

When I started working at Jean Knows Cars, I needed to rethink my mode of transportation. The commute to the world headquarters was six miles. Translated to walking, that would be two hours each way! I started by catching a ride with our executive editor, Laura Sky Brown, but I felt like I was in high school. Should I give her gas money? The bus was inconvenient, and my laptop was way too heavy for the mile to and from the bus stop. So, with much regret, I started driving my family's extra car, which is not so lovingly referred to as the POS. You will need to decipher that on your own.

The POS is a mess, but so far, it has not left me stranded. But as you can imagine, every time I get the opportunity to drive a spanking new vehicle, I take a moment and wonder if this could be the car that finally puts the POS to pasture.

With all of this baggage in mind, I pondered the possibility of actually owning a microcar. To make the mind boggle even further, this microcar is electric with a range of sixty-eight miles. I have never considered driving an electric vehicle because they have always seemed too expensive, and what about the battery life? As I ticked off miles, I realized that if I owned this cabriolet and I only drove it to and from work, I could drive it all week without having to charge the battery. With thoughts of donating the POS to charity dancing in my head, I realized that perhaps the Smart could actually be a smart choice for me.

Stay Tuned

When I reluctantly turned in the Electric Drive at the end of the day, I requested a longer-term review. The Jean Knows Cars staff will be trying out a Smart Electric Drive soon, and I will be writing a more detailed Should You Buy It? review to share my thoughts on actually living with this diminutive EV.
