title: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses?
promoTeaserSmall: I don't get it: why don't teens want their freedom? A survey breaks down reasons for the reluctance.
promoTeaser: I don't get it: why don't teens want their freedom? A survey breaks down reasons for the reluctance.
metaTitle: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses? A survey from the driver's-license-enabling website driving-tests.org tries to figure that out. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: When I was in high school, I was so desperate to get my driver’s license that I took the driving test a month early and begged my parents to pull me out of second period world history so I could be at the Secretary of State the moment it opened. I saw that license as my ticket to freedom, and I wasn’t going to wait for it a second longer than I had to. So, despite my status as a millennial, I’m as confused as anyone when I hear that today’s teenagers aren’t tripping over themselves to get a taste of the sweet, sweet freedom that is unsupervised driving.

A study from the University of Michigan says that just 28 percent of sixteen-year-olds had driver’s licenses in 2010, down from more than 40 percent in 1983. So why aren’t kids driving? A new study from Driving-Tests.org surveyed more than 1,400 young people and asked them about their attitudes toward and concerns about driving, seeking to find answers in the mysterious case of the missing teenage drivers.

They didn’t come up with a conclusive answer to the “where are the young drivers?” question. What they did find is that young drivers are concerned about safety and are worried they won’t pass their driving tests. Perhaps most encouraging is that 75 percent of the teens surveyed listed texting or talking on the phone as the most dangerous thing a driver can do behind the wheel, so those “don’t text and drive” PSAs seem to be doing their job. Less encouraging is that just ten percent of the teens that responded to the survey thought drinking and driving was a “critical risk.”

Although none of the teens surveyed said cost was influencing their decision to get a driver’s license, fourteen percent of respondents said they were afraid of driving, and twelve percent felt “emotional pressure” about driving. Twenty-nine percent of teens said they were concerned about learning basic driving skills like parallel parking and driving next to large trucks.

Local eighteen-year-old Tegwyn John gave two reasons for her choice not to take the final test and get her driver's license. Even though she went through the driver education course, she says, "I don't want to pay the higher insurance rates associated with very young drivers, and I have easy access to public transportation."
Whether reluctant teenagers have rational reasons like Tegwyn's or are afraid, the study offered some tips for parents hoping to help their teens turn into safe, responsible drivers.

<ul>
•	Make sure you’re setting a good example for your kids when you’re driving them around. Of the teens surveyed, 53 percent said they’d seen their parents texting or talking on the phone behind the wheel. If you don’t want them to text and drive, you shouldn’t, either.

•	Talk to your kids about what it means to be a safe driver. Don’t just focus on texting, either. Make sure your teens know how dangerous drinking and driving is, too. For a little added incentive, consider drawing up a driving contract so your teen can see your expectations in writing and agree to them with a signature.

• If your kid is a nervous driver, spend extra time on the tricky parts of driving, like driving on the freeway or making lane changes on busy roads. If he or she still isn’t confident, look into a defensive driving course to help your teen build confidence.

title: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats
promoTeaserSmall: Warm steering wheel and seats? Ventilated seating? Don't rule any of that out till you've tried it.
promoTeaser: Warm steering wheel and seats? Ventilated seating? Don't rule any of that out till you've tried it.
metaTitle: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats: Once you've experienced heated and cooled seats, you won't want to live without them. Read an appreciation on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: On the long list of things we once had never heard of and now can’t live without: heated and cooled seating in our cars. Return with me to the days of vinyl bench seats, on which Mom would spread white towels so it would be slightly less burning hot to sit down in the summer. Not anymore. Now our cosseted heinies get perforated leather seating areas with built-in heating and cooling. Roasting your nether regions is now much more under your own control these days.

No longer a feature only of top-end luxury cars, the heaters and, to a lesser extent, coolers can be found in vehicles from the Subaru Forester to the Ford Escape Titanium to the Dodge Durango—even the tiny Chevrolet Sonic and Nissan Versa Note (right). Sometimes even the second-row passengers get heaters.
If you are shopping for a new car, you really want to put these items on your shopping list.

But Are They Safe?

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has fielded a few hundred complaints about overzealous bun warmers and has passed the concern along to SAE International (the organization formerly known as the Society of Automotive Engineers). SAE’s Heated Seats Standards Committee is working on recommending an “acceptable operating condition” for heated seats in cars.

The committee is studying top temperatures and lengths of heating time, what kinds of warnings or indicators cars might be required to have, and a possible disabling function for use by people who are sensitive to heat, including people such as paraplegics who are unable to feel how hot their seat is getting. The committee has not yet issued an official statement.

For most people, of course, common sense can dictate when to turn the heat on and off. And once you’ve felt the comfy sensation of sitting on a warm car seat in the winter, it’s a hard luxury to do without.

Have You Tried a Heated Steering Wheel Yet?

The same will soon be true of another, more recent addition to the comfort-options list: heated steering wheels. Ford first put a heated steering wheel into the 2011 Lincoln MKX, noting at the time a good scientific reason for that: “The body’s initial response to cold is to preserve heat by reducing the blood flow to the hands and feet,” causing “reduced dexterity in the fingers and hands.” Not to mention the need to wear bulky gloves while driving. This feature is trickling down from luxury cars to such 2013 models as the Dodge Dart and the Kia Optima (right), and if you haven’t tried it, you have no idea how wonderful it is.

Is Active Ventilation Something You Yearn For?

Okay, heated steering wheels and seats make sense to just about anybody who has gotten into a cold car on a chilly morning. What about cooling seats?

This feature is still most likely to be found on luxury models, and even then is usually an option—for example, it’s part of the Premium 1 package on the 2014 Mercedes-Benz S-Class, where it’s known as “active ventilated front seats.” BMW also offers ventilated seats (right), calling them a means of “removing moisture and helping prevent discomfort or driving fatigue.” The cooling works through fans integrated into the seat padding; these fans draw in fresh cabin air and then channel it through the seat. BMW’s setup has three speeds. Having tried these, I feel that the chilly hindquarters is a bit of an acquired taste, but I’m willing to bet it’s only a matter of time before this, too, feels like a luxury you can’t live without.

promoTeaser: Shop for (and buy) BMW-themed items, from keychains to spoilers, without leaving Facebook. Like?
metaDescription: BMW's New Facebook Store: Everything from keychains to spoilers, available without leaving Facebook. Read about the new BMW Lifestyle & Accessories store on Facebook at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The BMW USA Social Shop sounds like a place where you get an egg cream or a hot fudge sundae, but it’s even richer than that. Starting today, BMW’s Facebook page lets you shop right on the social media site for everything from BMW polo shirts to M performance parts. The BMW fan base is going to love the ability to shop for accessories and “lifestyle” items via a Facebook page.

Why is this any better than going to the regular Shop BMW USA website? Because you can share, Like, and create and view wish lists from your Facebook friends, that’s why. This is what’s known as creating a “social memory” about your love of the German sport/luxury brand. Think of the possibilities: Be reminded of friends’ birthdays, and go straight to their wish lists to order something without leaving Facebook. Comment and give feedback about products you’ve purchased through comment functionality for each individual product. Use PayPal, Google Checkout, or a credit card to close the sale on the site.

Concerned about privacy? You can opt out of sharing personal data, and you don't have to give the app permission to access friend lists, but that would probably spoil the fun of using this page in the first place.
Concerned about the world of marketing making these inroads into social media? Brace yourselves. This might be the first Facebook store you’ve read about, but it ain’t going to be the last.

title: Google Glass Meets Mercedes
promoTeaserSmall: R&D could lead to a car so connected to you that it's like wearing your nav system on your head.
promoTeaser: R&D could lead to a car so connected to you that it's like wearing your nav system on your head.
metaDescription: Mercedes-Benz is doing research on using Google Glass technology in future cars. The result of that R&D could be a car so connected to you that you’re literally wearing your nav system on your head. Read more at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Among the most intriguing news of the week is that Google Glass, the computer you wear on your head, is being tested at the Mercedes-Benz Research & Development North America headquarters in Palo Alto, California, for use with future Mercedes vehicles. This could lead to a world where you only search for directions once, on one device, and Google Glass will get you from door to door.

Google Glass, of course, is a set of Star Trek-style spectacle frames with a little computer/camera inside. You say “OK, Glass,” to it, and follow that with a voice command, and information is shown in a semi-transparent display in front of your face. For route guidance, you say, “Show route overview,” “Hide route overview,” or “Stop directions,” for example.

So why do you even need it to interface with the car? Two reasons. One is that, in many places, you aren’t allowed to use mobile devices—even Google Glass—while driving, and places as disparate as West Virginia and the United Kingdom are already making noises about banning Google Glass specifically. The other is that Mercedes has a killer navigation system that it wants you to use. So, in the setup being researched at present, you can plug in your phone when you get into the car, and it will transfer your directions from Google Glass to the in-car navigation system and back out to Google Glass for use when you exit the car. Mercedes says this is all still in the research and development stage and will probably be more like the integration of Google Glass technology directly into the Mercedes-Benz by the time it hits production.

Will everybody be using Google Glass in the car soon? Obviously, not everybody, at least not right away. For one thing, a Mercedes-Benz can be expensive, depending on which model you buy. Likewise, Google Glass is expensive and, at present, only available to a very limited group of beta testers in an Explorer Edition ($1,500). There’s rampant speculation on geek websites that it will retail for more like $300 when it becomes available to the general public next year.

Between now and then, Tesla Model S owners already have the ability to download an app that integrates Google Glass with the car, letting them perform feats such as starting or stopping the charging process, viewing interior and exterior temperatures, controlling the sunroof, and locking and unlocking the car remotely with the Google headset. It also will locate your Model S on a map, give you directions to it, and honk the car’s horns or flash its lights if you still can’t find it. These people will be popular in parking lots after concerts.

Coming from the same company that is working on a project to provide Internet access to developing countries using hot-air balloons, this is an intriguing glimpse into a future where we will be completely Web connected to the world at all times. Here’s hoping Google is also working on an ad blocker, but I’m not optimistic.

title: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips
promoTeaserSmall: Here's my philosophy to make the best of time spent driving kids to the zoo, the museum, wherever.
promoTeaser: Here's my philosophy to make the best of time spent driving kids to the zoo, the museum, wherever.
metaTitle: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: driving school children on field trips
metaDescription: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips: If you are the driver on your own, or the school's, field trips and excursions, here's my philosophy on making it a success after years of being a field trip driver. Read my rules on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In my dreams, they are still coming down the sidewalk from school, their pigtails bobbing, their sneakers bouncing off the pavement as they half skip and half run to the curb. I, of course, am standing in a beam of sunlight, keys in hand, minivan door open, healthy snacks neatly packed in a cooler. It's my field trip group of third graders, about to line up next to my van for a trip to…. Where haven't I been with a carload of kids?

Sure, as those days retreat into my rear-view mirror, I recall them as more perfect than they were, but one thing I know is, those field trips were some of the best days of my children’s childhoods, both for me and for them. They’re all teenagers now, and their friends drive up to the house in their Toyota Matrixes or Honda Civics to take them wherever they feel like going. At school, the bus takes them on their out-of-school trips these days, and it has been a long time since I’ve been asked to drive on a field trip. But while it lasted, it is one of the great accomplishments I look back on, that I made room in my life to be a field trip driver.

Some of the regular trips I recall were to the natural history museum (a.k.a. the “Dinosaur Museum"), the assisted living facility where the students each had a "senior friend” to visit, the water treatment plant, the library for research projects and storytimes, the zoo, the nature center, and the Ann Arbor Art Association for snowflake projects. Some of the field trips involved a ten-minute drive and some a weekend. Some just involved me and my own kids, plus a friend or two. Some were formal trips where I was assigned to a group of classmates and given a route to follow.

From those many drives, I’ve created a list of Five Simple Rules for anybody else who dares to fill up his or her car, SUV, or minivan, and head off to youthful adventure with all the noise and craziness that entails. For those of you who have to take time off work to drive on a field trip, I have two words for you: Do it.

1. Adjust your expectations.

If you are taking a school group, the teacher will probably assign you to drive a set group of kids. If your own kid is a boy, you’ll get him and three or four other boys, depending on your capacity. Same thing if your own kid is a girl: you’ll get a girl group. No matter which gender you’re driving, one of the kids will be rude and bossy, one will be the jokester, and one will be needy the whole time. Maybe some particularly gifted kid will combine two or more of those traits. (Maybe it will be your kid!) I so looked forward to the day I’d get a carload of girls with my daughter, after a few years of driving cars full of boys in her older brother’s class. (Example of boy behavior: I had to pull the car to the side of the road twice with fifth graders who wouldn’t stop screaming out the lyrics to “Air Force Ones” at ear-splitting volume. And don’t get me started on the body noises and dirty jokes.) Surprise! The groups of girls were actually more challenging on a drive, because they all have squeals and know how to use them, repeatedly.

Before you even start the car, have a short and simple list of rules, and make your passengers acknowledge and repeat them to you. Examples: “We don’t throw, toss, or chuck anything for any reason. We don’t scream. We put on our seatbelts and keep them on the whole time the car is moving.” However, do not expect silence or perfection. If you adjust your expectations and get ready to be calm, detached, and authoritative the whole trip, it will be much better than if you let them get to you. Being shrill or angry does not make things work better!

I remember a trip to an indoor water park on which one boy clung to me for an entire weekend, refusing opportunities to run off with the other kids or play what they were playing. I realized, halfway through, that he was just a lonely kid who didn’t know how to interact with the others. We found ways to have fun together, and by the end, he was playing a little more with the others. What if I had rejected him and pushed him away as the other kids tended to do? You want to come away feeling, “I’m so glad I was there,” and not, “Thank God that’s over with.”

2. Be prepared.

The school will give you first aid equipment, probably, but bring water bottles, juice boxes, and small healthy snacks on your own. (Make sure the school is OK with what you are bringing, and don’t ever have something in your car that a peanut-allergic child might react to.) Also bring wet wipes, towels, and a couple of changes of clothes. Bloody noses happen, and so do traffic jams that delay your return. Bring music that everybody will enjoy listening to so your passengers don’t plug themselves in to their individual electronic devices. Do everything you can to make the driving experience a shared group experience, not an uncommunicative bunch of reduced-size commuters.

Being prepared also means having maps—the old-fashioned kind that fold. GPS and phones work up to a point, but backup maps have saved me more than once when I just needed to see a quick lay of the land.

3. Know your place.

If you are running the field trip yourself—say if you are taking your own kids and their friends on a personal outing—you are the boss. In every other case, you are not. Don’t start bossing the kids in your car or making itinerary or schedule changes; defer 100 percent to the teacher or leader. This is harder than it sounds when you are taking your own child and his classmates somewhere! But you need to model deference and respect for your child’s teacher the whole time. Being a pain in the neck to the teacher will backfire down the line, for you and for your kid.

4. Know your stuff.

Don’t just take the school-supplied map and follow the car in front of you. Find out about the place you are going, and know a little about what you’ll be doing. With the Internet, it’s not hard to go to the zoo website and check out the parking areas and the walking route. Extra credit for learning about the fish you’ll be seeing in the aquarium, not so you can bore the kids with your knowledge, but so you can answer questions if anybody has any.

5. Be there.

Remember that the kids you’re taking on this trip are kids. They may have all kinds of bravado. They may behave with complete confidence and seem very independent. But don’t just get them to the door and then get back on your cell phone, or go off to gossip with the other field trip drivers.

Here is a story for you. A few years ago on a trip to Greenfield Village, I was standing near a large group waiting for a train. I noticed out of the corner of my eye when a tall, athletic boy teased a smaller, sensitive boy until he cried, then got a group of their classmates to notice and laugh at the crier. I got up in Athletic Boy’s face, and my son and his friends saw me do that and declined to go along with the bully. That was almost three years ago, and my son just mentioned it the other day.

Be on the field trip. Take pictures. Be the one standing there with the towel or cool drink when someone doesn’t yet know he or she needs it. Be the one who helps a wild kid express his exuberance appropriately. It will pay off if someday, in your dreams, you see what I see.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
News Flash!

As of September 12, American Honda has started announcing the five winners of Project Drive-In, and the Cherry Bowl was the second-biggest vote getter! That means the classic theater won't go dark after all. --Molly

I feel like this article should begin with the annoying sound that precedes a public service announcement, so that I can get the attention of anyone in the vicinity. Here it is: The remaining 357 drive-in theaters across America are in a dire situation, and Honda wants to help us save them. By the end of 2013, the movie industry will be completing the switch from film to digital projection. Upgrading to digital projection costs roughly $80,000 per screen. In an age in which movies can come directly into the car’s entertainment system, will this be the final blow to the mom-and-pop drive-in theater?

When a press release from Honda landed in my inbox about the plight of the drive-in theater, I decided to join the crusade. Honda has launched Project Drive-In, a national effort to raise awareness about the digital switch. With it comes the automaker’s commitment to donate digital projectors to five drive-in owners, who will be selected via online voting. Like Honda, I see the importance of taking care of our automotive history, so I set out to relive the experience of a real drive-in movie.

Pause for a Little Nostalgia

Our daughter, age sixteen, has grown up being entertained on long trips with the in-car DVD system. One time we went on a road trip in a car that did not have a system, and she asked in all honesty, “What will I do?” My point here is that, to an entire generation, cars and movies go hand in hand but in a completely different way than the generation that preceded it.

The first drive-in opened in 1933, and by 1958, there were just over 4,000 drive-ins across the United States. As a little girl, I remember special trips with my family to the drive-in. After our baths, my mom would put me and my siblings in our pajamas, and we would pile into the car—not a seatbelt in sight—with plenty of popcorn to go around. Of course we had a station wagon! It was the 1960s, and that rear-facing back seat was the perfect spot for viewing, but snuggling on a blanket worked, too.

During the 1970s, drive-ins began showing lots of raunchy movies to make ends meet, and as our family would drive by them along the highway, I would try to see the forbidden fruit. A few times in high school I went to a nearby drive-in with friends, and I believe we hid a few people under blankets to avoid the per-person ticket charges.
 
But beyond that, I had not been to a drive-in in thirty years. In fact, neither have a lot of other Americans. With only 357 theaters left in the country today, the drive-in truly is an endangered species.

The Quest Begins

Even though I had missed a few decades of going to drive-ins, to see them go extinct seemed like a travesty, so I began searching the Internet for drive-in theaters. I explained to my daughter about Project Drive-In, and she was intrigued. I shared with her the nostalgic stories of my youth, and my parents told her tales of their dates in the Fifties at the drive-in to further whet her appetite.

We were about to leave on a weekend trip to northern Michigan. I quickly realized we could easily see a movie at the Cherry Bowl Drive-In in nearby Honor. I have passed the Cherry Bowl hundreds of times and had recommendations from a handful of friends, but I had never seen a movie there. Shame on me, because it is a gem. Its location, smack dab in the middle of Michigan’s vacation heartland, has helped keep this drive-in continuously operating since 1953—except for the winter months, of course.

Somehow my husband and I convinced two twenty-one-year-old friends to meet us there and spend their Saturday evening watching an outdoor double feature with the fossils. Neither of the girls had ever been to a drive-in, and the novelty intrigued them. The first movie was the animated Pixar film Planes, and the second was Pacific Rim, a science fiction thriller. I personally would never have gone to either movie, but we were going for the experience rather than the movies themselves.

A Night at the Cherry Bowl

Since this adventure was precipitated by Honda, I was happy to see the girls arrive in a 2008 Honda Fit. The Fit owner is positively in love with her car and considers it her accomplice on her adventures. The hatchback has allowed her to pack up her whole life many times, and it will be her companion as she heads off into her post-college life. My family, on the other hand, was taking our first road trip in our spanking new 2013 Chrysler Town & Country. It sports a third-row seat that flips down for what they refer to as tailgate seating and which I now refer to as drive-in seating.

Our daughter was our chauffeur as we pulled in to the Cherry Bowl. We had arrived several hours early so that we could get the perfect spot. That proved to be unnecessary, as the lot was only about half full when the movie started. It did, however, give me a chance to meet the owner, Laura Clark.

What Goes On in the Projection Room?

Laura and her husband bought the Cherry Bowl from the original owners in 1997. She generously shared with me her enthusiasm for the movie industry and showed me around the projection room. This small room housed the giant reels of film, poised to show our two movies. The reels were huge because, as Laura explained, there are twenty-four frames per second, which translates to a mile of film per hour. The movies arrive via UPS in giant boxes, and when she is finished she returns them the same way. The projection booth needs to be cooled in the summer and heated in the winter to maintain the equipment, which obviously adds to the cost of keeping the drive-in operating.

Laura is faced with saving this landmark drive-in alone, as she lost her business partner and husband this past December. She shared with me the story of how a tree landed on him as they worked in the yard. Sadly, he ultimately passed away nine months later. The prospect of losing the drive-in is now that much more acute. Since Honda’s Project Drive-In was launched with the Cherry Bowl as one of the nominees, it has given her a newfound direction.

Let the Movies Begin

After our daughter maneuvered our new minivan into position, we set up the vehicles for optimal viewing pleasure. Since we were novices, we didn’t know to bring chairs. The Fit’s hatchback allowed for a bed-type area once the seats were folded down. We were surrounded by experts: our neighbors pulled out their van’s third-row seat, plopped it on the ground, strapped their babies into car seats, and sat nearby in soccer chairs. The drive-in seat in our Town & Country needed some padding to make it bearable, because the headrests create a less-than-comfortable sitting area. But we were prepared and made a snuggly spot for two while our daughter headed to join the girls in the Honda Fit. An employee circulated through the parking lot and tied strings to hold the tailgates of vans and hatchbacks down just a tad. This was so that the tailgates didn’t impede the viewing pleasure of the vehicles behind them. This personal attention added to the family fun flavor.

A Cherry Bowl Welcome

The concession stand was stocked with all types of movie musts, as well as serving more substantial treats like pizza. We opted for hot dogs, pretzels, and, obviously, popcorn. The atmosphere is family friendly, boasting a playground as well as a good-size recreation area for Frisbee and volleyball. Pets are welcome at the Cherry Bowl, and they even have a designated rest area for pets. Sadly, we didn’t know this and left our pooch at home. Sad face.

Laura served as the master of ceremonies throughout the night, and her midwestern twang offered just the right amount of flavor to come across as homey rather than corny as she made announcements about patrons who were celebrating anniversaries and birthdays. After each announcement, she welcomed the crowd to share a “Cherry Bowl welcome.” Translation: beep your horn. It made us laugh every time.

Movie Time

For the audio, you can either tune your car radio to FM 93.7 or use the drive-in’s original 1950s vacuum-tube Motiograph speakers. We opted for the speaker. They really added to the nostalgic feeling, but they also made us appreciate the sound quality that we enjoy in modern theaters.

When dusk came, we retreated to our viewing areas. The show always begins with an old school version of the national anthem that must have been the same clip shown at the grand opening in 1953. Because the drive-in always shows a double feature, they don’t take time for trailers, but they do still show the classic clip enticing patrons to go to the concession booth. The dancing hot dog and his best mate, the popcorn man, really are powerful persuaders.

The movies were good, but the atmosphere was great, and much to my surprise I only heard one mosquito all night. When we drove away, I was already planning how I would make our next trip to the drive-in even better.

Making the Fun Last

It is a great memory that my daughter and friends took away from our night at the Cherry Bowl, but I am worried about these small drive-ins surviving the digital switch.

I am sure the Cherry Bowl is similar to many of the remaining drive-ins that are still open for business. The equipment is old and maybe a little tired, but what they stand for is very relevant: good, clean fun. My family goes to movies all the time, and we love the whole experience, but the night we went to the Cherry Bowl in the summer of 2013 is one that we will remember forever.

I encourage everyone to do two things. First, go to a drive-in yourself, and see first hand what a fresh new experience this old form of family entertainment can be. And second, please go to Project Drive-In and cast your vote. Choose the theater that you care most about, or join me in voting for the Cherry Bowl so that we can still take a moment and see movies under the stars. You can vote once a day, but (loophole) you can up your favorite drive-in’s chances by voting once on every device you have each day.

Honda is scheduled to notify the five winning theaters on September 23. Along with the free digital projector, each winning drive-in will have a celebratory viewing of Sony Picture’s Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2. As of today, there are only nineteen days left in the contest, so it is important that you start voting today. Remember, just like on American Idol, your votes will determine the winners. Let’s give Honda a big Cherry Bowl thanks for creating Project Drive-In. Beep beep beep beep beep!

title: Millers at Milwaukee
promoTeaserSmall: A Favorite from our first year! I got to drive Miller's cars, which once utterly dominated at Indy.
promoTeaser: A Favorite from our first year! I got to drive Miller's cars, which once utterly dominated at Indy.
metaDescription: Millers at Milwaukee: Harry Miller's cars once utterly dominated at Indy, and his cars were revolutionary in their day. Watch video, and read my story, of a day with these rare cars on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I’ve spent the past three decades of my life having great adventures. All the best ones have been in other people’s cars. For instance, I’ve driven across the Alps in an MGB with Stirling Moss, one of the greatest racing drivers in the world. I’ve driven a 1916 Benz open touring car from the Mercedes-Benz factory museum across New Zealand on a 900-car vintage rally; the Benz looked like a carriage without the horse. Every one of these adventures has been epic and life changing. I don’t have a bucket list because I don’t need a bucket list.
I can’t even believe the things that I’ve been able to do that have just landed in my lap, and driving a Miller was one of them.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/JYBDA7mS3-E?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Harry Miller (1875-1943) was a brilliant guy who had a vision, and his vision changed racing. Before Millers came on the scene, racing cars looked like Soap Box Derby cars made out of packing crates. He was so influential that Ettore Bugatti, when he saw the Millers race, went home to France and virtually copied them.

Harry Miller wasn’t an engineer, but the cars of Harry Miller were revolutionary in their day. They were revolutionary in proportion, in performance, and in the beauty of their manufacturing, as well as their engineering, and the metals they were made of. A Miller was simple but exquisitely detailed. The accelerator pedal on the oldest one in existence, from 1920, is a perfect little brass circle. Even the filler cap on the gas tank is something you would want on your desk as a paperweight.

Millers were beautiful, they were futuristic-looking, they were mechanically advanced, and they were unbelievably narrow—like a cigar tube with four wheels stuck out at the corners. This, for me, led to a situation: more on that in a minute.

Only a few dozen Millers are still in existence, and a friend of mine has five of them. He has been telling me about this “Miller Meet” where all the guys who own these old Miller racing cars get together in Milwaukee in the dead of summer—and, by the way, Milwaukee is not a very nice place to be in the dead of summer—to drive their cars around the oldest working track in existence, the 110-year-old Milwaukee Mile.

It would be worth going to Milwaukee to see a handful of these rare cars going around that track. But it should be on anyone’s life list to have the opportunity to sit in one and drive it. And that’s what I got to do. I had it on my schedule for two years and kept that date. I showed up with my helmet and was relieved to see it was eighty degrees and not 100 degrees, as it was the year before. I saw a line of Millers, the largest gathering they’d ever seen at this event. As soon as I walked up, my friend Dan Davis said, “Oh, I think you should drive this car first.” I wasn’t there five minutes before I was sitting in the 1920 Miller TNT, and out I went on the track.

It’s amazing. You’re sitting in this cigar tube, and everything is rudimentary. There’s an accelerator, a brake, and a clutch, from right to left. I barely fit into it with my big feet. The body is cast aluminum, which was absolutely revolutionary for the day. There was nothing like it. There are only three pressure gauges on the dash and a big giant wooden steering wheel and a nice, wide leather seat. (It’s only wide because it’s also supposed to accommodate a riding mechanic.)

The sides are exposed below your waist, and there’s no windshield to protect you from the air blowing right in your face. Luckily these aren’t 100-mph cars, or they’d wipe the eyelashes right off your eyes. There’s a reason why those guys wore goggles. I was probably going 50 mph—there’s no speedometer—and it felt like 100 mph.

The experience is so thrilling. You’re out in the wind driving this big old cart. The operation of the controls is beautiful. You have a giant worn wooden wheel in your hands that feels so good and is almost 100 years old. The shift lever is a beautiful large ball that fits in your hand. You think to yourself, I’m driving around the track that the car actually raced on in the Twenties. It’s the same pleasure in machinery you feel if you type a letter on a 1920 Underwood typewriter. The noise, the smell, everything gets me all choked up.

It’s very hard to get one of these cars to start and go. There’s no synchro between the gears, so when you change gears you can’t just go from one to the next. You have to depress the clutch, pull the big lever down out of gear into neutral, gun the engine a little, put the clutch back in, and move into the next gear. If you don't time it right,  you get this big graunching noise that is incredibly embarrassing. I’ve had a lot of experience with this kind of gearbox from driving old cars, so I was pretty good, but I'm embarrassed to admit I was not 100 percent.

It’s very simple, but you have to pay attention, because the last thing you want to do is damage this car. Driving around hanging out in the wind with the sides of it cut away below your waist is the oddest sensation. I had a helmet on, and I was going fast enough that the wind kept blowing my mouth open into the smile I was definitely feeling inside.

Every now and then, going through a turn, you’re thinking, I am now sliding a tiny little bit in a car that is offering me very little protection. It does give you pause. If you lose it and the whole thing goes south, you're going with it.

Of course I stalled coming in to the pit, because I could not downshift it properly and get it slowed enough without stalling.  But I didn’t really care, because I hadn’t graunched any gears.  They pushed me in and immediately said, Okay, you need to drive the Grand Prix car next.

Now I was really feeling great, and in that car I was going even faster. Hurley Haywood came out in the TNT car, and we were running tandem around the track, and that was as fun as it could be—until I waved him by and let my hand sort of drop to my side, where it came into contact with the giant spinning right rear tire. My hand flew up in the air, and I quickly jerked it to my side without looking at it. Do you know how, when you’ve had a very bad injury, it doesn’t hurt at first? Well, I didn’t want to look at my hand because I was afraid I had just wiped three fingers off. Then I carefully looked at it, and it was just filthy dirty from grabbing the moving tire. I kept both hands on the steering wheel for the rest of the time.

After that I decided I’d better come in, and I discovered the brakes were not working. It was too late for me to grab the outside brake lever, which controls the rear brakes. So I aborted coming in to the pits and went out for one more really slow lap and this time, when I came into the pits, I had my foot on the brake and my right hand on the outside brake lever. That slowed it enough to stall me again.

That didn't deter me from eyeing the very lovely and very petite old Indy car, the 1923 Miller 122. That one was an especially tiny one: a single-seater, with a body eighteen inches wide at its widest. It  trapped Dan Davis for forty-five minutes last summer in the broiling sun. His leather shoes couldn't get purchase on the oily floor, and his crew had to remove the steering wheel to rescue him.

I crawled up on the 122 and perched above the seat. What I saw below was not encouraging. On the right of the center tunnel were accelerator and brake together, taking up what looked like the total width of my stockinged right foot. The clutch was all alone on the left. I just had to figure out how to slide in under the big wooden steering wheel. Then I’d decide if I could keep the gas and brake separate. My plan was to jump from my perch down into the seat with my legs locked at the knees.

I took the leap. My left leg slid right into place. My right knee shot up as far as it would go, trapped solidly between the steering wheel and the body side. Wouldn’t go up, wouldn’t go down. I wasn’t panicky, but I was, uh, concerned. I was stuck fast with only my horrified cameraman as witness.

Not quite. Two older guys were watching everything. After fifteen minutes, they ambled over. “We don’t mean to be impertinent, but we can get you out of there.” Without a chainfall?
“I’ll slide my hands under your bottom.” Whoa. You’re each going to grab my ass? “Well . . . yes.” Okay, then, have at it. So they each slid their hands under one butt cheek, then levitated me straight up and onto the body behind the seat. At least they didn’t recognize me.
“By the way,” said the ringleader, Dana Meadows. “I love your writing.”

Want more? See the Millers at Milwaukee story by Preston Lerner, a video interview with Miller owner Tom Barbour, and my Vile Gossip column about the Miller meet, all on the Automobile Magazine iPad app.

metaDescription: Dogs Get a Safety Boost from Subaru: Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety are testing harnesses and car restraints using dog-shaped crash test dummies. Details and early photos are on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Here's some good news: Subaru has teamed with the nonprofit Center for Pet Safety, and together they are working on ways to ensure better safety in the car for dogs. The dog crash test dummy you see here is part of the good work they're doing. Subaru has just shared the photos with us while we wait for results of the testing that is ongoing now.

Dogs are kind of a big deal here at Jean Knows Cars. We own them, we love them, and we do everything we can to keep them safe in the car. But the sad truth is that even with restraints, when you put your dogs in the car, there are dangers for the dogs and for you. The good news: Subaru has partnered with the Center for Pet Safety to create standards for the testing of pet restraints.

As it turns out, even though there are plenty of dog harnesses and restraints on the market, but there’s no system in place to determine how well they actually work. In a pilot study last year, the Center for Pet Safety determined that most pet safety restraints on the market today “do not provide acceptable protection in a crash situation,” according to Subaru’s director of corporate communications, Michael McHale. And since there’s no existing standard, there also isn’t an easy-to-understand ratings system like NHTSA’s five-star designations to guide pet owners in their shopping.
But that could be about to change with the work Subaru is helping to make happen.

Why Subaru?

The automaker has a long history of dog friendliness and marketing to dog owners. “Subaru and Subaru owners have a shared love for our pets and safety,” explains corporate communications manager Sheriece Matias Dick. Remember the "Dog Tested, Dog Approved" ad campaign? The automaker has also previously sponsored many dog-related activities, from a day to honor military working dogs to a Pets on Vacation Photo Contest with the ASPCA humane organization. There's even an ad with the tagline, "Once you sit in a Subaru, you'll stay." So the partnership with the Center for Pet Safety is a good fit.

With Subaru’s help, the Center for Pet Safety has developed four different types of dog crash test dummies. These aren’t just stuffed animals, either. They’re weighted, instrumented dog-like dummies, ranging in size from twenty pounds (a terrier mix, CPS suggests) to seventy-five pounds (a golden retriever, perhaps). The dog dummies, covered in specialty tape, will be used to test the safety of different harnesses.

Subaru and CPS hope that creating a set of safety standards will not only help pet owners choose the safest harnesses, but will allow manufacturers to create better pet restraints going forward. They will announce the top-performing harness brands in October and will also add "an education component" to help people understand the importance and the technique of using a pet restraint in the car. We'll keep you updated!

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Five Great Lakes in One Day

My family is about to get into a 2013 Chevrolet Suburban, and we're going to drive to and swim in all of the Great Lakes in one day. Everyone’s first reaction is, Why?

Well, let me tell you why. My name is Molly, and I am a Michigander. Before I could tie my shoes, I knew the names of the Great Lakes. HOMES is the mnemonic device that every Michigan student learns to remember the names of these freshwater jewels. For those of you who weren’t lucky enough to be born in the Water Winter Wonderland, they are Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior. Four of the five lakes touch the mitten state, and they define us. The rest of the country may define us solely by our recent economic plight or by the fact that Detroit is in bankruptcy. But frankly many of us here are smitten with the mitten.

When my husband turned fifty, he came up with the idea to swim in all the lakes in one day. I agreed, assuming that once we looked at the map he would realize that it couldn’t be done. However, once we mapped out the route, it became clear that we could actually do it. The route is approximately 500 miles, mostly doable by highway.

The first year was filled with one catastrophe after another, beginning the night before. When we arrived in our starting point of Hamilton, Ontario, population 500,000, we were shocked at how industrial it was. Stupid Americans that we are, we thought it would be a quaint tourist city. It was about 2:00 a.m. when we arrived, and we still had to set up our tent. As we pulled in to the campground, we were horrified to see gates down and nobody around. We found out that we needed $8 in quarters to get it to open. This proved a tad tricky at two in the morning in an industrial wasteland. However, we found a hotel that would make change for us and left with ten dollars in quarters.

Back at the campground, we started feeding the machine, and at about dollar four, it jammed. After a lot of in-car fighting, my husband held up the gate, and we drove under. Things were looking up as we drove around the campground looking for the ideal spot for our four-hour stay. We located the perfect spot and were making a turnaround when the front tires went about six inches into a grassy median and quickly sunk to mid-tire. We quickly realized that we were stuck, but good. On exiting the vehicle, we realized that this campground was actually in what is now referred to as wetlands but I still call a swamp. It was now about 3 a.m., and obviously we couldn’t call for a tow because of the gate situation. I was thinking we would just sleep right there and deal with it in the morning. But my husband went into overdrive. We had brought a bunch of floor mats to use around our campsite, and he thought if he jammed them under the tires it would give us the grip we needed. Unfortunately, I had laid them out flat under all the gear in the car. So he unloaded the entire car as millions and millions of biting insects swarmed the vehicle and us. He shoved two mats under the front of the tires and pushed. No go. Then he put two more behind the tires, and we rocked back and forth, and he found his inner Hulk, and out we went.

It was now 3:45 a.m., and no way were we going to set up the tent in a swamp. My daughter and I killed mosquitoes for about twenty minutes, and then she fell asleep draped across the center two seats. Tom did yoga with the mosquitoes for about fifteen minutes near the bathroom, no joke, and then returned to the car, reclined, and fell immediately to sleep.

As soon as we woke up, we wanted out of Hamilton, so we set out to get the first swim out of the way. Once we reached the swampground beach, we found a sign that the water was unsafe for swimming. So we left the campground in search of safe water. After driving around for about half an hour, we found a place where you could swim with a shower a few feet away. Boom, in the water and out. Even though we didn’t see a sign saying not to, Tom and Elle decided not to put their heads under. It proved to be a wise decision. Just a few meters down the path, I found another warning sign.

The entire trip followed this same pattern, so when we finally made it to Lake Superior we had a long list of improvements. Our 2013 trip is our fifth, and all signs point to it being our best. As I type this article my parents have already set up camp on the southern shore of Lake Superior in Grand Marais. In just a few hours we will head for Hamilton, Ontario in a swanky 2013 Chevrolet Suburban. Nothing could be more Pure Michigan than navigating an American automaker's whale from lake to lake.
Full details coming soon! Meanwhile, keep an eye on Twitter.com/JeanKnowsCars for live Tweets of our trip all day on Saturday, August 24.

promoTeaserSmall: This turbo hatchback has most of what I want in a car. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: This turbo hatchback has most of what I want in a car. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Veloster Turbo: Should you buy it? I think this little hatchback is most of what I want in a car. The Peanut Gallery mainly concentrated on the $1,000 matte paint job. Read my review and their comments on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $25,020 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged DOHC 4-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/35 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Seven-inch multimedia touchscreen
Option I can’t live without: Matte gray exterior paint ($1,000)
You might also be considering: Honda CR-Z, Mini Cooper, Scion tC
See more specs on the Veloster in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I’ve liked the Hyundai Veloster since first I laid eyes on it. It has most of the things I want in a car: interesting looks, a hatchback body style, good gas mileage, a reasonable price, and a silly name. But the sub-$20,000 base model is also sub-140 horsepower, and I’d heard it wasn’t particularly fun to drive. But wait! The advent of the 2013 model year brought with it a turbocharged version, which kicks the base Veloster’s 138 horsepower and 132 pound-feet of torque up to 201 hp and 195 pound-feet of torque.
Problem solved? Only one way to find out.

I drove the Hyundai Veloster Turbo for a weekend, and, to be fair, I was hoping to be impressed. But I was also ready for the Veloster to disappoint, whether by proving impractically small or by failing to live up to the promise of its beefy engine upgrade. The Veloster was far from perfect. But by the end of my weekend, I found myself wishing I had more time in it—always a good sign.

Just by looking at it, you can tell that the Veloster is a little odd. It has an asymmetrical design, with two doors on the passenger's side and one on the driver’s side. The third door is unusual, but it’s undoubtedly helpful for passengers trying to climb in the back. The back seat is fairly roomy for a car this size, with enough head and leg room for my adult passengers.

Our Turbo came with a blue-trimmed interior that drew criticism from passengers, who thought it looked tacky. A more sophisticated driver would do better to opt for the gray interior trim instead. The standard touchscreen infotainment system is quick to respond and easy to use, and the Dimension Premium audio system (standard in Turbo models) can blast out your eardrums—and those of anyone standing nearby—if you turn it to eleven.

The Veloster Turbo’s exterior comes with a sporty body kit and a grille, both upgrades from the base model. It can also be had, as ours was, with Matte Gray paint. It’s a $1,000 option, and that matte finish requires a lot of special attention: you can’t run it through a car wash, and you must use special products when you hand wash it. But the Veloster looks great with a matte finish, and it turns heads everywhere you go.

A 201-horsepower engine might seem like overkill in a compact hatchback, but I thought it provided the Veloster with just the right amount of pep. The car steers and handles well and can accelerate with enthusiasm when pushed, but it doesn’t go so far into the realm of a hot hatch that you can’t imagine driving it every day. And with an EPA rating of 35 mpg on the highway, you don’t have to feel too guilty about choosing the Turbo model instead of the base Veloster (rated at 37 mpg highway).

The Verdict:

The Veloster is no family hauler, and rear visibility is limited. The trunk is surprisingly spacious but by no means large. The rear seat is adequate for occasional use, but it might not do if you’re driving kids around all day. But for the right type of person—young, unattached, and looking for a relatively affordable car that makes a statement—the Veloster could fit the bill. If you’re more concerned about cost than power, the base Veloster might be all you need. But with sixty-three extra horses just a few thousand dollars away, why not spring for the Turbo?

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: You say Veloster, I say Velociraptor. Like the wolf-size dinosaur, the Veloster will demand your attention. At just over $25,000, this is an economy sports car. The matte paint alone will sell this car to the demographic who would stand in line to buy a phone. The rear third door on the passenger's side, with its hidden handle, came as a complete surprise to me. I only discovered it, in fact, after my passenger had struggled through the front door to climb into the rear seat. We laughed so hard that we had missed it from the outside. Mystery lovers should buy this car for the hidden door alone.

Laura: I have to get this out of the way first: I love, love, love the $1,000 matte paint on this 2013 Veloster Turbo. I am aware that it is hard to take care of and easy to ruin, which is why I drove down the road feeling as vulnerable to damage as a person who has just put on gold-leaf nail polish. I also think Hyundai should put some sort of camera in the cabin so you could admire that handsome matte paint job while you're actually driving the car. But as for driving: I found the Veloster surprisingly easy to drive well (or believe I was driving well). It doesn't feel unpleasantly small on the road, power is more than adequate, and visibility is good. I'd definitely suggest it to anybody looking for a nimble, fun, out-of-the-ordinary car, especially to anybody who is enough of a hobbyist to enjoy taking care of the matte paint job. Hey, I got $1,000 worth of second looks in the first mile.

I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text:
2013 Beetle Turbo Convertible with Sound

Vital Stats

Base price: $29,265 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $30,665 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 21 mpg city/30 mpg highway
Safety features: Front and side airbags for driver and passenger, side impact protection door beams, tire pressure monitoring system, electronic stability control
Tech features: Premium VII touchscreen radio, Bluetooth connectivity, eight-speaker Fender Premium Audio system, RNS 315 navigation system (standard in Turbo with Sound and Navigation), power folding top
Chief competitors: Fiat 500c, Mini Cooper convertible
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7DhkyvTg9-c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The Beetle Turbo uses the same 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbocharged engine that’s in the Volkswagen GTI, among other VW products. In our test car, the engine makes 200 horsepower, but a recent engine update bumped Beetle Turbo models up to 210 horsepower. Volkswagen says the update shaves 0.2 second off the Beetle Turbo’s 0-to-60-mph time and translates to a four to eight percent fuel economy savings.

• Volkswagen is tweaking the Beetle convertible lineup for 2014. The Beetle Turbo convertible will be rebadged as the Beetle R-Line Convertible. Volkswagen’s R-Line offerings are performance inspired, but this new designation doesn’t come with any powertrain changes. It's the same old Turbo with a brand-new name.

• The Beetle convertible lineup features three engine choices. In addition to this car’s turbocharged four-cylinder powerplant, there’s a 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine that makes 170 horsepower and starts at $25,790, including destination, and a TDI model with a 2.0-liter 140-horsepower diesel-burning engine. The diesel Beetle costs a little more (starting at $28,690), but it’s rated at 28 mpg in the city and 41 mpg on the highway.

• This Beetle is one of the few convertibles on the market to offer a rear seat, and it’s surprisingly roomy. An adult might feel cramped, but most kids will fit just fine.

• It’s hard to name many direct competitors to the Beetle convertible, since so much of its appeal comes from its unique history and design, but check out other small, quirky convertibles like the Fiat 500c or the Mini Cooper convertible.

• For $30,665, you might expect a nicer interior (this Beetle is awash in plastic and leatherette), but if you ever feel ripped off, just remember: you’re driving a convertible. The power folding top is fully automatic and can operate while the vehicle is moving at speeds of up to 31 mph.

• Style features: Three-color adjustable ambient lighting, leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel and leather-wrapped shift knob, eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, leather seating surfaces (standard in Turbo with Sound and Navigation), and gloss black exterior mirror housings, available in special 50s, 60s, and 70s edition decade-themed models.

metaTitle: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car?
metaKeywords: shopping for a car for a teenager
metaDescription: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car? What he had to learn about financial planning and financial literacy before he was ready. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: “My friend just got a new Mustang,” my seventeen-year-old son, Cole, informed me recently. His expression said he was hoping this information would start a competitive mothering frenzy that would end with him seated behind the wheel of same. In fact, I could feel just such an impulse rising like a craving for chocolate. “What did it cost?” I asked, giving in a little. But he didn’t know. Even his friend the new Mustang owner didn’t know. And just like that, the craving was gone.

I wanted to give my child a new toy. But at seventeen, these boys are nearly men. Adults don’t own cars without even knowing what they cost. No. It was time to teach the boy to be a man—at least when it comes to buying a car.

Grant Baldwin, a motivational youth speaker and author of Reality Check, a book and curriculum that teach teens to be prepared for the real world, backed me up. Whatever I did here would teach something, he told me. The lesson I chose was up to me. “That mom taught her son he isn’t competent, that he needs a handout,” he said.

Harsh. But true. Treating my son like a child and the car like a big toy would be sending him a clear message, and not one about behaving like an adult. In the real world where I live, buying a car involves a dozen or more financial skills, from budgeting to comparison shopping to negotiating.

So where to start? “Involve him in the start-to-finish car buying process,” advised Tony Wahl, director of operations for the online credit and loan counselor Credit Sesame. Okay. Why not start with wanting a Mustang? Every car I’ve ever bought started with a dream car. But I’m an adult, and I don’t drive a cherry 1960 Ferrari coupe.

Lesson One: Sticker Shock

Since Cole didn’t know how much the Mustang he coveted cost, we looked it up online. So his first lesson was sticker shock. Its starting price of $22,995 (including destination charge) was more than twice his highest guess. That reality check brought him right down to earth. In fact, it made him give up. So, at Baldwin’s suggestion, I offered to match dollar for dollar everything he could save, which would put a car—if not necessarily that car—within reach. “This makes it possible for him to buy a car without financing,” he explained. “But he will still have some skin in the game. And if he can’t afford much car, that’s his fault. But if he pulls together $10,000, you will have to have to match it. So be prepared.”
Duly warned, I moved on to the next lesson.

Teaching a Teen to Budget

“Create a simple budget,” said Wahl. “Include up-front costs and costs that occur over time, such as gas, maintenance, and insurance. Be sure he shows his income and expenses.” Cole liked being treated like someone mature enough to have income and expenses—and the intelligence to manage them. And budgeting was well within his math skills. But he didn’t have a job.
“Well, you need one to own a car.” I told him. To my surprise, he agreed and went off to return some job-related calls he’d been putting off.
“If he is not earning an income,” said Wahl, “he could contribute by taking on car-related responsibilities like picking up his sibling from school or sports or helping with grocery shopping.”

Should I Help Him Get a Loan?

Baldwin insisted that this is an important opportunity to teach Cole that financing is bad financial planning. Much better, he said, that I teach him to buy what he can afford and avoid debt, which raises the long-term cost of the car and limits his future financial choices. “Financing teaches him that he can buy a car he can’t afford to impress people he doesn’t know,” he said. I agree—at least when it comes to financial planning. But I know my son. He will like the possibility of a fast solution.

Wahl said:  “It’s important for him to understand that a loan helps you get what you want more quickly. But it comes at a cost. You can show him how big that cost is by using online loan calculators. Also show him how larger payments can reduce the cost of the loan over time.”

Needs vs. Wants

Now that we are talking about his own hard-earned money, the Mustang doesn’t appeal, at least not for a first car. In fact, his car of choice right now is “something I can afford.” But choosing a car is big part of the process. So we are having an ongoing conversation about how to do that well.

“This is a great time to talk about needs and wants,” says Baldwin. “You may want a great car. But you probably don’t need it.” My fear is that Cole’s needs and wants might not be very mature. I’m sure he would choose fast and sexy over safe, whereas I would like him to live a long and happy life. But we will cross that bridge when we come to it.

In addition to safety, we are exploring the long-term expenses. “Is there a difference in fuel economy and the total gas costs?” asked Wahl. “Is one model less expensive to maintain?” All important things to consider.

Negotiating

For now, Cole is driving our old minivan and saving his money. But these car-fueled financial lessons are working. He has already gotten a job. And he has pushed off the financing decision until he has enough money for at least a sizable down payment. Meanwhile, he is hyper aware that every fast food meal and video game he buys is pushing his new car further into the future. When he is ready to buy, I will explain how to evaluate a used car and the art of negotiation. In fact, we might try negotiating on some smaller purchases in the interim.

I suppose it would be fun to have a big child (and budget) so I could wrap a car up and hand my baby the keys. Every parent loves that Christmas-morning glee in a child. But I think teaching him that he isn’t a baby anymore and that adult decisions are well within his ability is a much better gift.

title: Safest Places to Drive?
