metaDescription: Safest Places to Drive? New Allstate study says which of 200 biggest cities has the least--and the most--collisions. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Automotive studies are thick on the ground. In terms of how many there are—and how few are really interesting—they’re right up there with awards shows. To this list, you might add the Allstate Insurance Company’s ninth annual America’s Best Drivers Report—or you might not, depending on how much you enjoy trivia.

The Allstate report has named Fort Collins, Colorado, “America’s Safest Driving City” for the third year in a row. A forgettable statistic—unless you live in Fort Collins, perhaps. But consider that Allstate is basing this honor on the actual frequency of crashes on which claims were filed. The average driver in Fort Collins gets into a crash every 13.9 years. That’s 28.2 percent less often than the national average of ten years. The next four cities on the list are Boise, Idaho; Sioux Falls, South Dakota; Brownsville, Texas; and Madison, Wisconsin.
Source: Allstate Newsroom

But cut to the chase, you say. Which were the cities at the bottom of the Best Drivers list? You can probably guess a few. America’s Biggest Loser is Washington, D.C., with drivers enjoying an average of 4.8 years between accidents, or about one per presidential administration. That makes District drivers 109.3 percent more likely to get into an accident than the national average. Right next to Washington, D.C., as in real life, is Baltimore, Maryland, with the average driver getting 5.4 years between accidents.
Rounding out the bottom five are Providence, Rhode Island; Hialeah, Florida; and Glendale, California.

There are a few surprises on this list. One is that Reno, Nevada, is the sixth safest city, with an accident frequency 20.2 percent less often than the national average. Meanwhile, Las Vegas is ranked at 130 out of the 200 cities measured, with a 15.2 percent greater accident frequency than the average.
Another is that no cities in Massachusetts were ranked at all because enough information was not available.

A Dubious Second Honor for Fort Collins

But before you people in Fort Collins start feeling superior, it should be noted that the parking department of Old Town Fort Collins was just revealed to be using an AutoVu tracking system that scans, recognizes, and photographs every license plate that passes through the town. The city’s parking department is hanging on to that stash of GPS coordinates and plate numbers for two years—the data was supposed to be tossed out after six months—and anybody who asks for the information can get it. The Coloradoan newspaper got a copy of the database and tracked a reporter’s Jeep to four separate coffee shops and a parking lot, in addition to his apartment. The cars may not be crashing much in that town, but nosy people can find out where they’ve been parked, making Fort Collins a contender for “America’s Safest and Most Spied-Upon Driving City,” perhaps.

metaDescription: Harvest Tour: Taste the U.S.A. See the U.S.A. through its fruit and vegetable capitals, and gain a new appreciation for the regional specialties you'll find at festivals and farmer's markets. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: My friend Maggie doesn’t consider her summer complete until she has enjoyed at least one dinner featuring only three things: ripe locally grown potatoes, tomatoes, and corn. What a great tradition, just right for our Michigan harvest season. And that makes me think about all the ripe locally grown foods out there where you live, or a short drive away.

One of the best things about traveling in summer is the ability to sample whatever the local specialties are. It’s all too easy to stay on the Interstate highways and eat at chain restaurants, completely missing the regional flavor of each area you pass through. If you don’t believe regional differences are still out there, just go to a farmer’s market sometime. You’ll feel proud, patriotic, relieved, but mostly, you’ll feel hungry.

In honor of the harvest season, here are some of the slightly tacky (in a good way) World Capitals of various fruits and vegetables around the country. Some of them have annual festivals, and some are just good places to pick up the produce from the local stores. Maybe you should visit the ones near you—or make them part of your vacation plans for next spring and summer.

And take the family! Kids love any kind of festival, and teenagers will appreciate the ironic humor value. (I clearly remember posing, in great humor, for a photo next to the Giant Artichoke statue in California. Wish I could find it now.)

1. Hadley, Massachusetts: Asparagus Capital

Yankee magazine tells us that the Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts got the Asparagus Capital moniker back in the 1920s. Although the crop’s current importance to the area isn’t what it once was, at Barstow’s Dairy Store and Bakery, you can buy or lunch on local produce, and there is still an Asparagus Festival. In 2013, it was June 2 and 3, and it featured a “Spearit” Gala feast prepared by area chefs.

2. Kennett Square, Pennsylvania: Mushroom Capital

This is Pennsylvania Dutch country, and they don’t mess around when it comes to quaint ways to spend your tourism dollar. But this is legit: A full 65 percent of all mushrooms grown in the United States come from this area. The Mushroom Festival is always the week after Labor Day, so there’s time to get there this year. An amateur mushroom appetizer cookoff is part of the fun (six finalists have already been named, making such delicacies as grilled crimini reuben sliders and hot shiitake sausage stuffed mushrooms), and there’s a parade. Sorry to say that the mascot’s name is Fun Gus.

3. Windsor, Florida: Zucchini Capital

The Zucchini Pageant is over for another year, the Zucchqueen has been crowned, the Famous Kazucchini Marching Band has played, and the Zucchinithon Fun Run is all done. But don't worry; it'll all be back in 2014. Those of us in the north aren’t anywhere near done eating zucchini yet, but in Florida, the Windsor Zucchini Festival has happened in early May for a quarter-century. Fried zucchini, zucchini ice cream, the cook-a-zuke contest? Not to be missed.

4. Vidalia, Georgia: Sweet Onion Capital

The Vidalia Onion Festival will be held over April 20-21 next year, and it will see a dozen Georgia chefs competing for the Golden Onion award. The onions can be shipped anywhere, but here’s an opportunity to see an onion farm up close—not to mention appreciate the cooking of chefs from the most chic restaurants from Atlanta to Savannah.

5. Cordele, Georgia: Watermelon Capital

Crisp County. What a great place name for the number-four watermelon-growing county in the United States. Despite its position off the watermelon podium, Cordele, Georgia, still claims Watermelon Capital of the World status, priding itself on the size and juiciness of its seedless red melons. Despite that, I don’t even have to tell you they have a watermelon seed spitting contest, do I? The Watermelon Days Festival takes place in late June. There’s also a watermelon parade and, for some reason, watermelon dance lessons.

6. Houghton, Michigan: Thimbleberry Capital

There’s no festival with parades and crowds to celebrate the Thimbleberry Capital, just a lot of natural beauty in the area, on the Keewenaw Peninsula that juts out into Lake Superior. These soft berries, native to the Great Lakes, don’t travel well, so it’s worth a visit to get them at the source. Or order jam online from the Thimbleberry Jam Lady. What are they? The thimbleberry is a wild berry that looks similar to a raspberry and tastes like heaven.

7. Hoopeston, Illinois: Sweet Corn Capital

The Hoopeston sports teams have proudly worn ears of corn on their uniforms since the Great Depression, and the Cornjerker mascot (“Jerky” for short) is part of the area’s cultural heritage. As the city fathers put it, “A slender stalk of sweet corn has been Hoopeston’s backbone for more than a century.”

The 2013 National Sweet Corn Festival this year, titled “Rumble in the Corn,” is the seventieth annual. It’s happening all Labor Day weekend. Besides the expected beer tents and beauty contests, the local Jaycees cook up fifty tons of sweet corn with an antique steam engine (!) and distribute the corn free every afternoon.

8. Emerson, Arkansas: PurpleHull Pea Capital

What’s a PurpleHull pea? Just about what it sounds like. Of African origin, the peas are members of the same pea family as the more famous black-eyed peas. Every June, there’s a cookoff (sponsored by Big Daddy’s Hot Water Cornbread) and a shelling competition, but if you’re looking for a little more excitement, a garden tiller world championship race with a $1,000 prize. They’re not kidding about the “world” part here: the 1995 event was won by a contestant from Holland. The PurpleHull Pea Festival takes place at the end of June each year.

9. Crystal City, Texas: Spinach Capital

Crystal City will get a bit of an argument from Alma, Arkansas, for Spinach Capital honors, but Crystal City’s got a statue of Popeye, so that should settle it. This small town is home to a large Del Monte processing plant. The 2013 festival takes place November 7-10.

10. Jay, Oklahoma: Huckleberry Capital

Just as Huckleberry Finn was Tom Sawyer gone wild, huckleberries are like blueberries gone wild. They’re not a cultivated berry that you’ll find at Kroger; all the more reason to adventure to where they grow wild. Or plan your next Fourth of July weekend around the Huckleberry Festival. There, they do huckleberries to death: huckleberry pie, huckleberry lemonade, even huckleberry milkshakes. For a change of pace, there’s a root beer chugalug competition. Free ice cream with huckleberry sauce in the town square, too. Huckleberry products are for sale at the town museum to take home with you.

11. Rocky Ford, Colorado: Sweet Melon Capital

This place is about more than just melons. It's about America. See, a guy named George Washington Swink had a vision that started when he opened a trading post near the Santa Fe trail in 1870. All went well until the Santa Fe railroad was built. The enterprising Mr. Swink simply moved the post a few miles so it was closer to the tracks, and that's when he brought the town of Rocky Ford into existence. In his spare time when he wasn’t founding the bank, serving as the first mayor, and representing the area as state senator, Swink also started the town on the lucrative business of melon farming. Because of him, Rocky Ford claims the title of Melon Capital of the World. This Edison wannabe even invented a cantaloupe crate that’s still in use today.

Celebrate old Swink’s genius by dropping by Watermelon Day, part of the Arkansas Valley Fair since back in Swink’s day. It’s the second full week in August every year. Rocky Ford watermelon and cantaloupe are still grown in quantity here, and the Growers Association claims it’s the 4,200-foot altitude with its hot days and cool nights that makes them special. You can order direct from Knapp Farms of Rocky Ford and get them shipped to you, but what a nice road trip this would be.

12. Jacksonville, Texas: Tomato Capital

Who would have pictured an East Texas city as Tomato Capital of the World? More in character: it’s the home of the World’s Largest Bowl of Salsa, certified by the Guinness people. Gotta see that! The festival takes place on the second Saturday in June and features tomato eating and mashing contests, tomato peeling, and a tomato shoot. Tomatoes used to leave Jacksonville in special refrigerated rail cars, but you can take them home in your own car these days.

13. Hatch, New Mexico: Chile Pepper Capital

Chile facts learned while finding the Chile Pepper capital: one fresh medium-size green chile pod has as much Vitamin C as six oranges. Even better: hot chile peppers speed up the metabolism by triggering a “thermodynamic burn” in the body. Nuclear! The Hatch Chile Fest takes place over the last weekend in August and includes the expected cookoff as well as a mariachi competition.

14. Yuma, Arizona: Lettuce Capital

Here is another unlikely candidate for World Capital, but indeed Yuma, Arizona, does have an annual Lettuce Days festival, and the next one is March 1-2, 2014. Local produce, celebrity chefs, and a harvest dinner are all scheduled. Two great cooking contests are Make Me Eat It, giving $250 to the cook who can present the most desirable healthy kid’s meal—warning, the judges are kids—and Healthy Eating the RV Way, paying $250 to the cook who can make the best road salad using only five ingredients. For those of us in the north, who aren’t even dreaming about harvests yet in early March, this green event would be part of a perfect vacation.

15. Blackfoot, Idaho: Potato Capital

If you want the recipe for potato chip cookies, or just aspire to have your picture taken next to a baked potato the size of a Chevrolet Suburban, then the Idaho Potato Museum is for you. One Trip Advisor reviewer noted, “I particularly liked the tuxedo jacket made of burlap potato sacking, and the Dan Quayle exhibit.” Looking for more of a party atmosphere? Twenty miles north in the town of Shelley, you’ll find Spud Day, happening on September 21 this year. On the schedule are a Spud Tug, a potato picking contest, and free baked potatoes handed out at noon.

16. Castroville, California: Artichoke Capital

At the time I visited the Giant Artichoke restaurant in Castroville as an eighteen-year-old, I had never actually eaten an artichoke. I remember the insanely delicious deep-fried artichokes as if it were yesterday. (I also had a date milkshake and haven't forgotten that, either.) This is the kind of place that mixes kitsch with sincere homage to the agricultural side of the Golden State. Plus, who doesn't want a photo of the family in front of a giant artichoke? There's also an Artichoke Festival here, in mid-May.

17. Redlands, California: Navel Orange Capital

Redlands doesn't celebrate its history as navel orange capital with a big, splashy festival. Instead, this town that is home to the University of Redlands features a Market Night every Thursday that draws crowds. Join them, and try out the local citrus and other fresh treats.

18. Wenatchee, Washington: Apple Capital

I have to point out that Michigan has some of the world's best apples. Nevertheless, Washington State has some great ones, too. The town of Wenatchee also spends eleven days celebrating the industry with an Apple Blossom Festival. The next one starts on April 24 and culminates on May 4 with an Ultimate Apple Pie & Dessert Bakeoff competition.

title: What Are Millennials Thinking?
promoTeaserSmall: As a Millennial, I think I found the key to our reluctance to buy cars. What a new study showed me.
promoTeaser: As a Millennial, I think I found the key to our reluctance to buy cars. What a new study showed me.
metaDescription: What Are Millennials Thinking? New study says it's not true that young people are uninterested in cars. They're just looking at the experience of car ownership in different ways. Plus, they don't have the money right now. Read about the study on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There’s a lot of talk these days about Millennials: what they want, what they do, why they love the Internet so much, why none of them have jobs. Automakers are particularly concerned about Millennials—loosely defined as people born between the early 1980s and the early 2000s—because they don’t seem to care about cars. Much has been written and said about how slowly kids these days are moving to get their driver’s licenses, and how they are even slower to buy cars.

As a Millennial myself, I was interested in a new study from the website AutoTrader, which was looking to find out if and how young people's thoughts on the automobile differ from those of Baby Boomers and Gen Xers.

I was not at all surprised to learn that it showed young people are interested in cars after all. While it’s true that today’s young people are more likely to delay earning a driver's license than our parents were, we still see cars as an important part of our lives, and we know what kind of cars we want.

Perhaps most important for carmakers, Millennials are much more wary of car dealers than older buyers are. When asked about their dealership experience, only 47 percent of Millennials who had recently bought a car considered their dealer to be trustworthy, compared with 64 percent of buyers thirty-five and older. Worse, 60 percent of the Millennials who had bought a car in the past three months said they felt their dealer had tried to sell them a service they did not want, and 56 percent said they wanted to avoid further interactions with their salesperson. That's interesting in light of the fact that Millennials went to more dealerships before buying (3.1, versus 1.9 for Baby Boomers), and 49 percent said they relied "heavily" on dealers for information, versus 38 percent of Baby Boomers.

This hesitation to trust dealerships could present a problem for automakers, but it’s not one they’re likely to ignore. Ford and Chevrolet are already working on new ways to engage young people. Speaking in a panel discussion on Millennials in Detroit, Amy Marentic, Ford's marketing manager for global cars and crossovers, said Millennials’ attitudes towards dealerships might force manufacturers to change the way they launch cars.

“Millennials want advice from friends and peers, not manufacturers,” she said. Ford is already using social media stars as brand ambassadors for the Fiesta through its Fiesta Movement campaign (right).

Dora Nowicki, marketing director for the Chevrolet Sonic, said in the same discussion that encouraging dealers to embrace technology—and not necessarily relying on face-to-face interactions to sell cars—could help bridge the gap to Millennials.

If you ask me (and why not? I am a smartphone-carrying member of the Millennial generation), the key to the whole puzzle lies in a single statistic: of the Millennials surveyed who had driver’s licenses, 52 percent didn't own a car, and 83 percent of those who didn’t own a car couldn’t afford one. Car companies can tweak the dealership experience all they want, but my guess is that Millennials will happily spend their paychecks on cars just as soon as the paychecks are big enough.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

title: 2013 Toyota Highlander V6 4WD
promoTeaserSmall: Want a capable family vehicle that lets you skip the minivan? This may be the prettier alternative.
promoTeaser: Want a capable family vehicle that lets you skip the minivan? This may be the prettier alternative.
metaDescription: 2013 Toyota Highlander V6 4WD: Should you buy it? I take my years of minivan expertise into account when saying a family of six will love this crossover. But what does the Peanut Gallery think? Read our real-world reviews on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $33,772 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter DOHC V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/22 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Side curtain airbags in all three rows
Option I can’t live without: Running boards ($649)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Hyundai Santa Fe, Kia Sorento, Mazda CX-9

See more specs on the Highlander in our Car Guide.

You could be forgiven for thinking, as I did, "Here's yet another in a long list of garden-variety crossover/SUVs. Not excited." Yes, Toyota's Highlander is a garden-variety crossover in that it has three rows of seats, comes in two- and four-wheel-drive versions, and has a slightly high, slightly chiseled body that straddles the line between a minivan and an SUV. But the Highlander is much more than the sum of its stereotypes.

Yes, there's no doubt that the Highlander looks just about like any other crossover, but it was immediately understandable and comfortable for me as a minivan driver. It feels like a classic family hauler: no highly advanced or hard-to-understand technology and nothing strange about the seating position or the visibility. The front seat area is pleasantly spacious and comfortable, and the Highlander doesn’t have any of the bouncy-jouncy feel that I associate with an SUV (and that I dislike very much on longer trips). Yet it still has that veneer of capability that an SUV owner would recognize and appreciate.

I took the Highlander on a quintessential family trip: delivering my daughter to her freshman year at Indiana University, some 300 miles from home. My state of mind may have been bumpy, but the ride was sedan-quality smooth on any road surface. And I was surprised how much power was instantly available when I accelerated. The Highlander sure felt totally different from my minivan then—in a good way. The V-6 in the Highlander makes 270 horsepower, so that explains that.

But what this kind of vehicle is all about is its three rows of seats, taking you on beyond the family of four. I have six in my family so I'm well qualified to judge, even though I brought along a mere two kids this time, so I only used the first two rows for people on this trip. I had the third row folded down the whole time to carry cargo. Even so, I liked the easy-to-slide second-row seat that grants quick access to the third row.

I was less excited about the second row as a three-passenger space. Toyota is proud of its Center Stow seat in the middle of the second row, which lets you get rid of the center seat or replace it with a console. However, it’s too small to be a true third seat, and the amount of space it saves is minimal as well. Nobody who has ever driven three small children seated that closely together for any distance would call that row a permanent home for three. For two (like my boys, shown here), it's fine.

The third-row seat doesn't seem spacious on paper, with 29.9 inches of legroom versus 43.2 inches in the front row, but my leggy eighteen-year-old son fit in there reasonably well. Six people really can find room to enjoy the ride in this crossover.

The Chevrolet Traverse, to name one major competitor for the Highlander, claims twice as much space for cargo (24.4 cubic feet with seats in place, compared wtih 10.3 for the Highlander), but I didn't feel penalized when loading dorm gear into the Toyota. The liftgate was high for me, but it didn't feel appreciably different from any other vehicle in this class.
The optional running boards ($649) were a big help in climbing in and out, and as a short person, I wouldn’t get this vehicle without them. (Your height may vary.)

To get a few other desirable features on your Highlander, you’ll want to upgrade models. Go up to the Plus or Limited models, and you get a standard backup camera, which is quickly starting to feel like a must-have item—and it isn’t available even as an option on the base models. You’ll have to go all the way up to the Limited for the optional ($1,760) rear-seat DVD entertainment system. (The Plus starts at $31,730, and the Limited starts at $40,065, including destination.)

For others, you might find yourself downgrading. If you want a six-speed automatic transmission, you’ll need to select the model with a 2.7-liter four-cylinder engine. That one also offers slightly better fuel economy numbers at 20 mpg in town and 25 mpg on the highway. (It starts at $29,880, including destination.)

If you want to be green, you’ll be looking at the Highlander Hybrid. It has the 3.5-liter V-6 teamed with an electric motor. The hybrid model starts at a more vertiginous $41,030 (including destination) and gets you 28 mpg city/28 mpg highway, not a huge jump from the traditionally powered version. But it does have the vaunted Hybrid Synergy Drive that Toyota is known for.

Toyota's name and reputation are probably a big part of the equation when someone looks at the Highlander, and that makes sense. The Highlander is a Top Safety Pick from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and has four stars out of five in federal safety testing. It's got side curtain airbags for all three rows and, perhaps even more enticing, comes with Toyota Care, which gives you two years or 25,000 miles of free maintenance and twenty-four/seven roadside assistance.

The Verdict:

If you are able to stop at six people nearly all the time, the Highlander is a very comfortable, go-anywhere ride that would give everyone as much personal space and comfort as in a minivan, which is my gold standard for whether a “family vehicle” really is a family vehicle. If you want four-wheel drive but you don't want a traditional SUV, or if crossover looks are important to you so you're not pegged as a minivan type (I won't be offended), put this one on your list. Just don't try to squash in seven people too often.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: I took the Highlander on a weekend trip to northern Michigan, and while it's certainly not the most fun I've ever had driving, it was a solid road trip vehicle: spacious, comfortable, easy to drive. I easily matched the Highlander's 22-mpg highway rating even though I was driving a little faster than is strictly recommended. If I were buying a Highlander, I might spring for one of the cushier trim levels, but that's just because I like heated seats so much. The base Highlander has plenty of features to keep the low-maintenance family happy on long drives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Based on their name alone, I already liked Outward Hound's car products for dogs before I even saw them. In this video test, I got together small and medium friends and their small and medium dogs. Louie and I were the Big Dogs of the test. We tried four products in the Outward Hound lineup, which are made by Kyjen. All had their good points, but one thing the company stresses that I insist on, too, is that you must always attach dogs using a harness whenever they ride in the car with you. None of these products can be considered safe unless your dog is harnessed in. (See my previous video on how harnesses work to keep your dog safe.)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/8e6FDCK8BR0?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
These are the products we tested and where to find them.

Outward Hound's Extend-A-Seat ($22.38) stretches across your vehicle's back seat so your dog doesn't jump or fall down into the floor of the car. It's intended for dogs over thirty pounds. There's a center "safety barrier" that is supposed to keep your dog from getting into the front seat, but that's a laugh; it wouldn't stop your average dog from simply pushing its way through to the front (or climbing right over the top). It does make the back seat into a single-level seating area, which is good, but if your dog is restrained with a harness, that will not be an issue anyway. The Extend-A-Seat has adjustable straps; it folds flat for storage when you're not traveling with a pet.

The Up & Lift Out Harness ($9.79) is for those of us with heavy dogs (fifty to ninety pounds), especially the old girls or boys who have trouble getting up into the back seat on their own. It's a nylon thing with Velcro-closing hand straps, and it is a lot less cumbersome than setting up a pet ramp. But, even using two hands, you need to be plenty strong to lift a dog into a high back seat with this sling, even a dog at the bottom of the weight range. And with no stabilizer strap across the chest, Louie almost slid right out of the sling.

The Back Seat Hammock Protector ($17.25) is just what it sounds like: a cover for your seat that doubles as a barrier to keep your dog comfortably seated in the back seat, not on the floor. It has slits to let you attach your dog's harness into the seatbelts, and there's Velcro so you can divide the barrier and leave one seat in the back available to a human passenger. I bought this for our Volkswagen Jetta at home, and I'm going to get another one for our Chevrolet Suburban.

The Booster Seat ($20.07-$25.21) raises a little dog up to window level, a plus when riding with a smaller dog (size Small fits dogs up to ten pounds; Medium fits up to twenty-pounders). It has adjustable straps that attach to the back seat and the headrest, letting you adjust the booster's height. There's a front storage pocket, a back pad that protects your back seat's upholstery, and an interior strap that connects to a harness or collar to hold your pet in place. Interestingly, the company explicitly says it "cannot recommend" you attach the booster seat to your pet's collar, a tipoff that the safety level of this booster seat is questionable. Just say no.

metaTitle: Back to School by Cadillac SRX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: New York to Michigan driving trips
metaDescription: Back to School by Cadillac SRX: A cross-country drive to return my daughter to college, made easier because we drove a 2013 Cadillac SRX. Read our story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: This is the third year we’ve ferried my daughter, Jenna, back to the University of Michigan from New York at the end of August, and it's all about the car. The discussion about which vehicle to test drive from New York to Ann Arbor starts months ahead of time. The first year, it was the Lexus RX450h, a hybrid. The second year we took a Ford Flex, and this year, we drove the 2013 Cadillac SRX Premium. All three of these vehicles look good, haul a ton of whatever Jenna has collected over the summer, and are comfortable rides for the nine-plus-hour drive.  No complaints, and I like the SRX's distinctive look that separates it from a sea of similar crossovers.

Because we live in the heart of New York City, on the Upper West Side, logistics are tricky. We usually pick up the car early in the morning from a parking lot and put it in the driveway in front of our building. Then it takes several elevator loads to bring Jenna’s goods to the lobby. This time, as always, we were stuffed to the windows but with enough space for Jenna to sit comfortably in the back and for the driver to have a clear view out of the rear-view mirror. Here's the story of this year's ritual drive.
Friday

We got on the road at 9 a.m., two hours later than we had planned. Unfortunately,  Mike, my husband, has his own time zone. So we started off the trip on a moody note, or as Mike put it, “You two are being passive-aggressive.”

The bad energy only lasted about fifteen minutes. By the time we crossed the George Washington Bridge, Jenna had turned on a movie on her iPad, and I was already analyzing how the car was driving. And true to its technology, the SRX was analyzing me, too. I kept feeling a thump on both of my thighs and finally figured out it was the Safety Alert Seat. Its mini motors planted on both sides of the driver’s seat give your hips a bump if you veer into another lane.
The SRX offers plenty of power to get ahead of traffic. The 3.6-liter V-6 has 308 horsepower and gets 17 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway.

Then there was the CUE (Cadillac User Experience), a standard eight-inch screen in the center stack with touch controls for everything from the navigation system to the temperature. CUE is engineered to approximate the iPad. In fact, Cadillac gave out an iPad with the purchase of a CUEd-up vehicle when it was first introduced. But CUE is not as user friendly as the iPad, and since I am the type of person who needs everything immediately, it took about eight hours for me to figure out how to get a quick reaction from the screen. The vehicle was also equipped with OnStar, a voice-activated system that works for quick answers. 
Playing with CUE took me through the swoopy hills of Pennsylvania. The rest of the time I listened to Chill, the electric club music station on SiriusXM through the dynamic Bose surround sound system.

Besides the predictable features, the SRX had some cool additions, like the heated steering wheel with rake and telescoping, adjustable pedals, heated and cooled leather front seats, heated rear seats, an extra large power sunroof with power blinds, tri-zone climate control (so everyone can adjust his or her own temperature), a power liftgate, a retractable cargo shade to hide our suitcases, and a Xenon HID lighting system for excellent vision on the frighteningly dark Interstate 80.

Luckily, Ann Arbor, Michigan, is easy to get to from New York City. As one friend who often drives there quipped, “Just get through Pennsylvania and take a left.” By the time we took that left, we were starving for more than my bag of berries, bananas, and almonds.
Our first stop: Bingo! A grocery store with a Subway inside. It was right next door to a yard sale, which, of course, Mike decided to check out. Unfortunately, no finds.

For the second part of the trip, Mike took the wheel. Jenna remembered that she had forgotten her TV and her vitamins. For the next hour, we had a discussion about the price of shipping versus the price of purchasing a new or used TV. Or did she really need a TV? That suggestion didn’t go over well with my daughter, so we decided to table that for the next day when we went shopping. 
 
Hour seven: We begged Mike to change the radio station. His choice, the Underground Garage station, played a steady dose of obscure rock and roll, but it eventually got on our nerves. (It’s tough being a solo man with two strong women.) Bottom line: Jenna got her choice of popular tunes. I fell asleep, and Mike drove the rest of the way.
Our destination that night was Steller House. The B & B, located a few miles outside of Ann Arbor, has been our home away from home for the past three years.

The owners, Hillary and Terry Steller and their baby, Ruby, have become old friends. Plus, Terry works in the automotive industry, so he’s always interested in whatever I’m driving. He can also talk bicycles with Mike. And Hillary prepares awesome breakfasts and even cooks gluten-free muffins for me.

We went to downtown Ann Arbor's Blue Tractor for dinner, a funky barbecue and brewery with local beers, including its own. The eclectic menu includes sliders, beef brisket sandwiches, fried green tomatoes, and black bean burgers.

Saturday

After one of Hillary’s amazing breakfasts, we went shopping for Jenna’s room. The first stop was Target for everything that wasn’t nailed down and then to Macy’s for anything we forgot.

In the afternoon, we visited Kerrytown, a neighborhood that is home to Zingerman’s, the famous deli. It also has a thriving farmer’s market and craft fair. There we bought fresh roasted coffee beans from RoosRoast, olive oil from Sparrow Market, and fresh ground cornmeal from Ernst Farm.

After a deep nap, we had a late dinner at Pacific Rim, a restaurant that my daughter has been waiting for us to take her to. Obviously, entrees like Japanese-style sablefish marinated in miso and sake, pan roasted with a soy-tamarind sauce, aren’t in a college kid’s budget. Sitting outdoors with the evening falling on a quiet Ann Arbor street: priceless!

Sunday

We started early with a trip to Jenna’s storage unit, followed by a day of unpacking at Chi-O, her stately sorority house that resembles a Southern mansion.

After a day of setting up, throwing out, and rearranging her small room in ninety-degree weather (without air conditioning), we were spent. It was 5 p.m. and time to head back to the Big Apple. Needless to say, I hate leaving my baby girl, and I cried like it was our last goodbye. Okay, I’m a wuss.

Epilogue

A few days later, after recovering from arriving home at 4:00 Monday morning, I asked Jenna for some stimulating feedback on our annual trip.

Q. Any big thoughts?
A. We only had to do one round from the storage unit, because the car held so much.

Q. Would you rather drive than fly?
 A. I like a car, because I don’t have to pack everything nicely. I can just shove it in a car, and unlike flying, there’s no weight limit on clothes.

Q. What about spending time with your precious parents?
 A. It’s always nice for you guys to come to Ann Arbor, because it brings a piece of home to school…and we go to [expensive] Main Street dinners.
Oh, and about that TV set. We forgot about it. I guess Jenna doesn’t need one after all.

promoTitle: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found

metaTitle: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Tile finding device Tile iPhone app
metaDescription: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found: It's the Holy Grail. Attach this to anything, and an app locates it for you.

pageElements.text: Every once in a while, you come across something that you didn’t realize you wanted but now realize you must have. This small, simply but beautifully designed white electronic object should have been introduced on stage by a tall, rangy man wearing a black mock turtleneck and jeans. It wasn’t, but it looks good enough to have been. It’s the Tile low-energy Bluetooth device, it will find your stuff for you, and millions of people will be using at least one by next year at this time.

The inventors at Reveal Labs used a Selfstarter crowdsourcing campaign to raise the cash for the project, and they got $2.6 million worth of it. Almost 50,000 people have preordered the Tile, billed as “the world’s largest lost and found.” You can preorder yours, too (I did), but they won’t be out until winter 2013-14.

What it is:

The Tile is a little square with a battery you don’t have to charge or replace. (Tradeoff: The Tile only lasts a year and then has to be replaced.) It currently costs $18.95, with discounts if you buy several. It is compatible with iPhone/iPad/iPod devices, not Android or BlackBerry. It has a built-in speaker and works with an app.

What it does:

The Tile has a hole in it, so it can go on a key ring. It also comes with double-sided tape, and it attaches to whatever you want to keep from losing: anything from your wallet or keys to your bicycle. (I am thinking of putting one on each of my sons so I can find them, but I don’t know if I will be able to get away with it.) Then you use the app, which saves the GPS location of the Tile—and thus, the thing it’s attached to.

There’s a You’re Getting Warmer feature that shows you getting closer or farther away from the object when you’re within fifty to 150 feet of it. That's where they sold me: find my car keys that easily, without tearing up the whole house? Priceless. For bigger distances, the app saves the GPS location where the Tile was last seen. You can keep up to ten Tiles on your account, and you can share access to Tiles with other people who also have the app.

How it can help you:

The app will remember the last place your item was located, helping you keep from losing it. If you do lose an object that has the Tile on it, you can mark it as lost, and the Tile’s cloud servers send a GPS location to anybody else who also has the app so they can let you know they've spotted it, but not other information about you or the object you’ve lost. In this way, it’s intending to be a kind of social network for stuff. Seems too hard to make that work unless you really focus on setting up your own group of Tile users—but if you look at how many people rushed to invest by pre-ordering, maybe not.

You know my comment about how this could have been an Apple invention? The Tile’s Twitter feed, a few weeks ago, showed a photo of Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak holding the Tile prototype he just purchased.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $20,580 as tested (includes destination charge)
Engine: 1.5-liter SOHC 4-cylinder, 117 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Easy-fold “Magic Seats”
Option I can’t live without: No options; the Fit’s top trim level comes standard with all available options
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Toyota Yaris
See more specs on the Fit in our Car Guide.

What I Think:


It’s hard out there for a car shopper on a budget. Most people seeking a car in the $20,000-and-under price range aren’t shopping a dream car. They’re looking for something that will be reliable, efficient, and (perhaps hardest of all) that won’t announce itself as an econobox. It’s not an easy balance to strike, but it’s one the Honda Fit, Honda’s most affordable model, is searching for.

In my experience, Fit owners are among the drivers most likely to have an evangelistic enthusiasm for their automobiles. They tell a story of a car that’s fun to drive, endlessly useful, and easy to love. I was never quite convinced by all this fawning over the Fit, but after driving it for several days, I’m starting to understand the hype.

The Fit’s key feature (aside from its tiny price; our top of the line model barely crests $20,000, and a base model can be had for $16,215) is its surprisingly spacious interior. With the rear seats down, the Fit has more cargo room than any of its competitors, besting the nearest challenger by nearly ten cubic feet. The Fit owes its impressive 57.3 cubic feet of cargo space at least in part to what Honda has dubbed the Magic Seat. It’s a rear seat that folds into a variety of configurations, including a completely flat load floor, to accommodate whatever you might be carrying.

This Fit Sport with Navigation came standard with every available option, most notably a factory-installed navigation and infotainment system. I found the system easy to use, and I especially appreciated the ease of Bluetooth audio streaming, my most frequent source of infotainment frustration in cars. The system feels a little aftermarket, and it won’t rival Chevrolet’s MyLink, for instance, but it still accomplishes its appointed task well. The rest of the Fit’s interior feels spartan, and there’s a lot of road noise, particularly at highway speeds.

The Fit makes just 117 horsepower with its 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine, but it makes up for its lack of power by earning a combined 30 mpg. The Fit Sport with Navigation has sixteen-inch tires in place of the base model’s fifteen-inchers, and it gets revised gear ratios along with a host of appearance upgrades for a sportier feel. Even so, it might be going a bit far to call the Fit sporty. With its large windshield and airy cabin, what the Fit does feel like is a much larger car. And for the shopper who’s looking for versatility and utility in a small car, the wide open spaces could make all the difference.

The Verdict:


Even though I knew the Fit was designed to maximize cabin space, I was still surprised at how large it felt. Every time someone asked me what I thought of the car, I said it felt “cheap and spacious,” which is pretty much exactly what it is. Sure, Honda could have given the Fit a few more creature comforts, but the car doesn’t feel deficient when you consider how affordable it is. It may not be an aspirational car, but it feels just right for a first-time car buyer looking for something to bridge the gap between a cute ute and a microcar.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura: Strangely enough, I have to disagree with Annie's assertion that the Fit is not an "aspirational car." As a person who has driven large vehicles for years (thanks to my four kids), the Fit has been my aspirational car for several years now. I see one of these cute little runabouts on the street, and I say to myself, Someday I will get to drive something that fuel-efficient and adorable. Having actually driven this Fit, I may have wavered slightly based on the driving experience, because you can feel the road as though you were making a rubbing of every bump and striation. The Fit would be an adjustment for anybody who was downsizing from any kind of larger, more cushy vehicle.

But it might be worth it, and the photos of Annie stretched out under her blanket inside the Fit totally closed the deal for me. I would have loved this car when I was young enough to sleep in the car on cross-country drives! Maybe I'll do some yoga to keep me capable of that when I am old and free of responsibility enough to take solo cross-country drives again.

Scott: The Honda Fit Sport is billed as a car, but it's a mini minivan. There's a ton of room inside. I could fit all my music equipment before going and playing a show in this car and fit a second person in the passenger's seat without feeling crammed in. As a Honda Civic owner, I am used to having my arm right on the door armrest when I drive. This car felt more like a minivan because there was more space in the driver's area between the seat and the door. I do wish that the rear seat could be sectioned in three parts instead of two so you could fit a third person, but I'm not sure it's wide enough. On the road, when shifting into reverse or drive, I felt a little looseness and hesitation. But overall, I enjoyed driving it.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I went to my first Pebble Beach in the late 1980s. I don't think I've missed more than maybe two. I may say I hate dead-car shows, but clearly I'm a liar. I love the people who collect these cars. I love to see my friends, among them retired and working racing drivers, car designers, car collectors, and royalty. Yes, royalty. There he was, HH Maharana Sahib Manvendra Singhji Bahadur, 58th Maharana of Barwani, in the flesh, standing in the line of judges ready to go on the field. "Manvendra!" I shouted, six inches from his face.

"Oh, my God in Heaven!" he shouted back. I hadn't seen the Prince of Barwani since 1991, when he visited me at Automobile Magazine's old offices at 120 East Liberty Street. Don't you love it when that happens? He's not the only prince I've ever met, but he's certainly the only one who ever visited me.

The Monterey weekend is packed with vintage car events from races at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca to the Quail, an exclusive event on the grounds of the Quail Lodge. There's the Concorso Italiano, car shows in the streets of Pacific Grove and Carmel, and big, important auctions all over the traffic-choked peninsula. In fact, a 1967 Ferrari 275GTB/4S N.A.R.T. Spider Corsa, sold at the RM Auction by the family of its original and sole owner, Eddie Smith, brought $27.5 million—a staggering amount that broke multiple auction records. The family donated it all to charity.

image.caption: Start/finish line of the Pebble Beach Tour d'Elegance.

pageElements.text: The Monterey weekend actually begins in the early morning on Thursday, when the cars that will be on the lawn at Pebble Beach on Sunday gather for a long drive down to Big Sur and back. This year, the drive began with two circuits of Mazda Raceway before heading to Big Sur. The green ribbons you see everywhere on Sunday indicate the cars that went on the drive. When the judges can't make a decision, the green ribbon is the tie breaker.

This year, amazingly, there were four Prinz Heinrich Benzes, considered to be one of the first true sports cars, at Pebble Beach. I had the great fortune to ride in the back seat of a 1910 Prinz Heinrich owned by Mercedes-Benz Heritage, which was restored in tandem with a privately owned 1910 Prinz Heinrich. I was chauffeured by the head of Mercedes-Benz Heritage, Michael Bock, and racing driver Alex Lloyd was in the other.

image.caption: In the back seat of the 1910 Prinz Heinrich Benz.

pageElements.text: I was excited to see how wide the back seat was. I had plenty of room for myself and a bag. And then I discovered that the car was not meant for one person in front and one in back, but two people in each seat. They sure were tiny back then. Much to my surprise, our German riding mechanic showed up and got in the back seat with me. He was the same size as me. This was a seat big enough for three of our butt cheeks, but not quite four.

Over the course of the five-hour drive, we perfected the maneuver of counting to three and then, each with an arm wrapped around the other's shoulders, sitting down together, perfectly wedging ourselves into the back seat.

image.caption: Michael Bock of Mercedes-Benz Heritage, driving the 1910 Prinz Heinrich Benz.

pageElements.text: Meanwhile, in the front, there was no windscreen. Herr Bock took the brunt of the wind coming at him from the ocean, which was so brutal on the way back north to Carmel that he put on goggles and had his left hand clamped over his mouth to keep his lips from ripping off.

Like the Millers I drove the month before, being in this car was a thrilling, visceral experience that I can barely describe, other than to say that the openness, the big steering wheel, the smell of all the mechanical parts and fluids, the amazing comfort of the big cart-sprung suspension, and over it all, the sound of the valves chattering happily under the big, long hood, all transported me back more than 100 years ago. The Prinz Heinrich was more than a century old and delivering one of the most pleasurable, satisfying motoring experiences of a life that has included driving some of the world's most exotic cars.
Thank you, Mercedes-Benz.

The culmination of the weekend is the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, which has become much more fun and less stuffy in recent years with the addition of vintage Indy cars, vintage motorcycles, and the Preservation class of unrestored cars mixing things up. Yes, there are still the overrestored, Q-Tip-swabbed wheeled objets d'art. In fact, one car rolled in with what someone in the crowd described as "tire condoms" protecting tires from, God forbid, blades of grass adhering to the treads. But when you walk down the lawn, every third car is a car you've never seen before in your life, and you're so glad that somebody decided to be its benefactor. This is Sandra Button, the queen of Pebble Beach. She is responsible for all of this, ensuring that I can't imagine an August without being here.

The cars are not just in exhibitions everywhere but driving past you on every road. On scenic Seventeen Mile Drive, I was following a Pagani at one point, the first one I've ever seen on the road, from behind the wheel of a new Maserati Ghibli. The noise was stunning but after a while I wasn't sure which car it was coming from, so I opened the window. It was the Maserati's engine. Musica! See ya, Pagani!

title: My Weekend with Maserati
promoTeaserSmall: What's it like to bid for and win a Quattroporte drive and a VIP day at the races? Let me tell you.
promoTeaser: What's it like to bid for and win a Quattroporte drive and a VIP day at the races? Let me tell you.
metaDescription: My Weekend with Maserati: I bid, and won, on a charity weekend that involved driving a Maserati Quattroporte and watching the Maserati Trofeo racing from the VIP area. Read the story of my adventure on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm a trial attorney, car blogger, and motorsports enthusiast whose idea of fun is going to Detroit in January or watching a six-hour endurance race. A native Texan, I currently live and work in the Austin area. When I'm not in the courtroom, you can find me driving my red Mini John Cooper Works, wrangling my pets or enjoying some delightful Texas cuisine (Tex-Mex and barbecue!). In 2013, I started a blog, Motorista, to document my car adventures and opine on all things auto related. The courtroom is no longer a man's world, and the car world won't always be, either!

pageElements.text: If there’s a life lesson I learned this summer, I guess it is to pay attention to eBay (and JeanKnowsCars.com). You never know what exciting opportunity might be waiting!

My Maserati adventure began with this website. I read an article in early August about an upcoming eBay charity auction for a Maserati Trofeo weekend package. The package included the opportunity to drive a Maserati and attend two days of Maserati Trofeo races at Sonoma Raceway in Sonoma, California, with VIP access to the Maserati hospitality tent.

I live in Texas, where triple-digit temperatures are the norm in August. A weekend in wine country with Italian cars at a racetrack (pretty much my favorite place in the world) sounded like a no-brainer to me. Even better, 100 percent of the proceeds from the eBay auction would go to charity. In other words, I could have a spontaneous bucket-list-style adventure while helping others. Again, a no-brainer.
Much to my surprise, I actually won the auction and, on a Friday two weeks later, I was on a plane to wine country, blinking in disbelief at my extraordinary luck.

At 7:00 on Saturday morning, I arrived at Maserati of Walnut Creek, a brand-new dealership that donated the auction package. The dealership team, including owner Mario Biundo, marketing manager Massimo Cervelli, and service manager Trevor Thomas, instantly made me feel welcome as they gave me my track passes and introduced me to my car for the day, a Silk Black 2014 Maserati  Quattroporte GTS.

The Quattroporte is all new for the 2014 model year and, to my eyes, is even lovelier than its predecessor. I’m not generally a fan of long drives in traffic (particularly the gridlock for which California is famous), but I could have spent all day, and then some, in this car. The driver’s seat is a most excellent place to spend time, and the steering wheel felt just right in my hands.

As a Mini owner, I expected to have difficulty adjusting to a car as large as the Quattroporte, but I needn’t have worried.  Even at more than two tons, the QP is quite agile; while sure-footed and planted, it doesn’t feel ponderous. Maserati reports a 0-to-60-mph time of 4.6 seconds, and, while I never had the opportunity to test that assertion, I can report that the 3.8-liter V8 engine, which makes 523 horsepower, is eager to accelerate to whatever ungodly speed you prefer, without a hint of hesitation or turbo lag.  The new Quattroporte is an impressive achievement.

Our one-hour rally drive to Sonoma Raceway included another Quattroporte, a few Maserati Gran Turismos, and some Ferraris. We avoided the busy highway where possible, snaking through winding back roads, with beautiful lakes and rolling hills appearing in our windows.  The scenery was quite lovely, but our convoy of Italian sheetmetal was the true sight to behold.

Having arrived at the track in grand fashion, I was escorted to the Maserati VIP hospitality tent, which was overflowing with food, wine, chair massages, flat-screen TVs…oh yes, we were also less than fifty feet from Turn Two on the track. This turned out to be a bonus, since Turn Two, uphill and off-camber (meaning that the road slopes toward the outside of the turn), generated a fair amount of excitement, with spinouts and the occasional wall bump.  Two Maserati Trofeo races and one IndyCar qualifier later, I had grit in my teeth and brake dust up my nose.  In other words, I was perfectly happy.

Sunday’s drive to the racetrack was quite a bit less exciting in my rental Chevrolet Impala, but I would have gladly driven a Yugo as long as it got me to the track. Sunday’s races included another Maserati Trofeo race, the Pirelli World Challenge (my favorite racing series!) and IndyCar’s GoPro Grand Prix of Sonoma, which was a tough, physical race, particularly at Turn Two.  It was exhilarating.
