pageElements.text: I left California sunburned and tired but completely happy with my Maserati experience.  Happiness may be a warm puppy, but spending a weekend at Sonoma Raceway surrounded by Maseratis is close enough for me.

title: 2013 Chrysler 300C John Varvatos
promoTeaserSmall: Made-in-Detroit stalwart gets a fashion upgrade from designer John Varvatos. How stylish is this?
promoTeaser: Made-in-Detroit stalwart gets a fashion upgrade from designer John Varvatos. How stylish is this?
metaDescription: 2013 Chrysler 300C John Varvatos: A limited-edition version of the Chrysler adds taste and style to the Detroit standard. See my video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $41,840 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $50,620 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6 engine, 292 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Safety features: SafetyTec package ($1,995) includes blind spot and cross-path detection, ParkSense front and rear park assist system, adaptive speed control, and forward collision warning; 300C also has anti-lock brakes, stability control, traction control, and seven airbags, including a driver’s knee bolster airbag
Tech features: Ten-speaker Beats audio system ($995); Light group ($795) with bi-Xenon HID headlights; panoramic sunroof ($1,495)
Chief competitors: BMW 528i, Hyundai Genesis 3.8, Mercedes-Benz E350
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/6bf-BILhvR4?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• There are two Varvatos versions of the 2013 Chrysler 300C: Luxury and Limited. They're designed with an industrial look and feel to reflect the Motor City's blue-collar roots.
• In addition to the options listed above, the car we tested has Phantom Black Tri-Coat Pearl exterior paint ($500) on top of the Varvatos Limited Edition package ($3,000), which includes twenty-inch titanium-painted aluminum wheels, leather-trimmed seats, a numbered badge, a special analog clock, black velour floor mats, and satin titanium trim.
• This test car has a black exterior punctuated with metallic finishes inside and out. The cabin features hand-sanded wood, stitching patterned after the designer’s fitted jacket collection, and a special analog clock.
• The Varvatos Limited Edition we drove is not topped out. It can be ordered with optional 363-horsepower 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 engine, which adds an extra $2,200.
• This is one of the most expensive versions of the 300C, and there are several of them, including the Motown Edition, the Glacier Edition, and the 300C SRT8. The SRT8 is the most expensive, with a starting price of $50,445, including $1,000 gas guzzler tax and $995 destination.
• The Chrysler 300 holds a top five-star safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was a 2013 Top Safety Pick by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. However, IIHS has not conducted small overlap front crash tests on the 2013 Chrysler 300.

• John Varvatos is a menswear designer from Detroit. Women’s Wear Daily praised his fall 2012 collection for its “rock ‘n’ roll vagabond vibe.” His clothes have been described as having a soft, raw, and “lived-in" look.
• Chrysler turned to Varvatos, who has been a celebrity mentor on NBC’s Fashion Star, to extend its “Imported in Detroit” theme that first emerged with Eminem’s gritty Chrysler commercial during the 2011 Super Bowl. That commercial now has more than 16 million YouTube views.
• The Varvatos 300C is another example of when fashion and cars collide. Many designers have linked their names to automobiles. Examples: Victoria Beckham Range Rover Evoque with exclusive matte gray exterior paint and rose gold touches in cabin; Dana Buchman Cadillac SRX with snakeskin print fabric in the storage compartments and silk carpets; Mini Cooper by Kenneth Cole with exterior covered with studs.
• This car is a study in black and edgy materials. The Limited Edition is said to be styled after the designer’s cologne bottle as well as the foundries that once made the Motor City flourish.
• It's also seemingly aimed at men. Chrysler says it’s for the guy who comes in early, leaves late, and works harder “than the next guy.”

title: Great Lakes Swimapalooza!
promoTeaserSmall: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in a day. And we did!
promoTeaser: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in a day. And we did!
metaDescription: Great Lakes Swimapalooza: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in one day. And we did! Read the whole story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: My family and I went on an unusual journey at the end of the summer: we successfully swam in all five of the Great Lakes in just one day. It is not a difficult feat that requires years of preparation or amazing athletic prowess, but it does take a certain passion to accomplish this goal. It combines a passion for sitting in a car for a very long time, combined with the ability to quickly plunge into cold water. During the very same week, Diana Nyad put us to shame by swimming from Cuba to Miami. We still hold our heads high as members of a very elite group—and we didn’t require a support team to fend off jellyfish. How did we know we could do it? Because this is our fifth time going on the ambitious one-day, 500-plus-mile adventure, and we're veterans now.

For weeks prior to our trip, my family discussed which vehicle would be best to carry us on our pilgrimage. It is a true fact that my family consists of just three humans and one ten-pound pup (me; Tom, my husband; Elle, my daughter; and Bizee, our Jack Russell), but we do not pack light. Also, once we completed what we refer to as Swimapalooza, we would be camping for two days and then vacationing in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan for another seven days. Our list of requirements included a roof rack to hold all our camping gear, a hitch to attach our bike rack, and the ability to tote around my almost octogenarian parents, who would be meeting us at the end of our palooza. I set my sights on the Chevrolet Suburban, a vehicle that is perfect in every way for this kind of challenge.

image.caption: We wanted to let everyone know what we were doing.

pageElements.text: I'm here to tell you that dreams do come true. We got a 2013 Chevrolet Suburban and made it the fifth member of our family for the trip. I like to dress up our dog, Bizee, and I like to decorate our cars. We listed each lake on the window with Crayola Window Crayons and our estimated arrival times at each lake, and we also encouraged people in passing vehicles to honk if they love Michigan. As a finishing touch, we made magnetic signs and placed them on the front doors to show our route and tout our slogan: “One Day, Five Great Lakes.” It is telling of my family’s spirit that we were all equally geeked to be driving a giant beast that shouts, “We are having a great time! Are you?”

Swimapalooza Eve: Ann Arbor to Hamilton, Ontario

My daughter, Elle, was ready to go at 5:00 p.m. on Friday. She had already singlehandedly packed the car in preparation for Tom’s arrival home. She had thoroughly explored the Suburban and set up her nest behind the driver. The headphones were prepped, and the first movie was poised to begin. She set a place for Bizee to travel in the seat right next to her. Her beverage was already in one of the cupholders behind the front seat console. A cozy blanket and pillow were strategically placed for her to quickly access when necessary. Then we waited for Tom. And waited. And waited. Finally, around 8:00 p.m., he arrived home and quickly threw his last-minute items into the cavernous interior. We set sail for our first stop: Hamiton, Ontario, a mere 252-mile drive.

We set the navigation for our hotel near Hamilton. The layout of the navigation screen was odd and left us feeling unsure of how many miles were left in our journey, and we couldn’t get our hotel’s address to register. Since you need to be stationary to set it, we opted to keep moving and use our handheld TomTom instead. The drive would take a little over four hours, and we needed to be out of bed by 7:00 a.m. Luckily, we were living off vacation adrenaline. During our long wait for Tom, Elle and I had connected our phones to operate via Bluetooth. It was not an overly user-friendly process, but once we consulted the manual we got it done quickly. We didn’t bother to set up the iPod via Bluetooth but instead opted to use an auxiliary cord. The center console has two accessory plugs, which was perfect to keep all of our gadgets powered at all times.

As we drove, we admired the common-sense layout of the instrument panel. The side blind zone alert signal in the side-view mirrors added an extra set of eyes to make any blind spot created by the bike rack less ominous. The front console housed four cupholders, which were barely enough for my husband. Tom likes to juggle a fresh coffee, an old coffee, flat water, and bubbly water to keep him perfectly hydrated for long drives. He is seriously high maintenance when it comes to hydration and the accompanying rest stops on long drives. But I keep my mouth mostly shut, enjoying the catbird seat with plenty of pillows and flannel blankies for a good portion of the trip. We rolled into Hamilton around 1:00 a.m. and quickly fell asleep dreaming of driving, and driving, and driving.

Lake Ontario

We ate a quick continental breakfast at our hotel and set out to knock off Lake Ontario before 9 a.m. Since we have honed our route over the past few years, we now take the first dip along a thin spit of land between Hamilton and Burlington. The water is clear, and the bottom is sandy, although the high-power electric lines lose the beach points for beauty. The air temperature was a pleasant 70 degrees, but the water was surprisingly frigid. We set up a portable changing room and made a quick change into dry clothes. Tom had created an in-car clothesline to dry his suit, and Elle had brought along five suits to eliminate the need to struggle into a cold, wet suit. And I am a wimp and actually only photograph the swims, since if the team had to wait for me to fully immerse myself in the lakes we would still be on this odyssey.

Hamilton to Port Stanley, Ontario

Once we were heading west, Elle and Tom both engaged their seat heaters, and I enjoyed the fabulous power lumbar support, which I combined with the heated seat to help me recover from a seriously wrenched back that had required a quick trip to the chiropractor on the day of departure. (Not to jump ahead, but I think my seat actually healed me.) The heated steering wheel was a bit of overkill on our August trip, but we imagined it would be a godsend in February.

Elle quickly conquered the whole entertainment system and barked out orders to her minions in the front seat to get her movie started. Phone calls were coming and going. Because we used the car speakers, it was possible for all us to be included in updates to our friends and family. We zipped across the bucolic countryside, enjoying the SiriusXM radio, and Tom became the master of controls via the steering wheel buttons. As we pulled into the quaint tourist town of Port Stanley, the temperature had climbed to 80 degrees, and the cove where we planned to swim was quickly filling up with tourists.

Lake Erie

Our swim spot is always very wavy, and this year did not disappoint. Lake Erie's water was much warmer than Lake Ontario's had been, but Erie also proved to be the murkiest of the lakes. As we exited the beach, I spied a group of ladies doing yoga. This town always makes me want to sit down for a relaxing lunch. But no can do: we still had nine hours of driving, a border to cross, and three lakes to conquer. Tom’s in-car clothesline was a bust; there was no breeze or sun hitting the suits. We went back to shoving them up on the dash and allowing the sun, with an assist from the defroster, to do the work. Since our next leg was six hours, I was confident they would be dry for the next dip.

Port Stanley to Cheboygan, Michigan

As we left Port Stanley, it was time to refuel. We grabbed sandwiches out of our cooler to refuel ourselves and filled the 31.5-gallon tank as well. I was shocked to see the price for that tank climb to $114 Canadian, and with a combined 17 mpg, this wouldn’t be my last stop. I reminded myself that there is a cost with bringing everything you own on vacation. However, I knew that once we arrived at our destination, I would be glad that I had not left my gravity recliner behind. I was a little heated from the high gas price and cooled myself right down by testing the cooling feature of the seats. Elle was turtling in the back seat watching Almost Famous, Bizee was sleeping, and Tom and I spent the next hour or so playing Guess That Tune with the iPod, courtesy of the excellent Bose surround sound. Life was good.

Blue Water Bridge

At 7,400 pounds, the Suburban would be an excellent contestant on The Biggest Loser, but surprisingly the 5.3-liter V-8 engine had no problem making the effort to move this whale down the highway. The Suburban remained stable in quick lane changes, and we didn’t experience any lag when we stomped on the accelerator. The ride is smooth, and coupled with my couchlike seat, I felt like I was flying first class and the pilot had just announced that we were not expecting any turbulence on the flight.

Once over the bridge, Tom was ready for a nap, and I took command of our land yacht. Tom is a fan of cruise control and generally stays within a few miles per hour of the speed limit. I, however, tend to skip cruise control and throw caution to the wind and cruise between 80 and 85 mph. Nothing crazy, but seriously!  Seventy-three mph feels like we are standing still.

In past years, the border crossing at the Blue Water Bridge in Sarnia, Ontario, has proved to be a time suck. We often lost an hour waiting in traffic for our moment to tell the border patrol why we had been in Canada for less than twelve hours. This year was a pleasant surprise: we made it to the booth in less than ten minutes. As usual, the border patrol agent was very serious, and he was not thrilled that I was taking photos. At one point we were pretty sure there would be a strip search. But just as I was envisioning myself naked in a cinderblock room, he released us. Whew—high fives all the way around, including Bizee, who had to be awakened first.

Elle happily moved up to the front seat and complained that she was feeling really cramped in the back seat—too little legroom, and the seat couldn’t recline with the cargo behind it. None of these First World problems concerned Tom as he slept like a teenager for the next five hours. Meanwhile, Elle went into DJ mode, and the hours flew by with her spinning the tunes. I made sure to savor the moment of mother-and-daughter time as we discussed her upcoming junior year of high school. There is something about talking in the car that has the same effect as the confessional on The Real World.

Another stop for gas, and another $100 flew out of my wallet. A fellow gas pumper took notice of our window painting and asked about our quest. He shared our enthusiasm for the Great Lakes and said he thought it was a great idea. Maneuvering around the gas station was easier with the Suburban's backup camera, even though the bikes partly impeded the view.

Lake Huron

As we neared Cheboygan, my bestie Tam Schirmer met us in the nearby town of Indian River, and I hopped into her car for the drive to the shore of Lake Huron. Tom resumed his captain duties and was happy to discover that indeed his suit had dried nicely in the sun. With our fan base of one, Elle and Tom dashed into the water to check off lake number three. The water remains at waist height for what seems like miles, so the two actually had to submerge themselves and swim in the shallow water. Every year we discuss finding a better spot, but we never do.

Cheboygan to Brevort

We waved goodbye to Tam, feeling a bit jealous that she would be sitting lakeside in a few minutes with a beverage in her hand. But our two favorite lakes were calling. In fact, our swim in Lake Michigan was less than an hour's drive away, and this portion of the drive was indeed the most picturesque of the day. Once we spotted the Mackinac Bridge, we were stoked. The drive over the five-mile-long bridge is always a highlight. Mackinac Island is off to the right, power boats are zipping around, and often there is a barge passing through the Straits of Mackinac. If you haven’t ever heard one of the Pure Michigan ads with Michigan’s Tim Allen, do yourself a favor and watch this one. This moment was Pure Michigan.

Lake Michigan

As we traveled along U.S. 2, Lake Michigan dazzled us with its beauty as it came and went from sight. The route is peppered with scenic overlooks, but just over thirty minutes later, we reached a point where the water comes almost right up to the road. A small sand dune is all that separates this stretch of road from the water. There were a dozen or so cars pulled over, but the beach is so vast that each group seemed to be on its own separate beach. The waves were pure perfection, and Elle and Tom were practicing cartwheels and happily bodysurfing, but I reminded them that Lake Superior was still an hour and a half away. Even though this beach is right next to the highway, it is idyllic, and you barely notice the road. Again I wished that we could linger here.

Brevort to Grand Marais

This portion of the drive is the most difficult—we were all tired, sick of sitting, and thinking about the chilly waters of Lake Superior and the prospect of having to set up our tent. In past trips to the U.P., before there was satellite radio, the radio selection was horrible. I have heard Gordon Lightfoot’s Lake Superior classic, "The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald," at least once on every trip. However, the XM and another round of Guess That Tune saved the day. This leg is mostly through heavily forested terrain that is riddled with deer with a death wish, so at night all human eyes need to scan the horizon for glowing animal eyes.

Lake Superior

Luckily, we did not spot too many suicidal deer, and we pulled into the harbor town of Grand Marais at 9:40 p.m. My parents met us at the beach, where the temperature had dropped to 65 degrees. Tom and Elle quickly changed into their suits under the cover of darkness and screamed as they ran into the chilly water. They were pleasantly surprised that Superior was warmer than Ontario had been for the morning swim fourteen hours earlier.

The Suburban had proved to be a worthy companion on our trip despite the fact that it is a gasaholic. We still had over a week to recover from our blast through the Great Lakes and were sure happy that our pole barn on wheels had all of our toys inside to help us enjoy our favorite lake that is named Superior, because it is.

pageElements.text: This request goes out to all the parents out there. How many hours a week do you estimate you spend in the car with your kids?

And when you're driving them, what kind of attention are you paying to the music they hear? With babies and toddlers in car seats, I'm betting you mostly play what you like to hear, and they're along for the ride. With tweens on up through the teen years, they're most likely plugged in to their own iPods or phones, listening to what they want to hear (and you probably would rather not).

That leaves a whole demographic that nobody's paying attention to, and they're mainly the ones I'm talking to you about today. Between babyhood and eighth grade, there are many years of listening in the car, and you can use them to teach, to share your musical tastes, and really, to blow your kids' minds with beauty or outrageousness in music. And you don't have to get into World War Three to make it work. Here are my five secret strategies that I hope you'll make your own.

1. Know what you want your kids to hear.

Don't be mindless about what you play. In my case, I wanted my kids to hear complex, gorgeous classical music. So I used to go to the library and check out cassettes, and later CDs. One memorable day, I maneuvered to have the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in one hand and my three-year-old in the other. I waited for my moment: we had a twenty-five-mile drive to take, just the two of us. I put it on, and he ignored it and wriggled around in his seat...until it got to this part where the orchestra explodes. His eyes as big as saucers, he didn't move a muscle for the rest of the drive. I could see his brain cells expand at that very moment. These days, you have the whole YouTube/iTunes world of music at your disposal. Think it over, and choose wisely.

2. Start low and gradually get louder.

By this I mean, you can play almost anything if it's almost unnoticeable at first. I can't even overstress what a huge discovery that was for me, and it still works no matter how old my kids get. I used to be a Suzuki violin mom, meaning I had discs of violin music that my two violin student children were supposed to listen to a lot every day. If I put on the CD at normal volume, they might protest (the other two who were not studying violin protested loudest of all). But, I learned, if I put it on almost vanishingly softly, they wouldn't care, and I could slowly increase the volume until it reached loud. By that point, they were listening and usually liking it.

3. Make it into a treat, not a lecture.

For instance, I waited till my three older children, then all between eight and ten, were in the car together. I announced, "I'm going to play you one of my favorite songs. It has a murder in it. I think you're all big enough to handle it. Okay?" Had their attention then! Guess what the song was? Bohemian Rhapsody, by Queen. I will never forget the looks on their faces as they took it in. They all still listen to Queen, years later. I also tried to get under-twelves interested in Bob Dylan. That one didn't take at first; I mainly remember their derisive laughter at his "bad voice." I accepted that and didn't force the issue or lecture, and now my eighteen-year-old has virtually the whole Dylan catalog on his iPod. I have to think that presenting the music to him at a young age was a start, even if I didn't get instant gratification for it.

4. Tie in the music with other things you can do together.

You could plan to take a child to a concert of someone you love to hear, or someone you want your kids to appreciate. I got Paul McCartney tickets for my eight-year-old, who had just started guitar lessons at the time. It was a surprise, but in the weeks before we went, I played a ton of vintage Beatles and McCartney music in the car. I didn't say anything about why. When we arrived at the Palace of Auburn Hills to hear Sir Paul, my boy already knew all the songs without being told he had to. You could also choose a theme, such as New Orleans jazz when you're going there on a family vacation, or songs in a language your kids are learning, or movie music in the week before the Oscars are on. The car is the place where you have the block of uninterrupted time with kids to build a theme like that.

5. Have a sense of occasion.

If you're going on a trip, why not make a road trip playlist? (Here are some of the Jean Knows Cars playlists we just made, for inspiration.) I associate M.I.A.'s All I Wanna Do with a drive to Vermont with my fourteen- and sixteen-year-old sons, because we had it on our playlist. Not like I am recommending that music, but it helped us bond, and when I appreciated that, they appreciated what I wanted to play, in that case Graceland, by Paul Simon. What fun to roll out a "Road Songs" playlist for your kids next time you are driving somewhere for the weekend. Come on, you can think of some great songs your little kids need to hear that won't be on the radio or their iPods.

You may not care if your children absorb Tchaikovsky (shame on you, though). But if you want your kids to grow up knowing and appreciating jazz, or Prince, or Leo Kottke, or Pink Floyd, they're not going to pick it up at elementary school. It's absolutely your job to insert it into their heads. In the car is the best place to do that. Bonus: The more you set the expectation that you will give your kids a great listening experience in the car, the fewer times you'll have to twist the dial to get away from "Blurred Lines" and One Direction.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: We recently drove the 2013 Toyota Highlander, and even though we liked it, we thought was room for improvement, especially in interior space.

Cue the redesigned 2014 Highlander. Toyota has tweaked the crossover in a few small but significant ways. The tweaks include revised exterior styling and a redesigned center console (specifically sized to fit a large purse). And remember that tiny third row? It’s been stretched to fit a third passenger.

Whenever I hear that a car has been designed with some feature that’s supposed to appeal specifically to women–like a six-cupholder center console or Honda’s new in-car vacuum–my kneejerk reaction is to dismiss it as pandering.

When I heard that Toyota had specifically engineered the center console in the new Highlander to fit a large purse, I was momentarily annoyed that Toyota thinks women need somewhere to stuff their purses in order to be happy with a car.

Then I thought about how convenient it would be to have a dedicated space to shove my giant bag other than the passenger’s footwell, and I decided this was one piece of gender stereotyping I could get behind.

The purse-concealing center stack is a feature I didn’t even know I was missing in the 2013 Highlander, but the redesigned third-row seat could bump the Highlander up to the short list for buyers who frequently make use of the far back row. The new back row will be more than four inches wider than the outgoing seat, which makes room for a third occupant and means that the Highlander can be configured to seat eight. Larger rear windows also mean that the kids who are relegated to the back seat won’t feel as claustrophobic.
Toyota also redesigned the Highlander’s front fascia with a trapezoidal grille and tweaks to the headlamps and front and rear fenders, which should help the Highlander stand out from the crowd.

Buyers anxious to get their hands on the 2014 Highlander will have to exercise some patience. The gasoline-powered version won’t hit dealerships until this December, with a hybrid model to follow in February of 2014.

pageElements.text: Here's the thing about the small-crossover segment of the auto market: those little vehicles can get expensive. That's why the best news about the all-new 2014 Nissan Rogue is that it is going to be priced starting at $23,350, including an $860 destination charge. Even the top-end model will come in at a starting price of $30,280. The second-best news is that it's going to get 18 percent better fuel economy on the highway than the outgoing Rogue, with a 33-mpg highway mileage figure that's very user-friendly. (Nissan says it expects to lead the class when the official numbers are posted.) And the third-best news is that the Rogue is built on a new common platform from the Renault-Nissan Alliance that will be the basis of up to 2.3 million vehicles worldwide (including the European version of the Rogue, the X-Trail). Plus, the new Rogue, formerly assembled in Japan, now will be built right here in the U.S.A.: Smyrna, Tennessee.

All of those bits of nice information almost (but not quite) cancel out the fact that Nissan Americas' vice-president for product planning,  Pierre Loing, called the Rogue's design a "sonic pulse." That's just weird. Everybody knows that Nissan has a fearless aesthetic: take a look at the Juke or the Quest sometime. And, to be sure, the Rogue's body, especially on the sides, has an aliveness to it that you don't see in a lot of small crossovers. But I would call it something prettier than "sonic pulse." Harmonious, maybe. Or just "good-looking."

So, if you're shopping for a small crossover, you could feel comfortable with the new Rogue looks-wise. More good news is that the completely redesigned 2014 Rogue has wider-opening doors, which is good news for people toting car seats. The new Rogue benefits from a slightly longer wheelbase, wider body, and taller overall height.

The front seats have an optional Quick Comfort seat heater, which does just what you'll be hoping it does on frosty mornings. Among the other options are LED headlights, a power liftgate, and a huge panoramic power-operated moonroof.

Looking at the body leads to the next bit of good news: There's an optional third row of seating. Now, it's really just occasional seating for kids, but it does make this smallish crossover into a seven-passenger vehicle in a pinch. Nissan marketing manager Scott Shirley said the company expects a lot of interest from customers who are moving up from a small car or moving down from a minivan, and the third row option is a value-added proposition for either of those groups. I had a good look at the new Rogue at its official rollout at Nissan Technical Center North America in suburban Detroit. Let's just say I would not want to go on a long drive sitting in the third row. But if I had two kids who sometimes wanted to bring friends along, it would be excellent for that. Plus: check out those adorable tall, skinny headrests the third row has! Love 'em.

Nissan is bringing out the new Rogue with a bang, setting up a microsite to take inquiries and pre-orders. The automaker is offering the new crossover at a bargain lease price of $239 a month over thirty-six months, with a $2,599 initial payment. This price is for a mid-grade all-wheel-drive version, not the base model. Those who reserve a Rogue through the microsite by November 12 will be eligible for a $250 gift card as a bonus.

Scott Shirley had the best line of the morning. He clarified that the optional third row is available on the base S and midlevel SV models only. What about the third-row needs of buyers of the top-of-the-line Rogue SL? "Get a Pathfinder," he said.

pageElements.text: At Jean Knows Cars, we’re big fans of manual transmissions, and we think everybody should learn to drive stick shift, but we’re willing to admit that for drivers who frequently navigate in heavy traffic, driving a stick can turn into a chore. It’s always been a choice that shifting enthusiasts are faced with: drive an automatic so you don’t spend half your driving life with your foot hovering over the clutch pedal, or stick with the stick and accept sore shins as part of the bargain.

If automotive parts supplier Bosch has its way, though, this decision could soon become a thing of the past. Bosch has developed a technology it calls the eClutch, which allows drivers to shift into first gear without using the clutch pedal. Essentially, this means that a car equipped with eClutch could be driven like an automatic, using only the brake and gas pedals, in stop-and-go traffic.

The Art of Shifting into First

Drivers will still need to use the clutch to shift into second and higher gears, but Bosch believes the eClutch can “close the gap” between driving a manual and an automatic. Practically anyone who’s learned (or tried to learn) how to drive a stick shift will agree that mastering the art of shifting into first gear from a standing stop is the toughest part of the process. Even for shifts into higher gears, the system will help ensure smooth gear changes by automatically adjusting engine speed when it detects that the driver is changing gears.

Coasting to Improve MPG

The eClutch could also result in significant fuel economy savings in equipped cars, thanks to a coasting function that decouples the engine from the clutch when the driver stops accelerating, allowing the car to coast and resulting in what Bosch says could be up to a ten percent saving in fuel economy.

Any Takers?

Looking back on my own experience learning to drive a manual transmission, I can’t help thinking that the whole process would have been much smoother if the car could have shifted into first gear for me. Could this be the magic bullet for reluctant learners? Bosch hasn’t said whether it’s found a customer for eClutch, but if anyone’s asking us, we’re all for it!

pageElements.text: Forget about all the Hallmark holidays, National Cheese Weeks, and American Dental Floss Days. There’s one nationally announced occasion that all parents should take seriously: It’s Child Passenger Safety Week, which this year starts on September 15.

Did you know that child safety seats saved the lives of 8,616 children aged four and under between 1975 and 2011? Or that, if you put your child into the appropriate child safety seat, you are cutting an infant’s likelihood of being killed in a car crash by 71 percent? (It’s 54 percent for toddlers.) NHTSA, which collects that data, states the obvious in saying, “Car seats work best when used correctly.”

Of course, you have every intention of strapping in your child correctly. But “correctly” also means that your child is in the right seat at the right age. Here is the rundown on that, and below is the latest infographic from NHTSA, to ensure you are up to date on the regulations and recommendations.

You probably know that putting your child’s safety seat into the car is more than just tossing it in the back seat and loosely fastening the seatbelt around it. But did you realize that, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), fully 20 percent don't even read the directions before installing it? And beyond that, parents make five classic errors when installing the seat that can lead to unsafe riding: using the wrong slot for the harness straps; positioning the chest clip too low or too high; letting the straps be too loose; not attaching the seat to the car tightly enough; and attaching the car's seatbelt in the wrong way. It sounds complicated, and that's why there's help out there.

If you are a parent, or if you ever transport other people’s kids in the car, you need to celebrate National Seat Check Saturday (September 21). This is a day when you can quickly and easily get a trained Child Passenger Safety Technician to look at your child’s car seat in your car. If any fixes need to be made, they’ll do them, and it’s free. Find a child seat inspection station here. If one isn't listed near you, go here and let Safe Kids Worldwide help you find a technician.
We made a video of technicians at work. Watch the great work these people are doing! Why wouldn’t you put these trained helpers to work to keep your kids safer?

Diminutive electric vehicle with two seats and a roomy trunk seeks companion. Does not like to travel more than 68 miles at one time, and needs to rest for long periods between trips. This quick and agile driver with a petite frame requires only a tiny parking space. Addicted to electric current. Interested parties must appreciate a unique personality, and not mind if others openly laugh. If you prefer going topless, I can send my twin.


This is the personal ad that the Smart Electric Drive would place in the local paper seeking a mate. The number of potential suitors is very slim. But the microcar-curious, EV-questioning shopper should at least meet over coffee.

If you have not laid eyes on the Smart, look closely at the accompanying video of our fit friends from Applied Fitness Solutions to really take in its size. It is tiny with a capital T and that rhymes with P and that stands for puny. And that, my friend, is the very first obstacle that you must get over before you can consider the Smart Electric Drive. If only having room for one passenger doesn’t send you packing and your only concern is the safety aspect of piloting a small car, you may like what you read.

Obstacle Number One: Safety

The engineering behind Electric Drive comes from the engineers at Mercedes-Benz. So this coupe boasts eight airbags, a crash management system, and stability control. The passenger compartment is a steel safety cell that can withstand 9,000 pounds of force. In recently published crash test results on the 2013 Smart, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave the Electric Drive four out of five stars in front crash and rollover testing, and five stars out of five in side crash testing. This honestly shocked me because I would have thought a side impact test would have been the Electric Drive’s Achilles' heel. The cabrio has not been tested, and it does come with two fewer airbags.

Obstacle Number Two: Range

If you need to drive more than sixty-eight miles in a day, you can stop right here. Seriously, sixty-eight miles is the best-case scenario, and charging is slow. I know that when my iPhone’s battery is drained to zero, it frustrates me to wait the five minutes until I can make a call. The Electric Drive can be charged from any household socket but may require as much as fourteen hours to go from a zero charge to a full charge. A 240-volt Bosch Keba charging station will do the charging job in six hours. It's sold separately, by Bosch Service Solutions, and costs $1,322 plus installation, but your local utility company may offer incentives that will pay for some or all of that cost.

Obstacle Number Three: Price

The pricing structure is a bit confusing because of tax incentives and a battery assurance program, but the Electric Drive is priced to move. The Electric Drive coupe is priced starting at $25,750, and the cabriolet starts at $28,750, including destination. Subtract from that a federal tax credit of up to $7,500.

Alternatively, in a program heavily promoted by the Smart people, you can purchase the coupe for $20,740 or the cabriolet for $23,740 and rent the lithium-ion battery for $80 per month. This is called the Battery Assurance Plus program. It guarantees you a battery with a capacity of at least 80 percent and includes an annual battery checkup.

But it's leasing that really caught my attention. Smart's thirty-six-month Electric Drive lease packages are geared for penny pinchers. The coupe is $139 per month and the cabriolet $199; they both include Battery Assurance Plus.

Obstacle Number Four: Driving Experience

The combination of rear-wheel drive and a short wheelbase makes the driving experience actually fun. The added weight of the battery, and its location under the seats rather than too far fore or aft, helps stabilize this little whip. The cornering is tight, and seriously you can’t beat the turning radius. The acceleration is peppy, the top speed is 78 mph, and the 11.5-second 0-to-60-mph time would make the Lollipop Guild drop their lollipops. The handling is nimble, but because of the short wheelbase the ride can be a bit jarring. I was also concerned that it could really be dangerous to hit a large pothole. Assuming the Electric Drive will spend most of its life on city streets, the driving experience should meet most buyers' needs. But it can handle being with the big boys on the highway as well.

Obstacle Number Five: Availability

If you are still on board, you may have to wait for the opportunity to own this Smart. It is currently only available in states that have a zero-emissions-vehicle mandate (California, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, and Rhode Island). However, it is slated to be widely available this winter. So start picking out your colors and options now.

The Verdict:

I would personally recommend the Smart Electric Drive to anyone willing to leap the objections I have outlined. The price is unbelievably enticing for anyone who mostly rides alone and has very short commutes. I would personally lean toward the cabrio version and live dangerously with two fewer airbags. The time I spent in the Electric Drive took me back to the way I felt when I first drove a golf cart. It was my first experience at the wheel, and I loved driving it as fast as possible, but this version is a lot faster and much safer.

The Peanut Gallery:

Annie: The Smart Electric is definitely not the car for me—I enjoy spontaneous road trips and functional cargo space—but I was surprised at how much I liked this tiny city car. The convertible top made it feel more like an indulgence and less like a penalty box, and the electric motor's instant torque means accelerating off stoplights can be fun. Plus, I can't help but like that the Smart is small enough to park lengthwise in a parallel parking space. The real reason I wouldn't buy one: caught some fellow drivers openly laughing at me and my tiny car as I waited to make a left turn. Not the reaction I usually look for.

Laura: I like the fact that cars like this exist. To cruise around a limited area in town, it's so much more suitable than a big SUV. If I lived in a small European town or a really small American village, I might find the low cost of the Smart Electric Drive irresistible. Once you are seated in the comfortable front seats, you can easily psych yourself out to forget that you're driving a vehicle with no back to it. But what I couldn't forget is how limiting the driving range is. The appearance wouldn't bother me; even the smallness wouldn't bother me much. It's the range anxiety that would be the deal breaker for me.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: As great as electric vehicles seem in theory—no carbon emissions, no more trips to the fuel pump, instant torque—there are still a lot of obstacles to becoming a real-life EV owner. Even if you can get past the range anxiety and the long charging times, there’s the fact that buying an EV often means buying a brand-new car, since they’re such recent additions to the marketplace. And that is a major financial decision for most buyers.
Thanks to a new Certified Pre-Owned program from Nissan, though, finding a used EV just got a little easier.

Starting this month, Nissan will begin offering its all-electric Leaf in the Certified Pre-Owned program, meaning that buyers will be able to purchase used Leafs that meet Nissan’s requirements for CPO vehicles.

In the case of the Leaf, that means that it will have less than 60,000 miles, be less than five years from its original in-service date, pass a Carfax vehicle history check, pass a 167-point inspection, and—perhaps most interesting to used-EV shoppers—have at least nine bars of battery capacity. (Leafs start their lives with twelve bars of battery life, but battery capacity depreciates over time.)

Buying a CPO Leaf still won’t be the quite the same as buying one new, though. That minimum battery capacity of nine bars translates to just 75 percent of the battery’s original capacity. With an already limited driving range of seventy-five miles, any lost driving range could be a problem. But with Nissan’s eight-year/100,000-mile battery warranty, each CPO Leaf that finds a new owner will have at least three years and 40,000 miles of coverage left.

Buyers who choose a CPO Leaf will also get twenty-four-hour emergency roadside assistance, a three-month satellite radio trial, car rental reimbursement, and other perks. Nissan will also extend the powertrain warranty from five years/60,000 miles to seven years/100,000 miles for CPO Leafs.
As an added incentive for used-EV buyers, Nissan will offer 0.9 percent financing for thirty-six months to qualified buyers.

Nissan’s director of electric vehicle sales, Erik Gottfried, said in a statement that as Nissan has seen growing numbers of used Leafs enter the market, the automaker decided to add the car to Nissan’s CPO program to “provide second owners the same confidence in the car that the original owner enjoyed.”

pageElements.text: As the technology front moves inexorably toward the car that drives itself, like it or not—and I’m not sure—it’s good to know that some of the most forward-looking car companies are rolling out more and more technology to make us really safer in the car, while still letting us (mostly) be the overall brain in control. And Mercedes-Benz is determined to keep going in the effort to make its cars all-knowing and all-protecting. The German automaker took an S500 Intelligent Drive research car out on the road in August, following the same route Bertha Benz took on the world's first road trip 125 years ago. The intent was "to demonstrate the feasibility of autonomous driving on both interurban and urban routes." It worked, and Mercedes hastened to note that the technology it used was very similar to what you can buy on current production models.

For 2014, in fact, the automaker has a suite of more than thirty active and passive safety technologies on tap, which it’s calling Intelligent Drive. Basically, it involves sensors and cameras to maintain a 360-degree continuous view of the road around you. It can keep you alert, in your lane, without smashing into anyone or having them smash into you.

The Mercedes-Benz Driver Assistance package is a $2,800 option now available for the 2014 E-Class lineup (right) and for the 2014 S-Class, rolling out in October. This is a package of five main safety technologies. Central to its diabolical plan to keep you from crashing: a set of stereoscopic cameras that see 1,600 feet in front of the car at all times, “sensing” traffic patterns. There’s also short, medium, and long-range radar going on. It reads the road's profile seventeen times per second, gauging whether there’s something to react to. And there almost always will be. For example:

• Bends in the road (Distronic Plus with Steering Assist, a radar-based cruise control system that “intervenes” with steering to maintain just the amount of torque you need on straight roads or bends);
• Somebody crashing into you from behind (Pre-Safe Plus, rear-facing radar that prepares the vehicle for a “possible secondary incident into an active intersection." Translation: they smash into you, and then you smash into someone else);
• You crashing into someone else from behind—or hitting a pedestrian (Pre-Safe Brake, automatically putting on your brakes at up to 31 mph, to supplement or take the place of your own braking efforts);
• Intersection imbroglios (BAS Plus with Cross Traffic Assist, using those stereoscopic cameras and rear-facing radar to detect something bad about to happen in an intersection you’re entering and adding “appropriate brake assistance” in case you don’t brake enough);
• Straying outside your lane (Active Lane Keeping Assist that signals you with a vibrating steering wheel);
• Missing a car coming up in your blind spot (Active Blind Spot Protection that does “one-sided braking” when needed).

The 2014 Mercedes-Benz E-Class lineup starts at $53,750, including a $925 destination charge, for the E350 sedan. The 2014 S-Class starts at $93,825, including destination, for the S550. (The top-end 2014 S63 AMG 4Matic is pictured here; it comes out in November, priced at $140,425, including destination.) These aren't prices to allow you to buy these cars for your teenager or college student, but it's a safe bet that intelligent safety systems will continue to trickle down and become more affordable.

And Mercedes-Benz isn't stopping there with the advanced technology: There's also Night View Assist Plus, Attention Assist (the nagging cup of coffee that really does know when you’re too tired and need a break), and even Traffic Sign Assist with a wrong-way warning function. This technology is either begging for a parody from The Onion or "Saturday Night Live," or it deserves a Nobel Prize. Or maybe both.

pageElements.text: Can you believe it? Honda has upped the ante on its generosity toward the American drive-in movie theater. Having already saved five drive-ins by ponying up the more than $75,000 cost of transitioning each theater to digital projection, Honda just announced it will save four more. Considering there are only 357 drive-in theaters left, this ought to make a substantial dent in the closure rate of these American classics.
The four added winners are going to be named on September 23. What are you waiting for? Go to Project Drive-In right now and vote for one of the 116 theaters on that list!

Here's the Back Story

Honda announced its Project Drive-In on August 9. Its aim: to help a few theaters survive after film distributors phase out 35-mm film at the end of this year. Why did Honda do this? Jean asked John Mendel, executive vice-president of automobile sales for American Honda. Here's what he said: ""Drive-In theaters are a unique element of America's car culture and they play heavily in many of our fondest memories." Can't argue with that!

An impressive 121 drive-ins participated in the program, which asked people to vote electronically for their favorite theaters. I promptly loaded up my family to see if the drive-in still has a place in modern society or if perhaps it was time to let them fade away. It was such a great night that I hopped on the soapbox to help save as many theaters as possible. I was especially pulling for the Cherry Bowl in Honor, Michigan (near Traverse City in the northern Lower Peninsula).

For five days in a row, starting on Monday, September 9, Honda announced the five winners. The first winner was the Saco Drive-In in Saco, Maine. I was happy for the lobster-loving Mainelanders, but I was worried for my sweet Cherry Bowl. When on day two Honda announced that the Cherry Bowl had won the second projector, I felt like northern Michigan had really dodged a bullet. The week rolled on with Christmas in September for the 99W in Newberg, Oregon; the Graham in Graham, Texas; and the McHenry in McHenry, Illinois.

We were inspired by the millions of Americans voting to save their local drive-ins and
decided to help even more communities.

All the winners get to show the new movie Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2, ahead of its nationwide opening on September 27, as part of what will surely be a heartfelt community celebration at every theater on that list.

Mendel explained why four more winners are about to be named: "We were inspired by the millions of Americans voting to save their local drive-in theaters and decided to help even more communities ensure that future generations can
enjoy this unique experience."

So thanks, Honda. We haven’t thought about drive-ins much in recent years, and you put them back in the forefront of our minds. You can bet we’ll be spending a few choice evenings up at the Cherry Bowl next summer!

title: Strap In Those Kids
promoTeaserSmall: Do you ever (just this once) let kids ride unsecured? GM-backed study says it's shockingly common.
promoTeaser: Do you ever (just this once) let kids ride unsecured? GM-backed study says it's shockingly common.
metaDescription: Strap In Those Kids - A new study by Safe Kids Worldwide, backed by the General Motors Foundation, says an alarming number of parents think it's okay to let their children ride in cars unsecured sometimes. Read about it and check out a checklist for car seat safety. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I remember it like it was yesterday. One bright, sunny afternoon, I lifted up my one-year-old baby boy, the joy of my life, and lovingly, carefully strapped him in to the car seat in the back seat of the test car that I was driving that day. I paused for a moment to kiss his round, pink cheeks. Then I got in the driver’s seat and drove out of the parking lot. It was only moments until I rounded the first bend and noticed, out of the corner of my eye, that the car seat had slalomed over to the other side of the back seat. Horror! I had done everything right—except remember to strap the car seat in to the car.
Fortunately, that baby boy was fine (he’s twenty now), and I never did that again.

But apparently, I am not the only one to have made that mistake. A newly released report says one in four parents has driven without making sure that baby and child passengers are strapped in properly or even in a safety seat at all.

It’s even more alarming to know that the parents admitted this to the wonderful organization Safe Kids Worldwide, which takes it upon itself to ensure car-seat safety. The General Motors Foundation underwrote the study, in which Safe Kids Worldwide surveyed 1,002 parents and caregivers of children aged ten and under.

The study actually found that the more education and financial resources a parent has, the more likely he or she is to make an exception and let a child ride improperly secured. It also found that young parents and men are more likely than older parents and women to do so.
Listen to GM executive Mike Robinson, a GM Foundation board member, when he says, “Exceptions can lead to tragedies.”

What are the reasons parents make “exceptions”? The study gave a few examples: how about if you are only going a short distance? Twenty-one percent of parents said going unrestrained was OK for kids on short trips—but 60 percent of accidents involving children happen within ten minutes of the child’s home. And how about this statistic: 34 percent of parents with household incomes over $100,000 were okay with unrestrained children on short trips. Only 15 percent of parents with household incomes under $35,000 thought so. And parents with graduate degrees are twice as willing to travel with unsecured children than parents with only a high-school education.

How about if the child will be in the car overnight? Nearly a quarter of the parents under thirty felt it would be acceptable, and thirteen percent of older parents said it was okay—but children are most likely to be injured in an accident during nighttime hours.

Other reasons people offered for leaving children at risk in the car: if there was no booster or child safety seat on hand, if someone was holding the child on a lap, or—my favorite—as a “reward.” I don't care what socio-economic group you come from; this is just plain wrong.

It’s National Child Passenger Safety Week (through September 21), so let’s all look our kids in the eye, kiss their rosy little cheeks—and make absolutely sure they are strapped in securely and safely whenever we take them out in the car. Here's the Safe Kids checklist to help you make sure you're doing it right.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. pageElements.text:
Ann Arbor’s summertime cool-car fest.

From the October 2004 issue of Automobile Magazine.

One Friday in early July, the hippy-dippy city of Ann Arbor closes about ten blocks of downtown at noon, fills the streets with cool cars, and has a neighborhood car show till it gets dark at ten. Rolling Sculpture is no concours d’elegance, mind you. No blower Bentleys or Ferrari GTOs or Hispano-Suizas or Auburn boattail speedsters. More like lots of Mustangs, old GTOs and Chargers, and an Olds Vista Cruiser or two. And not all of the “sculptures” are old or historically important. But just the fact that the Earth Shoe capital of the world, home of the five-dollar pot fine and the Weather Underground, has a car show downtown is cool in itself.

We love it and are avid participants, roping off the half-block of East Liberty in front of Automobile Magazine for the family fleet. Our cool metal was somewhat blocked from view this year by the City of Ann Arbor’s new, not so cool-looking alternative-fuel garbage truck which was butted up to technical editor Don Sherman’s spectacular 1967 Corvette. But never mind. By six, the streets were jammed, and we had plenty of lookers. Sherman had brought along two friends to create a sort of Corvette corral, and we also had the gorgeously restored white 1957 Mercedes-Benz 190SL roadster belonging to Craig Layson, whose ownership of Stony Creek Collision, a spectacular body shop, makes him almost a member of the Automobile Magazine family. Ahem.

But never mind those Corvettes. Forget the M-B roadster. Could there have been a cooler car at the show than the Jennings family Fiat 500, parked daintily amid the big-block Chevys? Not on our block there wasn’t. Children flocked around it, pointing and pressing runny little noses against the glass. Old ladies pointed. Foreign visitors nodded and told stories about learning to drive in one. Even Elvis paid his respects.
I like that about the Fiat, and I let kids get in and check it out, much to the horror of my husband. Start them young, I say.

The Fiat is really Tim’s car, a present from me to him on his forty-ninth birthday. We keep it under a tarp in the barn all winter, then air it out in the spring and put it in service to show kids and old aunts and moms the trails through 100 acres of woods around our northern Michigan house. It’s faster and much more stylish than a golf cart.

This year, we hauled the Fiat down from north-woods tour-bus duty and washed it, and I was determined to enjoy driving it fifty miles to town. It went to town, all right. The very next one, eight miles away, before it lost forward motion. Luckily, I couldn’t convince an overnight guest that I was safe driving it alone, that my car was a solid little champ. She was right behind me in a sensible Toyota Sienna minivan when it crapped out. She swept me up from the side of the road, leaving the Fiat forlornly shouldered.

This had happened before to my husband, and I knew it was an easy fix. I just couldn’t remember what that fix was: a simple poking of the throttle linkage back into place. I called the husband away from his appointed rounds, and we went together to sort it out. It was so late by the time we arrived at the Fiat and popped its throttle back into place that we decided to trailer it the rest of the way. I proudly drove the Fiat exactly seven blocks from the trailer to its appointed curb. I was two hours late, but at least I was rolling under my own steam this year.

What is it about this event that causes our cars to crap out? Last year, Layson had buffed up my BMW 3.0CSi, fresh from its mechanical recovery, chronicled ad nauseam in these pages. Somewhere between his Ypsilanti shop and downtown Ann Arbor, out on the interstate, the beautiful blue BMW’s brakes seized up. Layson loaded it on a flatbed, trundled downtown to the car show, and rolled the BMW off into place. (Every old-car owner needs a friend with a flatbed.) The brakes released themselves sometime before the show ended but seized again on the way home. A new master cylinder made a significant difference.

The quirks of cool old cars take some getting used to, but in the case of the BMW (which now has an electrical gremlin), the situation could possibly be helped with regular driving. In the case of the Fiat 500, though, a big wad of gum on the end of that throttle linkage just might be all the fix it needs for a while.

When this year’s show was over, my husband and I jumped into the teensy Fiat and snuck down an alley leading to our car trailer. Tim was driving when, suddenly, we lost all forward motion. I jumped out, ran around to the back, and threw open the engine cover. A small crowd gathered on the sidewalk to watch. I plunged my hand in, grabbed the dangling throttle linkage, and popped it into place. “Try that!” I shouted. It was just like magic, and the crowd was suitably dazzled as he drove off. Ooh, aah. The lady fixed the car. I’m such a faker. If only I’d had a handy wad of gum to add to the show.

We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. pageElements.text: I was dead set against selling our 1970 Fiat 500L, a special car I famously bought for my husband’s fiftieth birthday. I say “famously” because regular readers of my Vile Gossip column in Automobile Magazine might remember that it starred in two, and because it actually wasn’t my husband’s fiftieth but his forty-ninth birthday. My bad math.
“I can’t wait to see what you’re getting me for my fiftieth!” he gleefully exclaimed.

Italian car lover and friend Dr. Raymond Boniface (father of Bob, the GM car designer) found this perfect specimen for my gift right from the motherland (complete with its original front plate with the faint MO following the license number, indicating it had been registered in Modena, Italy), and I loved it dearly. But after eleven years, it became clear that it was not getting the exercise it deserved because we live on a farm. Every time we took the Fiat out for air…oh, wait. We never took it out. It had room for one of us and a dog, but not both of us or two dogs. And whenever that dog was Louie, she preferred to face the driver—leaning hard in—and make little woofs and rwowrrs in the driver’s right ear, no doubt a recitation of the injustices of the week that we’d visited on her.

Meanwhile, whenever I drove it, SUVs would pile up like a parade behind the spunky little Fiat. (Top speed downhill with a tailwind: 50 mph. Maybe.)  The first SUV driver in line would be laughing. The rest, who couldn’t see the tiny 500 holding up forward progress, would be honking madly. Consequently, most of the miles we racked up happened out in the fields and down the dirt lanes of our farm.

Considering that, I admit to having been shocked at just how perfectly the Fiat cleaned up in the hands of Stony Creek Collision of Ypsilanti, Michigan. In fact, I felt worse and worse as the auction date approached, although the RM people were sweethearts and made me feel quite special. They took gorgeous photos to go with the killer photos from Automobile Magazine’s A.J. Mueller for the coffee-table-book-quality catalog, and they promised I could drive it across the block. They called to walk me through the paperwork. It was too late for seller’s remorse, too late to turn back.

Owning a vintage car, especially one as iconic, joyous, and virtually trouble-free as our completely unrestored forty-three-year-old Fiat 500, is a special feeling of belonging, not necessarily to the elite club of Best in Show collectors, but to anyone who has smelled that old-car smell of leather and wool and sweat; who has felt the big old steering wheel (or, more likely, sawed away at that big old steering wheel) and heard the creaks and moans of old bones still willing to go for another ride at the end of a long day; who has thrilled at the first burst of life from an engine that is unencumbered by the EPA or NASA-level black box engineering but needs careful attention to plug and point gaps, fiddly carburetors, and the right magic combo of choke, accelerator, and ignition. Selling that car? You feel like a traitor.

And the day arrived. Actually, first came the viewing cocktail party. I spent the entire evening hovering protectively around the Fiat while everyone I knew who knew I’d be there came to call. A tiny bit of that evening’s and the following morning’s raucousness were captured in this video.

I was adopted on the morning of the auction by one of the guys hired by people selling cars around me to professionally detail their cars. Every time he went by, he’d work on the Fiat’s windshield. Buff some chrome. Flick off some leaves under the hood. We were serenaded, the Fiat and I, by the irrepressible Donald Osborne, a car collector, car show judge, appraiser, journalist, and retired opera singer who worked for the Metropolitan Opera. In Italian. Swoon.

I brought my best Jasmin Zorlu fish-leather-and-pheasant-feather hat, one I was sure would make the correct statement, sticking jauntily out of the top, once I folded back the Fiat’s vinyl roof. All I had to do was turn the ignition key, reach to the little inner lever on the floor at my right and pull it up halfway to open the choke a bit, and then pull up on the outer of the two floor levers (with foot off the gas) until it fired up. I would then drive it up the ramp and into the building as RM’s color commentator Alain Squindo revved up the crowd. I would stop perfectly in the middle of the turntable, which would start revolving slowly clockwise, showing the Fiat’s perfection as auctioneer extraordinaire Max Girardo would whip the bidding into a froth. My imagination ran wild.

Just before I lit up our Fiat 500—a car we had never named, because I’m not really that kind of girl—just before I fired it up for the last time, two little blond kids, Georgie and Hally, ran up to it hollering, “Mommy! Mommy! It’s Luigi!” and threw their little arms over the hood. “Can we kiss Luigi, Mommy?” they asked.

Could I feel worse?

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Cadillac's Art and Science design philosophy now extends to the sounds you hear. The 2014 CTS has microphones placed inside the cabin to pick up engine noise, amplify it, and pump it back through the car’s Bose stereo system. The microphones, in concert with an electronic sound enhancement system, pick out the most “desirable” tones (as identified by a team of Cadillac engineers) and magnify them.

Cadillac has created three distinct engine soundtracks, tied to the CTS’s driving modes. In Touring mode, the artificially enhanced engine sounds will “purr with refinement” (or so says Cadillac). In Sport mode, the engine “growls with power.” In Track mode, only available in the 556-horsepower CTS VSport model, it “roars even more aggressively.” This is what Track mode sounds like from inside the car:

pageElements.text: The artificial sound idea has been done, notably by BMW in its M5. However, Cadillac is very careful to note that it’s not piping in a manufactured engine sound but is instead taking existing engine noise and curating it to match the desired characteristics of each drive mode.

If you love the sound of a Cadillac but can’t quite stomach the CTS’s $46,025 starting price, don’t despair. Enthusiasts can download the CTS Vsport’s Track mode bellowings as a ring tone, all the better to impress car nut friends.

metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Silverado 1500: I tried out the Z71 4WD LTZ Crew version of this all-new pickup, with one question in mind: Should you buy it? Find out what I thought (and what the Peanut Gallery had to say) on JeanKnowsCars.com.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging.
