pageElements.text:
Price: $49,590 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower, 383 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: EZ Lift-and-Lower tailgate door
Option I can’t live without: Chevrolet MyLink audio system with eight-inch diagonal color touchscreen and navigation ($795)
You might also be considering: Ford F-150, Nissan Titan, Ram 1500, Toyota Tundra

See more specs on the Chevrolet Silverado in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

In the full-size truck segment, there has long been an undisputed king. The Ford F-150 consistently and significantly outsells its competition. It is by far the bestselling vehicle in Ford’s lineup, and it’s the truck every other automaker hopes one day to dethrone. You can bet that’s what Chevrolet was aiming for when it completely redesigned the Silverado for 2014, and by the looks of it, it’s not a challenge the automaker took lightly.

This truck is all new for 2014, and you don’t have to look far to find major changes. The grille is bolder and boxier than previous models, commanding attention as soon as you see it. Steering, suspension, and brakes have all been tweaked to offer a better ride and improved handling. The available V-8 engine has best-in-class fuel economy and the best tow rating of any light-duty, gas-powered pickup truck. Chevrolet also threw in standard scheduled maintenance for two years or 24,000 miles.

We recently tested a 2014 Chevrolet Silverado 1500 Z71 4WD LTZ truck with a crew cab. This top-of-the-line truck is more than capable of spending a day on the farm, with a 5.3-liter, 355-horsepower V-8 engine, a 7,200-pound tow rating, and four-wheel drive—not to mention the Z71 off-road suspension. But the interior is so cushy that it’s difficult to imagine someone climbing into the driver’s seat with muddy boots or gloved hands.

Our Silverado had heated and cooled leather front bucket seats (a $650 option), an eight-inch touchscreen infotainment system (a $795 option), and a power sunroof (a $995 option), and it felt more like a luxury SUV than a workhorse. Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system features an easy-to-use iPad-like interface that won’t distract you from the road. The big touchscreen radio wasn’t the star of the center stack for me, though. The Silverado’s truly impressive array of power sources (two USB plugs and two 110-volt outlets) is what really got my attention. No more fights over the iPhone charger!

The Silverado’s back seat has plenty of space for adult-size passengers, and the redesigned rear doors are larger and open wider than on previous models, so it’s easier to get in and out. Also easier: loading the cargo bed. The Silverado has an EZ Lift-and-Lower tailgate that takes the brute strength requirement out of pickup ownership. Notched steps carved into the rear bumper give you a place to get a leg up when you’re reaching into the truck bed.

Getting a Silverado loaded with options like ours was will run you nearly fifty grand, but you can also get one for less than $30,000 if you’re willing to sacrifice the back row and the leather seats. The base 1WT model starts at $24,585, including destination, but springing for the 2WT model at $26,830, including destination, gets you a MyLink radio display and Bluetooth connectivity (worth it). The Silverado is available with a regular cab, a double cab, or an even more spacious crew cab. It’s also available with a short (5'8"), regular (6'6”), or long (8') cargo box. Base model Silverados come with a 4.3-liter, 285-horsepower V-6 engine, but LTZ models like ours come standard with a more powerful V-8 powerplant.

The Silverado is a very large piece of machinery, and it felt that way going down the road or trying to squeeze into one of Ann Arbor’s maddeningly tiny parking spaces. That’s not to say it felt sluggish—the Silverado was perfectly capable of passing on the highway—but it’s still a truck, and its large footprint will take some getting used to if you’re accustomed to something smaller.

The Verdict:

The Silverado is as comfortable as it is capable, and if you’re looking for a truck, it’s a standout contender. With highway fuel mileage of 22 mpg—thanks in part to cylinder deactivation that can turn the V-8 into a four-cylinder under light loads—it’s more efficient than much of its competition. The 2013 Ford F-150 with four-wheel drive and a V-8 engine makes just 16 mpg on the highway. Consumer Reports just named the Silverado its top pickup truck, beating out entrants from Ram and Ford thanks to that fuel-sipping engine and a luxurious interior. It may not be the best car for ferrying the kids around town, but if you’ve got some more demanding chores on your checklist, the Silverado could do the trick.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura: I love the practicality and do-anything versatility of this four-door Silverado. Every surface looks strong, powerful, and capable. It has every kind of plug, every kind of bin, every kind of opening to put every kind of thing inside. Over dirt roads, it looks and feels entirely comfortable and in its element. I wouldn't dare buy something this big and gas-inhaling unless I really needed it, but I kind of wish I really needed one of these.

Molly: Having just spent ten days in a Chevrolet Suburban, I was surprised to see the Silverado's interior. I thought they would be basically the same. However, with its recent redesign, the Silverado's instrument panel took a giant leap for mankind. As a Apple-phile, I am a sucker for a good clean interface, so I especially appreciated the eight-inch touchscreen. I instantly paired my phone and was off and running with tuning the radio. The buttons were designed so that they can be operated with gloves on, which would be a plus in Michigan. I also loved the easy-access plugs right in the center of the instrument panel.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: My story began in the winter with Part One, when I first started considering whether I could justify replacing my Honda Odyssey with a Fiat 500. It continued in Part Two, when I overcame envy of others driving Fiats and made my own shopping list. In Part Three, I started the test-driving experience. Then, in Part Four, I took delivery! And now, the epilogue.

Six hundred miles. Six hundred miles in one day, and I never left the state of Michigan.  Yet, in those 600 miles, I had my moment, that Fiat Nostalgia moment. It is that magical second in time where life seems to be a scene caught on a movie frame, the one that causes that look in many a Fiat driver’s eye.
I confess I never thought I would have that Fiat Moment, as I’ve always associated them with Europe. Imagine my surprise when it happened Up North in Michigan.
It started with a text and a completely impractical and somewhat preposterous teenage request: "How far is AGQ from here?"
By “here,” she meant Interlochen Center for the Arts. By “AGQ,” she meant Camp Al-Gon-Quian, the YMCA camp on Burt Lake.
"Two hours."
"I want to surprise Katherine."
"No. That would be two hours further north, then four hours south."
"I never said a proper goodbye to AGQ."
"I already have to drive four hours to get you. No."
"Please?"

There is something about a particular “please” that comes from a teenager. That “please” conveys a need that can’t quite be articulated, but a need that requires attention and parental respect of what seems like the silliest or most meaningless request.  My parental instinct went off; we needed to do this.

And why not? I reasoned. I had the day off, I had my new car, and Traverse City through Charlevoix up to Petoskey ranks as one of the loveliest of drives. I have experienced the imposing drama of crossing the Alps; I have traveled much of the length of the Maine coast in the early morning, as the fog lifts and the forests of pines give way to the costal romance of boats and buoys of harbor towns; I have driven at sunrise in the New Mexico desert, where the mesa becomes a warm glow of oranges and purples; I have felt the majestic isolation of Australia’s Great Ocean Road; and I have had the thrill of the Amalfi coast, where only the narrowest of roads and hairpin turns keep you from tumbling into the Mediterranean below.

Yet none compares to the coastal route between Traverse City and Petoskey, where the rugged terrain of northern Michigan juts into the flat, gray, imposing expanse of one of the Great Lakes. Perhaps it is because I am not native to Michigan, but even after more than a decade in the state, I am surprised and captivated by the muscular beauty and almost industrial power of the state’s northern landscape.

Perhaps it has something to do with being north of the 45th Parallel, so the horizon seems lower, the land closer to the sky, the vistas more powerful, as cerulean blue skies with long white clouds hover over apple orchards, only to give way to forests, then to craggy shoreline and the mass of Lake Michigan. The day was supposed to be beautiful and sunny. Why not? I could pick her up at Interlochen, drive to AGQ, stop by the cottage at Pickerel Lake to see her best friend, Rosie, and drive home to Ann Arbor.

I checked my plan with the dealership. I had, in the back of my head, automotive lore about needing to break in a car slowly, and, when I took delivery, my Cinquecento had only fourteen miles on it. Since the drive I had planned was a combination of highway and country roads, it could only help ease the engine in. My saleswoman, Corky, advised me to drive around town enough to reach 100 miles on the odometer before departing.
“I hope you love it,” she said as she signed off.
I had to make up a few extra errands that weekend, but that Monday morning at 6:00 a.m., the odometer said ninety-eight miles, and I hopped in for my first road trip.

The radio with its fifteen presets and the bonus of SiriusXM, with its unlimited music capacity, kept me company, and learning the information displays helped the time pass rapidly. Not only can you track the progress of the whole trip using Trip A and of each leg with Trip B, but if you’re feeling international as well, you can set the language in French, Spanish, German, Portuguese, or Italian.  Within Trip A and Trip B, you can see your range: how many miles left on the tank of gas. A useful tool, for I have been known in my driving to try to be über-efficient—I won’t detour now, my next errand will take me by the station—only to end up stranded in the neighborhood, or worse, on the highway. Oops. So much for efficiency.

You can also follow your gas mileage, which has become my new delightful obsession. The display provides instant gas mileage or average mpg. If I’m having a bad day, nothing cheers me up more than to see my average gas mileage around 35 mpg and think of the money I’m saving. That savings went into consideration when I agreed to this giro, as the Italians call it. Had I been in the Honda Odyssey, the gas cost alone would have made it prohibitive.

Getting gas into the car, however, proved to be a bit of a trick. As I pulled in to the gas station off M-10, onto the two-lane road that leads from Clare to Cadillac, I realized that I didn’t know where the button was to pop open the gas tank. I searched high and low. No luck. I pulled out the abbreviated owner’s manual (the longer version now comes on CD). Apparently, most people must intuitively know how to open their gas tanks, because neither “gas” “gas tank,” nor “fuel” merit entry in the index. It was fifteen minutes of befuddlement, with a running monologue to myself: You have a Ph.D., and you can’t figure out how to open the f-ing gas tank to put fuel in your new Fiat?!?! I should have gone to law school. As if law school would have had a special class on gas-tank-opening litigation.

I must have skimmed most of the owner’s manual before I found the secret page, only to discover that there is no button. One simply pulls the tank door open. Got it. The lever or button must be a Honda thing.

Feeling a little blonde, I headed north on M-115, and I spent the next hour and a half getting to know Sophia. Sophia is the hands-free genie of the 500. I like to think of her as a well-educated but slightly testy Italian aunt who doesn’t always understand the nuances of the English language.  "Call Sarah McCurrach [pronounced Mc-Cur-a].”  Sophia responds: “Do.you.wish.to.call.Sarah.Mac-CUR-Wratch.on.cell?” It makes me laugh every time.  Fair to say that Sophia and I do not always understand each other.  I suppose if I consulted the owner’s manual about more than the location of the fuel tank button, Sophia and I could avoid having to go to counseling to reconcile our differences.  Like all good friendships, we’re going to need a little time to learn each other’s quirks.

As one of the main arteries to the towns and lakes "up north," M-115 gets its fair share of holiday and recreational travelers in the summer: SUVs with Yamaha boxes on top and laden with bikes on the back, pickup trucks with Jet Skis, and plenty of RV and truck traffic. The road is one of significant hills and dales, which makes for interesting traffic, as the more laden vehicles struggle to make it up the steep inclines. It is well designed, however, with lots of passing opportunities.

The Fiat 500 has a Sport button on the dash that provides a little extra jolt when you need a burst of power or if you need some extra zip in handling. Simply lift the foot off the accelerator for a moment, push the button, re-accelerate, and the power kicks in. It’s not exactly warp speed, but the difference is palpable and adds to the fun of driving such terrain.

On the final leg to Interlochen, a small country road with broad vistas of fields and farms, I noticed a number of minivans tooling ahead of me and reasoned correctly that they, too, were headed to camp pickup. Each summer, the Interlochen Center for the Arts, one of America’s cultural gems, hosts a Summer Arts Program in which teenagers from all over the globe give up typical summer activities and come together to dedicate themselves to six intense weeks of music school, complete with history and theory classes, hours of lessons and practice, master classes, and high expectations of performance. The daily schedule is rigorous, beginning at 6:45 a.m. reveille and calisthenics outside the rustic cabins next to Green Lake, and it goes straight through until cabin call at 9:00 p.m. To wander the campus is to hear a cacophonous blend of flute sonatas, piano concertos, vocal arias, and string quartets emanating from the practice studios, which really are huts set in the Michigan woods.

Interlochen alumni speak of their experiences as transcendent and life changing. Attend a performance, and one can see why. My Sarah, a soprano, had been awarded the role of the Countess in Marriage of Figaro, for the high-school Opera Scenes performance. A magical evening, the event presents vignettes from a variety of operas—Bizet’s Carmen, Gilbert and Sullivan’s The Mikado, Bernstein’s West Side Story, a condensed act two of The Marriage of Figaro, and Copland’s The Tender Land. The talent and dedication of these students is so powerful, so moving that, by the end of the show, there is not a dry eye in the house.

For all the unique character of the program, however, a six-week summer camp has its common issues of dirty laundry and lots of luggage, and the practical issue of transporting camper, materials, and, in the case of Interlochen, instrument. I noted with a bit of amusement as I parked that I had the only two-door car in the lot among a sea of minivans and SUVs.

As we walked to the car, Sarah, who had been looking for the Odyssey, squealed with delight.  "You brought the Fiat???" She had yet to see it. She quickly surveyed the scene of minivans surrounding my car, and her joy turned into a slight panic. “Is all my stuff going to fit??” Of course, with the back seats down.
“It’s a good thing I don’t play the cello,” she noted as she hopped in.

One can only imagine the flood of tears and range of emotions after such a summer; departure from Interlochen is emotionally wrought. Sarah’s first instinct was to plug my iPod into the sound system and play comfort music: the Italian soundtrack from Anastasia, a movie we must have watched 1,000 times when we lived in Italy. I noted to myself that the music quality was quite nice; the space of the 500 really didn’t require Beats Audio.

At first, she could barely speak, and the music of her childhood filled the car as she read her “train letters,” goodbye notes the campers all write to one another. The name harks back to the day all campers came and went by train; Interlochen traditions are nothing if not enduring. Bursts of laughter were followed by a quivering lower lip and a small stream of tears, and a snippet of a tale would be shared. This lasted an hour or so, and then we were well north of Traverse City. Anastasia finished, and in the quiet, she explained that her time at Interlochen had made her realize that vocal performance was what she wanted to do with her life, that her path was not going to be like that of her friends. It was a realization that needed processing, and I now understood the request to go home via Al-Gon-Quian. She needed closure, to say goodbye to one way of life as she fully embraced another. We needed more music.

On the second day of having my Fiat, my dearest friend, who is a treasure trove of musical knowledge, came by to program my radio. She knows me well enough to know that I might never find the time to play with SiriusXM, so she decided to take matters into her own hands. She showed me the features, and, as a slightly wicked jab at my love of classical music, programmed the Met Opera station as Station 1. Broadway went on Station 2, Frank Sinatra on 3, and Sirius U on 4.

I broke the silence. “Hey Sarah, let me show you SiriusXM. It’s pretty cool. Ellen programmed the Metropolitan Opera station for me.”  I tuned it in, and we heard the last few measures of some very familiar music.

“Was that Marriage of Figaro?” Sarah looked up, with striking clarity. “It’s the right key.” Of the thousands of recordings the Met station could be playing, we had tuned in just as it began Act Two—the act she performed—of a 1954 recording of The Marriage of Figaro. Surreal does not begin to describe it.

Sarah began to sing. She knew every note. Transported by the Italian and the moment, I began reminiscing about another memorable summer drive, following SS2 through the countryside of southern Tuscany, where olive groves give way to fields of sunflowers—girasole in Italian, which literally means “turn toward the sun.” They are my favorite flower, perhaps because of the vivid association with the Italian landscape. As if on cue, over the next crest, we were met by an expansive field of sunflowers on the right, glimpses of Grand Traverse Bay on the left, and blue sky and long, white puffy clouds above.

For that moment, the world seemed perfect and the future—my future, Sarah’s future—was full of hope and promise. The pain of the trials of the past three years was fading; a new life was beginning.  And somehow, this new promise was wrapped into my Fiat 500; it was all part of the magic of my Cinquecento.

I was contemplative on the last leg of our giro. We had had an emotional visit to Camp Al-Gon-Quian and a restorative, if not brief, stop at Pickerel Lake. Sarah was asleep next to me as I drove down I-75 to Ann Arbor. I thought back to Corky’s parting comment, “I hope you love it!” I did, but I wondered if the magic would endure, if my Fiat Moment would be a blip in time, if I would still feel this way going about the normal, prosaic tasks of daily life, a far cry from such a moving journey with my sixteen-year-old.

It is fair to say that, yes, the magic has endured. Perhaps it is in part due to the fact that the Fiat 500 is a less common, less well-known model. A “niche” vehicle, I’ve discovered, evokes a particular set of public responses, an element of Fiat ownership I completely did not anticipate.

First, there is the Fiat Wave. This took me a little while to learn. It is a tacit acknowledgment of camaraderie among Fiat 500 owners when passing each other on the road. No wild gesticulation allowed, but rather a subtle lifting of the fingers off the wheel and a nonchalant nod of the head.  Directions for this element of Fiat ownership are not found in the owner’s manual.

Then there is the routine questioning. It takes a little longer now to move about town. Not only do heads turn as I am driving down the streets of Ann Arbor, but strangers will stop me and ask, “What type of car is that?” The question is usually followed by interest in the gas mileage.   Acquaintances, on the other hand, if they have not seen me in a while, exclaim in delight, “Is that your car?!?!”  “It’s so…..” Fill in the blank: “Cool!” “Cute!” “Totally you!” “Gorgeous!” And then, always: “Do you love it?”

These are not, I note, reactions one ever receives driving a Honda Odyssey. Others who know about my 500 have remarked my movements about town, which might be due to the fact that I seem to have the only Luce Blu Lounge in Ann Arbor: “Hey, I saw you on West Liberty the other day around noon.” That element has become a little disconcerting, and I have surmised that were I to need to move about incognito, I’d have to take the minivan.

And then there are those with Fiat Lust. Fiat Lust, it turns out, afflicts more people than one would think. I parked my 500 at the pool one day to pop in quickly and grab a forgotten suit. As I walked out, I saw my car surrounded by two different couples I knew casually: “We are seriously considering getting one!  Do you love it? [Again, that question.] Is it practical?”

How does one define practical?  I could pick up one child from camp, but two with their gear would never fit. With expert packing, Saturday errands to Costco, Target, or Whole Foods are not an issue, although sometimes a large pack of paper towels joins the passenger in the back seat.   I’ve driven around the state; taken a trip to Point Pelee in Canada, where the odometer crossed 1,000 miles; and recommenced my commute to Detroit. All told, I've gone 1,445 miles, and I’ve only spent roughly $160 in gas, so, in terms of gas savings, the car is extremely practical.

In terms of mental health, too, the Fiat's practicality cannot be underestimated. Nothing soothes me more than to hop in my Cinquecento, feel the leather of the steering wheel, and experience the calm contrast of the creamy white and pale blue dash. It even worked on the day my ex-husband returned my two younger children to me after their ten-day holiday in Maine, and I immediately discovered they were infested with lice. By the time I had returned from the drugstore with treatment items, I was calm and no longer thinking murderous thoughts. If the Fiat 500 keeps me out of jail, it’s definitely practical.

Some Fiat Lust has an immediate solution: one “simply” has to be in a life position that makes it work. This is not the case for others with the affliction, particularly women for whom such a car represents a different phase of life. Sarah babysits for a couple with three young children aged eight, six, and three. The mother came to pick her up and saw my 500. She drives a new Odyssey. She stared at my Fiat longingly, with that look in her eye, and said, with that tone in her voice: “I told my children the other day that if I did not have to drive this minivan, that is the car I would be driving….right now, it’s just not practical.” I smiled. I have been there.

Last Sunday, I pulled into the drive of a dear couple, friends who have seen me through the firestorm of the last few years, for an impromptu late summer dinner on their new patio.  I drove behind their house and neatly parked my 500 in front of their garage.  I took my first drive in a Fiat 500 with the lovely and intuitive Meg; if anyone understands my connection with this car, they do.  They happen to be car people (well, he is), thus the garage contains a 2010 Audi A4 Avant and a 2004 Volkswagen R32.

I had parked my Honda Odyssey in that spot in the past, and it always looked out of place, a dented and dirty hulking behemoth awkwardly squeezed into pristine surroundings. It looked how I felt. We all noted the change, how nicely the Fiat fit in.
“Sooo,” Jim drolly intoned, “you finally made a commitment.”  Commitment, a word that still gives me pause.
“It’s only a three-year lease. Is that a commitment?”
He chuckled. “Well, for some relationships, three years is a long-term commitment…”

“Hmm, if we’re talking in terms of relationships, this is a far better commitment than any relationship I’ve been in. Look, my 500’s out there behaving with its friends, it doesn’t drink, you know where it’s going to be, it doesn’t lie, it’s dependable, reliable, honest, wonderful…." I was on a roll.  “I’ll take that commitment and my Cinquecento at this point, thank you very much!”
He laughed. “So this is a little more than just a car?” Sunday night psychotherapy.  “Do you love it?”
I got that look of Fiat Nostalgia in my eye, thought back to my Fiat Moment…yes, it is definitely a little more than “just a car.”

The sun had set, and the night was warm and still. We raised our glasses and said a toast to the past and to the future.  I have my children, my friends and, now, Fiat Love.  Life is good, and I am fortunate.  Here’s to the future, indeed.
Avanti!

pageElements.text: My mother always used to curse herself for not having invested in Microsoft when it first launched. Well, she's not the only one. You just don't always know what crazy-sounding startup is going to turn into the next, well, Microsoft.

image.altText: tesla model s going on autopilot

pageElements.text: So I have to ask: Are we in the presence of a new Thomas Edison in the person of Elon Musk? I ask that question now because the brash Tesla Motors leader has just Tweeted out the Help Wanted ad you see at the top of the page.

"Team will report directly to me." Meaning, Mr. Musk has just made self-driving cars or, as he calls them, "autopilot" cars, into a big priority. In fact, he has announced that he'll have a car out in three years that will drive itself 90 percent of the time. Should we be excited about this or a little freaked out?

He may be a PayPal mogul, but he's also earned a strong reputation as a car visionary. The Tesla Model S was the Automobile Magazine 2013 Automobile of the Year after all. Not just a succes d'estime, it's a seriously good performance sedan. With a 4.3-second 0-to-60-mph time, in fact. Jean said about the Model S: "It's the performance that won us over. The crazy speed builds silently and then pulls back the edges of your face. It had all of us endangering our licenses." Plus, an unheard-of 99/100 score from Consumer Reports?
And now, Musk is targeting an autonomous-driving Model S in three years? I have two questions.

1. Does this mean that the Tesla Motors goal of an "affordable" electric car is going on a back burner? If so, that seems like a loss for the 99 percent, or at least a slice of that 99 percent who would like to have some hope of affording a Tesla EV someday. (The Model S starts at $71,070, although a federal tax credit can cut that by $7,500.) Answering my own question here, I know that he has a lot of burners (and a lot of cash). After all, he's also obsessing over high-speed mass transit with his Hyperloop Alpha project, so maybe the affordable car will not get short shrift. I have to hope not.

2. If the really, really great thing about the Model S is how fun it is to drive, should anyone be thrilled that Elon Musk wants to make it drive itself 90 percent of the time very soon (and 100 percent at some future date)?

While you puzzle over these weighty questions, have a little fun with what is shaping up to be one of the legendary automotive innovator companies. Try this surprisingly difficult (won't even tell you my score) Tesla Motors Quiz from the Christian Science Monitor.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Some things we ran across on the way to finding what we were looking for. Go ahead, click on them and let these random items sidetrack you now.

1.

A seriously in-depth look at Fifty Years of the Porsche 911. I want the timetable for my wall.

2.

Automotive recalls these days are as common as twerking, but not as easy to spot. So the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, or NHTSA, has stepped in with a Free Search by VIN to see if your car needs a tweak.

3.

Automobile manufacturers' PR websites tend to be less than beautiful. Smartly, they have saved all of their creative juices for their consumer sites. I think I will order the Rolls-Royce Celestial Phantom. Meanwhile, you can enjoy this collection of design-driven sites.

4.

Photographer Jim Golden is based in Portland, Oregon, and he is a sucker for vintage cars. Well, so am I. The cars in his Auto Portraits may be past their prime, but they still look good to me. And, if you are either a hoarder or a historian, you may also like his Still Life work.

5.

Living to 100 is an accomplishment on its own, but Eiji Toyoda also did a few other things in his lifetime. He worked at Toyota from day one, and you can thank him for bringing the Corolla to the U.S. market in 1967. He also was at the helm for the 1989 introduction of Lexus. But just as important were his manufacturing methods and his contributions to the creation of the Toyota Production System that is widely used across manufacturing worldwide. Here's his New York Times obituary. Don't miss the look on his face in the photo. That's pride in a job well done.

6.

Okay, it has to be said. Grand Theft Auto V was released this week, to the general delight of gamers everywhere. Parents may have their qualms, as they should, but you’ve got to appreciate the sheer range of vehicles players can steal on their quest to amass ill-begotten riches. From supercars to passenger jets, this game will let you live out your stunt driving fantasies from the comfort of your own La-Z-Boy. Just make sure you mind the M for Mature rating.

7.

Infiniti and Gilt.com (a website that offers steep discounts on designer clothes) have teamed up with designers Zac Posen and Thom Browne to create two custom Infiniti Q50 sedans. The cars will be sold for $75,000 on December 12, following a three-month U.S. tour. Browne’s Q50 is entirely wrapped in chrome, while Posen’s wears an ombre paint coat that shifts from light matte gray to shiny dark gray as you move toward the rear. If money were no object, which would you drive?

8.

And, to close out our weekly list: I am in an exclusive relationship with my iPhone, but it doesn’t mean I can’t enjoy a trip down the lane of mobile phone history.

metaDescription: Rush: A Car Movie about People. Read my review of this new movie that focuses in tightly on two legends of Formula 1 racing. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: A new movie from director Ron Howard, the auto racing film Rush, is not just for people like me (and, probably, you) who love cars. It has one thing that you don't usually get enough of in a big-budget sports movie: character development. It also has an indie-movie feeling that makes it feel like much more than a traditional crash-and-smash car-chase blockbuster.

Don't get me wrong; over the years I have test-driven cars on racetracks and attended several races. In other words, I have smelled the oil and burning rubber, been jolted by the energy of the crowds, and heard the grind of the gears. I get it. But if you're not the type to be intoxicated by the world of racing, will this movie work for you? All I can report is that my friends who have seen the trailer are keen to see the movie, and I'm going to encourage them (and you) to go see it.

Rush turns its focus to a golden age of Formula 1 racing, the mid-1970s, in a landscape of disco and miniskirts, when the track scene was one big party. This is the compelling true story of the clash of two bigger-than-life superstar rivals, McLaren's James Hunt and Ferrari's Niki Lauda, competing to win the 1976 world championship. The tale has the advantage of being true; here's a photo of the two real-life stars on the track at Japan, the momentous last race of that championship season.

Screenwriter Peter Morgan has crafted a gripping, colorful and sensitive story that combines the leanness of a good documentary with the fantasy of film. Casual, handsome, fun-loving Brit James Hunt (Chris Hemsworth) is a perfect counterpoint on film, as he was in life, to the ultra-stern Austrian Niki Lauda (Daniel Brühl), an icy, calculating, efficient, and exacting gearhead.

The hedonistic Hunt drinks champagne, smokes grass, and sleeps with women before a race. Lauda plays the polar opposite, preparing for a race by going to bed early and staying on the straight and narrow. Yet that’s also where the sensitivity chip shows up, and there is a palpable amount of respect between the two athletes as the story unfolds.

The tension on the racetrack is equally tangible, but director Howard goes beyond the exterior shots of the action. Instead, the camera takes you into the cockpit and behind the helmets to focus intensely on the eyes of Hunt and Lauda. The sounds are guttural; the colors are brilliant; the crashes are explosive, and the director does not shy away from their violence. But this is not a movie punctuated by special effects. What you see in the film is very close to what you get on a track. The film's R rating will probably keep you from taking your car-crazy ten-year-old to the theater, but that's okay. I'm happy to report that, unlike so many movies these days, Rush is a very grown-up story about human striving and achievement.

title: Teen's First Car? Seven Must-Haves
promoTeaserSmall: My son wants a Mustang. I want to wrap him in bubble wrap. Here are some things that bridge the gap.
promoTeaser: My son wants a Mustang. I want to wrap him in bubble wrap. Here are some things that bridge the gap.
metaTitle: Teen's First Car? Seven Must-Haves - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Teen's First Car? Seven Must-Haves: I asked the experts about the essential considerations when shopping for the first car for my seventeen-year-old. Here's what I found out. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Lately, my son, Cole (17), has been pointing to muscle cars and saying, “That’s what I want.” Part of me, the mom of a little boy who loved Hot Wheels, would like to buy him one. But another part is terrified. I’m not overprotective. I believe kids need to take risks. But nothing in my history with this child has panicked me more than handing him the keys to a car. Cars aren’t toys. And driving—especially for teens—is dangerous.
Even if Cole never drinks, texts, or lets his mind wander while driving—which is hard to believe—he is still an inexperienced driver.

“At this stage of their lives,” agrees Sharon Basel, GM’s safety communication manager, herself the mother of two teens, “teens are at their highest risk for accident, injury, and even death.” In fact, car crashes are the leading cause of death for teens in the U.S., taking the lives of more than 5,000 of them every year. “Teens will get into crashes,” agrees John Ulczycki, vice-president of strategic initiatives at the National Safety Council and DriveItHome.org. “On average, half of all teens get into some sort of crash before they graduate high school.”

Despite my involuntary panic on the topic, I have agreed to help Cole buy a car by matching, dollar for dollar, whatever he saves toward one. I’m not just being a kind and generous parent, though. I plan to use my dollars to buy the safety features that won’t interest him at all. So while Cole is scanning Craigslist for convertible Ford Mustangs in his price range (of which there are—thankfully—none) and saving every dollar, I’m studying car safety.

A lot has changed since the last time I shopped for a car. I recently toured the technology built into a new Infiniti Q50. On that car, you can get a Technology package that includes Distance Control to make the car slow down if Cole drives too close to the car in front of him. It has Intelligent Brake Assist with Forward Collision Warning, so it will warn him if it senses danger ahead and, if he fails to respond to the warning, apply the brakes to reduce the severity of the crash. It will keep an eye on his blind spot and alert him to impending crashes—and, through its Blind Spot Intervention System, bring the car back into his lane if he is about to make a dangerous mistake. Which means that safety systems are number one on my list.

I want all of that technology keeping an eye on him and correcting his mistakes as he learns to drive. But a $40,000 luxury car for a teen’s first car? Out of the question. So how much safety can I buy without slipping into absurd helicopter parent territory? José Alberto Uclés of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration assures me I’m not likely to go overboard: “Safety should be a parent’s main concern when buying a car for a teen.” And he suggested I research any car Cole wants at Safercar.gov, which rates car safety by model with a star system. Forward collision warning systems, blind spot alerts, lane keeping assistance, and active technologies that brake or control the steering wheel when something is about to go terribly wrong are also on Ulczycki’s wish list for a teen car.
“They are absolutely good safety devices,” he says. “And I am optimistic we will have these features in more vehicles in the near future.” So let's make the list of must-haves, starting with that:

1. As much modern safety tech as we can afford. GM’s Sharon Basel says many warning systems—if not those that take active control of the vehicle—are available in affordable cars now. “There are cars at all price points equipped with forward collision sensing systems, lane departure warning, and blind zone alerts,” she says. “They have been out for a couple of years. So you might even find [these technologies] in a used car.” And if those are too expensive, there are simpler items, such as mirrors that amplify the blind spot, available in the aftermarket.

2. A big-enough car. Technology is not the only criterion. “Safety starts with the size of the vehicle,” says Ulczycki. “Bigger cars withstand impact better. Some small cars do withstand crashes well but I would not start a teen out in a compact or subcompact.”
3. The right amount of power. That muscle car Cole is shopping for? A bad idea. “Avoid horsepower,” says Ulczycki. “If he has a car that can go fast, he will probably drive it fast.”

4. A newer model. At the moment, Cole is driving our 1996 minivan. It’s big and gutless. So I wondered, would he be safer if I withdrew my offer to match his savings for a newer car? “Not when it comes to safety,” says Ulczycki. “Forty years ago, there wasn’t much difference in safety between old cars and new ones. But today, you have only to go back five years to find a huge difference.”

Okay. So I have to somehow convince my Hot Wheels shopping teen to buy something big, slow, and built within the past five years. And, while I’m at it, Ulczycki offered a sub-list of must-have features for that car:
5. Airbags for the driver and side curtain airbags for the passengers. “Even though teens aren’t supposed to carry passengers, they often do,” says Ulczycki. “So keep them safe, too.”

6. Electronic stability control. Kids swerve to pass a vehicle, take sharp turns around corners, and overcorrect. Electronic stability control helps minimize the loss of control. “I believe it prevents crashes and the seriousness of crashes,” he says.

7. A teen harassment system. “Teens don’t wear seatbelts,” he says. (Well, at least not all the time.) “So any device that encourages him to wear the seatbelt is good.” Ford’s MyKey system addresses this by refusing to play the radio until the seatbelt is fastened.
“Teens need to be annoyed into doing the right thing,” agrees Ulczycki.

That last feature is one that usually goes by the name of Mom. So that advice about teens needing to be harassed is one I will keep in mind while redirecting my son’s first-car wish list away from something that will bring his childish Hot Wheels games to life and toward one that will help him keep on living his own.

Is My Seventeen-Year-Old Ready for a Car? August 27, 2013

metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend? Here's my rundown on what I did and where I went (and in what). Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I could probably start every Monday with the sentence, “Never a dull moment!” Okay, that’s out of the way. And so were my husband and all four dogs, who’d decamped to the north country for bird-hunting season on Thursday. Seemed like a dream come true! It wasn’t. I was immediately and unrelentingly lonely for the little barking beggars, and the constant cacophony of chainsaw and tractor.

I brought home a gorgeous Dolomite brown 2014 Mercedes-Benz E550 Cabriolet to keep me company, beginning Thursday night with a workout, then dinner on the street in downtown Ann Arbor with my twenty-three-year-old girlfriend Jacqueline. “Don’t take this wrong,” she began. I started to laugh because she does say whatever comes to her mind. “But this is like a hot-mom-mobile.”

Hot car for a hot, rich mom, maybe. Hot because it looks killer—especially with the top down—and rich because it includes flashy options like that special exterior color ($720); custom leather interior ($1,370); wood/leather steering wheel ($590); rear deck spoiler ($350); a package of options that encompasses sound system, nav, satellite radio, rearview camera, and heated headrests ($3,270); and a sport version of the steering wheel and multicontour front seats ($870). And then there’s a full suite of parking aids ($1,290) and enough driver assistance safety nannies to almost make the car autonomous ($2,800).
You decide what you can’t live without, but I can see losing more than $6,000 of un-necessities, bringing the final bill in closer to $75,000.

On Sunday, I drove the twin-turbo V-8 cabrio with the top down to Saint Louis Center in Chelsea, to see its first annual car show, a fundraiser to build a center for the senior residents of the residential and educational facility, which cares for kids and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. I had a brother with profound disabilities who lived in a state institution because there were too many children at home for my mom to manage. He died in his twenties, and I wish there had a been a place like Saint Louis for him.

It is run by a Catholic order of priests called the Servants of Charity, started by Father Louis Guanella, who died in 1915 and was canonized a saint in 2011.  There was a lot of blessing going on by the affable Italian priests at St. Louis. They blessed the more than 100 cars that filled the sylvan grounds of the center. They blessed the people who brought the cars, the people who came out to see the cars, the judges, the raffle, and the fifty-fifty drawing, and they blessed everyone’s drive home at the end of the day. I’ve never been blessed so much in one day in my life. All of that and the Mercedes cabrio, too!  If you’re waxing nostalgic about that special Catholic school experience of being stripped daily of your pocket change by the nuns, get your checkbook out and send a fat donation to the very worthy Saint Louis Center.

The week ahead is full, including taping Jean’s Driveway reviews on Tuesday, my husband Tim’s birthday on Wednesday, writing and delivering a speech in northern Michigan, and then flying to Santa Fe, New Mexico, for the weekend for the fourth annual Santa Fe Concorso. It’s the Southwest's premier classic automotive event, taking place September 27-29 at The Club at Las Campanas. In addition to a record field of more than 140 classic and exotic cars, motorcycles, bicycles, and even children's pedal cars, the Concorso leadership has invited artist Dale Chihuly to do something he has never done: place an installation, Red Reeds, on the ninth fairway at Las Campanas, a first at any automotive event. Chihuly will also display his personal 1956 Austin Healey sports car at the Concorso, help judge the Jaguar group, and present the winner of that group with his Midnight Blue Piccolo Venetian with Red Feather Studio Edition.
I love Chihuly, but I’ll be there to honor our heroine: Denise McCluggage. If you are so inclined, come to Santa Fe next weekend. A lot of your friends will be there. - Jean

As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Honda has its finger on the pulse of American culture, doesn't it? This Japanese automaker, firmly embedded into the United States, has reached out to a couple of the sweetest spots in our cultural lives by underwriting drive-in movie theaters and, for the twelfth year, rewarding the efforts of the marching bands of historically black colleges and universities.

If you've never seen such bands as the Albany State University Marching Rams, the Winston-Salem State University Red Sea of Sound, or the Jackson State University Sonic Boom of the South, you'd better start dialing up YouTube.

These bands may sport dorky uniforms and know their way around a Souza march, but they’re far from stodgy. There’s acrobatic dancing from drum majors, the bands play renditions of popular music ranging from Al Green classics to the latest rap hits, and marching configurations include fifty-yard-wide smiley faces along with the traditional letters and undulating lines. Your high school marching band had nothing on this.

Whether or not you've got a favorite on the list, join the fun anyway and start voting online now. You're allowed to vote once per day in each of the three categories: 128 instruments or less (the longest list, which includes such famous names as Howard University and Tuskegee, the latter founded by Booker T. Washington himself); 129 to 160 instruments, and 161 and up. Voting ends October 9.

On January 25, eight bands will participate in an invitational, known as "The Honda," at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta. The band that receives the most online votes is automatically included in the showcase. Three more bands are chosen (one from each size category) based on a combination of popular vote and the votes of presidents and band directors from the participating colleges. The final four bands are chosen based on social media buzz, showmanship, and past participation in the event. Each gets twelve minutes to show its best work out on the field in front of an enthusiastic crowd.

The eight bands each get a $20,000 grant from Honda for their school’s music education programs and an all-expenses-paid trip to Atlanta to the showcase.

Honda has been sponsoring the battle since 2003, and each year since then the automaker has given out more than $205,000 in educational grants to the participating colleges to help underwrite music education programs. This may not be Honda's biggest donation each year, but it's got to be the coolest.

I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. Vital Stats

Base price: $24,515 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $29,255 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 24 mpg city/37 mpg highway
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, 182 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Rearview camera, traction control, eight airbags including driver and front passenger knee airbags

Key Points

• There is a huge price range with Fusion, which also comes in hybrid and plug-in hybrid versions. The 2013 Ford Fusion Energi Titanium starts at $40,895, including a $795 destination charge. The base 2013 Ford Fusion S starts at $22,695, including destination.
• The car shown in this video is well equipped with $4,740 in options. They include the $1,000 SE Tech/MyFord Touch package that bundles dual-zone A/C and a rearview video camera with MyFord Touch; a $2,395 luxury package with heated front seats; a navigation system ($795); a start-stop system ($295); and a reverse sensing system (also $295).

• The Fusion is in the same ballpark as the 2013 Toyota Camry and Honda Accord in terms of fuel economy; the four-cylinder Camry and Accord get 25/35 mpg and 24/34 mpg, respectively. People really worried about fuel economy should consider the 2014 Ford Fusion Energi, which returns 100 MPGe.
• The Fusion achieved five out of five stars in National Highway Traffic Safety Administration crash testing and was rated a Top Safety Pick by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
• The Ford Fusion is one of at least twenty affordable mid-size cars on the market: Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Volkswagen Passat, Mazda 6, Dodge Avenger, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Subaru Legacy, etc., etc.

• Affordable mid-size cars are generally seen as bread-and-butter cars, but the Fusion is noteworthy because it is a style leader.
• The midlevel 1.6-liter EcoBoost engine in test car is the high-volume model; the 2013 Fusion no longer offers a six-cylinder engine. Instead, there are three four-cylinder engines with a range of horsepower and fuel economy ratings.
• It is possible to order an all-wheel-drive Fusion, which is becoming a rarity in this class.

• The interior gets high marks for roominess and for its upscale materials, but some have complained that the design and color palette are bland.
• The Fusion’s handling deserves high marks for being engaging, which means a little more excitement in your daily commute and school carpool duties.
• The car in the video is a 2013 model; the 2014 Fusion is a carryover model that adds a few things, including new exterior colors and interior trim combinations and the optional inflatable rear seatbelts that cut the risk of abdominal, chest, and shoulder injuries.
• The 2014 Fusion is also available with a new 1.5-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engine.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: I’m generally not particularly taken by in-car technology. Give me four wheels and a steering wheel, and I’m good to go. I know that tech like blind spot monitoring, lane-keeping assist, and pre-collision alert are huge leaps forward and will help people drive more safely, but I have been known to turn them off when I’m driving in favor of what I think of as a simpler, more pure driving experience. But I do make one exception, and it’s for adaptive cruise control (ACC), which I consider to be a life-changing addition to the driving experience.

Adaptive cruise control has been around since the late 1990s but has had relatively limited availability. It looks like that might be about to change, though, because Chevrolet just announced that it will bring ACC to its flagship sedan, the 2014 Chevrolet Impala, making it the first Chevrolet ever to offer the technology.

The Impala’s ACC will be “full speed range,” meaning it can operate at cruising speeds and in some stop-and-go traffic situations (Chevrolet mentions passing through a tollbooth as a possible low-speed application of ACC). Some iterations of ACC are not capable of bringing cars to a full stop and need drivers to take over during stop-and-go traffic. Chevrolet is billing the technology as a stress reliever for drivers who spend a lot of time driving on the freeway, saying that ACC can reduce brake applications by up to twenty-five times, significantly reducing the workload on the driver.

The Impala’s ACC system works using forward-looking radar to measure the space between it and the car ahead. Drivers can select one of three following distances, and the car will maintain the desired gap by automatically applying the brakes and accelerator as needed, with minimal input from drivers. If you’re worried that this is the beginning of the self-driving-car apocalypse, don’t be. It’s a far cry from autonomous driving; drivers still need to provide steering input and may need to override the system for emergency braking and other maneuvers, so you can’t just switch on cruise control and take your eyes off the road. What ACC can do is lighten the load on long highway drives or busy early morning commutes.

Adaptive cruise control isn’t hard to find if you know where to look, with offerings from Audi, Volkswagen, Mercedes-Benz, Chrysler, Honda, and others. The 2014 Infiniti Q50 sedan has made waves recently for something closer to autonomous driving: that car will manage speed and keep a car centered in its lane, even around slight corners, with no input from the driver. General Motors first introduced ACC to its Cadillac XTS sedan in 2012 and also offers it in the Cadillac ATS and SRX. The technology’s move to GM’s non-luxury brand is a good sign for those of us who can’t quite justify a Caddy.

The cost of the Impala is still nothing to sneeze at, either, since adaptive cruise control will be available only to drivers who choose the Impala’s top LTZ trim level and the 3.6-liter V-6 engine. The car's price is $36,715, including destination, and adaptive cruise control will add $1,695.

pageElements.text: It’s not just people milling around in the road looking at smartphones who are at risk as pedestrians. (See Christina Tynan-Wood's story on the zombie apocalypse in the modern crosswalk.) It has been in the forefront of my mind lately that it’s dangerous for just about anybody, at just about any time, to cross the street. In the pedestrian-heavy college town of Ann Arbor, Michigan, where I live, the city has gone to seemingly extreme lengths to protect pedestrians, and still: on a summer afternoon, in broad daylight, a college student was crashed into and killed by a car just a few weeks ago. Making matters worse, she was crossing at one of those special HAWK (high-intensity activated) crosswalks with bold signage, wide stripes—and flashing lights to warn that someone was crossing the street. This is what it looked like, and it still wasn't enough.

This kind of tragedy is a motivating force behind Honda’s experimental safety technologies that aim to keep walkers and motorcycle riders safer from collisions with cars. As a bonus, the Vehicle-to-Pedestrian (V2P) and Vehicle-to-Motorcycle (V2M) technology will help protect the occupants of the vehicles, too.

Honda’s experimentation involves Dedicated Short Range Communications, or DSRC. This technology uses GPS and requires that both the pedestrian and driver have DSRC enabled. The pedestrian’s is on a smartphone, and the driver's shows up on a head-up display, as shown here. If the pedestrian has a smartphone enabled with the DSRC technology, it will warn both the pedestrian and the cars around him or her about traffic. Honda says this will be a big help when the pedestrian is not easily seen by a driver, such as when there’s traffic in the way or the pedestrian is stepping out from behind parked cars. Both sound—a series of loud beeps—and an on-screen visual warning are sent to the smartphone and the car.

It’s interesting to note that the vehicle can also get information about whether the pedestrian is on the phone, texting, or listening to music…too bad the pedestrian can’t learn the same about the driver.

Vehicle-to-Motorcycle (V2M) works in much the same way. Its advantage, as Honda explains it, is that the motorcycle can be detected by the car’s DSRC setup even when the driver can’t see a bike, such as when it’s obstructed by other traffic or the surrounding landscape.

Honda has eight vehicles participating in the pilot car-to-car communication study by the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute. The automaker has also been doing pedestrian safety research for years with its Polar pedestrian safety crash test dummies. The Polar I, II, and III series dummies have helped spur such advances as collapsible hood hinges and windshield wiper pivots to help keep the heads of pedestrians safer in the event of an accident.

title: Driving in the Zombie Apocalypse
promoTeaserSmall: Teen pedestrians are more distracted than ever. Five safety tips for drivers.
promoTeaser: Teen pedestrians are more distracted than ever. Five safety tips for drivers.
metaTitle: Driving in the Zombie Apocalypse - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Driving in the Zombie Apocalypse: What can you do as a driver when you have all those distracted teenage pedestrians crossing in front of you, listening to iPods and talking on smartphones? Five tips from JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Every time my son gets in the car and drives away, I worry. This isn’t the everyday variety of worry, even though it happens every day. I know driving is dangerous for teens because I’ve seen the numbers: Thirty-five percent of all teenage deaths happen behind the wheel. I also know my son: He is a very distracted teen. Even without a smartphone, earbuds, friends texting him, hilarious YouTube videos, and mobile games in the palm of his hand, he’s always been a bit of a “lost in thought” space case. And eleven percent of all drivers under the age of twenty involved in fatal crashes were distracted at the time. So he and I have talked at length about distracted (and drunk) driving.
Funny thing: I haven't been worried when he walks away.

It turns out I should worry more about his distracted walking, which has more than once caused him to walk into furniture at home. Safekids.org recently published a study detailing how dangerous this common behavior is. According to this report, one in five high school students and one in eight middle school students were observed crossing the street while distracted by technology. I guess it’s not that surprising that pedestrian injuries are the fifth leading cause of injury-related death in the United States for children ages five to nineteen. And given how many teenagers have a smartphone, they are at greatest risk. According to SafeKids.org, “Teens have a death rate twice that of younger children and account for half of all child pedestrian deaths.”

1. Talk to Your Daughters and Sons

As a parent, I obviously need to talk to my son (and my not-yet-driving daughter) about this very dangerous habit right along with all the other risky teen behaviors, like alcohol, sex, drugs, guns, and driving, because statistically this is more dangerous than teen pregnancy or gun violence. But what about when I get behind the wheel? If the kids are all walking around distracted, what should I do to keep from running them over?

2. Realize That Anyone Could Be Walking while Distracted

This study focused on teens. But, according to John Ulczycki, vice-president of strategic initiatives at the National Safety Council: “This could just as easily apply to adults because they are just as distracted. Teens tend to text and play games while walking, but adults are talking on the phone. And the difference in how distracted people are by those activities is negligible.” Ulczycki explains that you can do some things (chew gum, for example) while walking and still focus on walking. But anything that presents a “cognitive distraction"—and all these activities do—means you will not see what is right in front of you. So I guess I have to start driving as if I’m living in a zombie apocalypse--one, that is, where I desperately don’t want to hurt any of the zombies?

3. Don’t Assume They Can See You

Yes. And I can't begin to overstate the zombies’ lack of awareness of the world around them. There may have been a time when I could assume that if someone looked right at my car, they saw it and were likely to do their best to avoid being hit by it. But—in the zombie apocalypse—you can’t make that assumption. A person who is “cognitively distracted,” as Ulczycki describes it, might look right at you and not see you at all. “Their mind is occupied by something else,” he explains. “They are looking but not seeing. Psychologists call this ‘inattention blindness.’ ”

4. And Know That They Might Be Jaywalking

According to the Highway Safety Research Center, jaywalking is also a huge problem. So I can’t assume that distracted pedestrians are planning to stay safely on the sidewalk. If I’m in a school zone or a residential area, I have to assume that pedestrians can’t hear my vehicle because they might be wearing earbuds, and they can’t see me because they are cognitively distracted. It's also important to assume they have no intention of obeying the rules. Better to be pleasantly surprised.

5. As for You: Don’t Drive Distracted

All this is challenging enough for a driver. But if that driver is also distracted by a phone call, a text, or the phone’s navigation software, it’s a perfect storm in which someone is very likely to get hurt. I may not be able to stop those teenagers from walking distracted, but I can put my own phone down when I’m behind the wheel and pay careful attention to the zombie apocalypse that’s happening outside my vehicle. And so can you.

title: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska
promoTeaserSmall: Elderly ex-dealer offers hundreds of Chevrolets at auction. Is this Norman Rockwell or Hoarders?
promoTeaser: Elderly ex-dealer offers hundreds of Chevrolets at auction. Is this Norman Rockwell or Hoarders?
metaTitle: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska: Hundreds of old Chevrolets, many never driven or owned before, and many more left out in a field untended, are up for auction this weekend. See some of them at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: It was probably the 1950s for quite a bit longer in small-town Nebraska than anywhere else in the country...but still: the Chevrolet dealer in tiny Pierce, Nebraska, a mom-and-pop operation since 1946, held on to hundreds of Fifties and Sixties Chevys, many of them never driven. Years have passed; Lambrecht Chevrolet closed its doors in 1996 and left a huge inventory right where it was. All these years, the cars have been kept, but not well cared for. And just like that, like a Fifties dream deferred, Mom and Pop realized they are now in their nineties and it's time to cash them in.

So the Lambrecht Chevrolet collection, nearly 500 cars and trucks, is up for auction this weekend. Previews are happening Friday, September 27, with a live auction to follow on Saturday and Sunday. Some 10,000 people are expected to flock to this village about 130 miles northwest of Omaha. Many of them will come with trailers, but online bidding is sure to be frenetic as well, and the Chevys will surely disperse to the four corners of the world right afterward. Imagine the circus that will be downtown Pierce this weekend. Lemonade stands, sidewalk sales, and all kinds of outside commerce are sure to make a great news story--and to leave the town in a bit of shock for months afterward.

You've got to ask: How did this happen? Having read the biography of Ray P. Lambrecht by his daughter, titled The Man behind the Legend, I think it's a Norman Rockwell painting mixed with an episode of "Hoarders." Apparently Lambrecht, home from the Aleutians after his tour of World War II duty, married his pre-war sweetheart, built them a house in Pierce, then opened up a Chevy dealership across the street. He only wanted to sell the brand-newest Chevrolets, so when he took cars as trade-ins, he just parked them out back and left them there untouched. For decades.

Likewise, he picked out some cars that he especially liked and never sold them at all. These are the ones the collectors are salivating over: cars with less than ten miles on the odometer, never titled. The collector blogosphere has been blowing up for weeks: Will these be sold to wealthy foreign collectors who will restore them? Will they be kept as is, dust, mold, and all, like a Mouton Rothschild bottle in the wine cellar? Is this guy a genius or a villain? The latter designation comes to mind because he left so many cars out in a field until trees grew through them. I do wonder: Why didn't he put these in a bunch of garages or pole barns? Why didn't he hire somebody to keep them in running condition? Instead, his faithful sole mechanic, the guy who worked at the dealership all those years, kept people from stealing them and, apparently, didn't do much else. He has passed on, and reportedly vandals have been stealing the chrome and radiators off the untended cars. So, as I said, a fascinating story that's really kind of sad.

Now, I was born in 1957, and I suppose I look about as fashionable and current as some of these dust-covered, tailfin-spouting Bel Airs. I hope I have at least as much retro charm as my favorite at this auction: a 1958 Chevrolet Cameo Pickup in turquoise with 1.3 miles on the odometer, which was never issued a title. That one, shown at the top of this page, has already been bidded up to $46,000 in pre-auction online action, although all of the cars will be sold live.
This auction is too fascinating not to watch. Here's where you can see it online live, starting at 9:30 a.m. Central on Saturday: VanDerBrink Auctions.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.
