pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $42,775 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.8 liter turbocharged inline 4 engine with direct injection
Transmission: 7-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: mbrace2
Option I can’t live without: Dynamic Sport package ($3,050)
You might also be considering: Audi A4/S4, BMW 3 Series, Cadillac XTS, Infiniti Q60 (formerly Infiniti G), Lexus IS
See more specs on the Mercedes-Benz C-Class in our Car Guide.

C does not stand for cookie in the case of the Mercedes-Benz C-Class, but it may stand for cowbell. The C250 sedan that I drove had plenty of cowbell. In fact it had a $3,050 Dynamic Sport package that included eighteen-inch two-tone wheels, AMG spoiler, silver shift paddles, “agility suspension,” and enough red stitching to make a grown man cry, but the pièce de résistance for me was the red seatbelts.

The C-Class is the entry level for Mercedes, but it truly feels like you could swing by your best friend Kim Kardashian’s house for mimosas, and your car would be right at home. The base price for the C250 is $36,255, so many will not make it past the velvet rope, but for those who do it will not disappoint.

Mercedes has built its reputation as a luxury marque and has relied on its subsidiary AMG to provide performance versions of its models. Rather than a full-blown AMG model—that would greatly increase the performance and the price—the sport package in this model featured AMG’s styling and suspension. At first, I thought that it was just a marketing gimmick with no real substance, but once I sat in the cabin I understood the choice. AMG is more than power and performance; it also demands an unrelenting attention to design and detail.

The 1.8-liter turbocharged engine with the seven-speed transmission, in combination with the so-called “agility suspension,” delivered a sporty driving experience rather than a more floaty, luxury experience that you might expect from a C-Class Mercedes. The steering was precise, and the cornering was tight. It made me yearn for a long drive on a twisty road. For those who want an even sportier experience,  there is a sport mode that makes the ride firmer and the steering sharper and pumps up the performance by starting in second gear.

The included equipment list is longer than an NBA player’s arm, but of note is the inclusion of mbrace2. This feature connects with a smartphone to keep track of the keys, accept Google maps, and remotely set off horns and lights. It also has monitoring features that can act as an in-car nanny for new drivers to track routes and alert you if the car is speeding.

The C-Class is also available as a coupe, which has styling that is actually even more beautiful. Both body styles are available with either a V-6 or, for those who want even more power and are willing to pay for it, a V-8.

The Verdict:

Every time I buckled the bright red seatbelts in the C250, I felt special. Even though the version I drove had the standard 1.8-liter turbocharged engine, it was the perfect amount of performance to make the experience fun without feeling like more power and torque than I could handle. The exterior and interior design is utterly modern, and the red seatbelts and red stitching look like they could be featured in a MOMA catalog.

The C250 is in an ultracompetitive segment, and the one to beat has always been the BMW 3 Series. But now there is a new contender, the Cadillac ATS, which arrived in late 2012. For buyers who lean toward domestic, this is a viable option. For 2014, the ATS's base price of $33,990 comes in just $515 above the 3 Series' base 320i ($33,475) and $705 below the Audi A4 ($34,695). GM is specifically going after the BMW on sales and has called it out by name in advertisements. If buyers do shift from BMW to Cadillac,  that could split the vote and help the C-Class close the sales gap. With that being said, if design trumps all for you, then the C250 is the better option. And for me personally, after a week in this entry-level luxury sedan, I declare that C is for count me in.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: The C250 was fun and felt sporty despite having the smallest engine in the C-Class lineup. I really like the mbrace infotainment system; I find it logical and easy to use. I can't stand those bright red seatbelts, though. I'll take mine without the AMG styling package, please!

Laura: I liked the red seatbelts and trim! To me, they mean that this upwardly mobile car doesn't take itself too seriously. They appeal to me as a Mercedes-Benz hesitater: I don't want to drive some middle-management mobile. Between these colorful styling touches, the unobtrusive but exhaustive mbrace2 telematics, and the low-key but attractive body, the C250 may be a Mercedes, but it easily won over this lefty Democrat. The turbo engine reacted to the light, undemanding pressure of my right foot the way a ten-month-old golden retriever puppy reacts to a slack leash in the park: it went along with me cheerfully, but it was clearly eager to do much, much more. I think it's worth the price to have a runner in your driveway, even if you're usually only going to go out for a mild stroll.

pageElements.text: Raise your hand if you love the fake woodie look!
I assume no hands are raised.

The last man standing with fake vinyl exterior panels was the Chrysler PT Cruiser (shown here), and good riddance to that look. Manufacturers have been slower to realize that fake wood on the inside of cars also looks horrible. And then, when they put in real wood but overprocess it until it looks just like plastic, that’s almost worse.
If you are not currently swanning around your neighborhood in a Bentley or a Rolls-Royce, next time you see one, sneak a peek inside and see what real wood looks like.

To Be Real

High-end manufacturers have long understood the need to have authentic materials, and when the sky’s the limit, why would you consider such plebeian choices as pleather or synthetic wood? Fortunately, in recent years many automakers have turned their attention to the wood being used in their interiors. In fact, when I first saw the interior of the 2014 Volvo XC60 (shown at top), I was so impressed with the smooth, matte, totally real-looking wood interior on the center console that I started to dig deeper into exactly what kind of wood Volvo was using in its interiors.

The Wood in the Volvo XC60

The 2014 Volvo XC60’s wood trim looks like a fine piece of furniture rather than the highly glossed wood that has graced some interiors out there. In the past, even when designers have selected real wood, they have made them appear fake with way too much gloss, rather than let the beauty of the wood itself do the shining. This wood actually has a texture to it, and it looked and felt great.

This optional trim from Volvo is  called Urbane Wood. The automaker does not specify the exact tree species that is used but explains that it is real wood—you can tell—sourced from responsibly managed forests and certified by the Forest Steward Council.

Volvo’s spokeswoman, Laura Venezia, went on to explain: “It is constructed from wood that is dyed, and then those different-colored pieces are artfully layered together, creating its intense and distinctive pattern. The pattern was inspired by the exotic grain of the strikingly beautiful but threatened species of African Zebrano.”

Then There’s Lexus

I pushed on to see what other manufacturers were doing with their wood. Lexus is using many different woods and can actually name them, too, but I was most interested in the bamboo they are using in their hybrids. Janis Ambrose Shard is color, material, and finish manager for Lexus, and she explained the division’s choices.

“Our goal is to create a luxurious and comfortable cabin that is consistent with the personality of each Lexus model.  We're often inspired by trends, new processes and innovations.  We look for wood that is distinct and will make our customers feel like they're indulging every time they step in the vehicle. “ Shard also noted that wood selection for Lexus interiors is also, like fish at a fine restaurant, “dependent on market availability."

From the Sublime to the Rare

The fabulous Audi A7 has optional fine grain ash wood in a natural brown color, or layered oak wood interior inlays. It is seriously stunning.

On the other end of the automotive luxury spectrum stands the top-of-the-line Ram Laramie Longhorn pickup truck. Ram has followed the trend of upscale automakers and is using reclaimed wood. Ram’s interior design chief, Ryan Nagode, told the New York Times the fascinating back story of the wood he chose for the Laramie Longhorn: “I wanted it to have the feel of the worn stock of an old shotgun or rifle. I really wanted it to show that it’s real wood.”

So Ram is repurposing distressed wood that it found in Europe, as the Ram Trucks Blog explains. “On French farms, trees are often used as fence posts. Farmers wrap barbed wire around the tree, and over time it grows around the wire. This produces a swirl pattern within the wood. However, not all fence posts are created equal. Only about one in 1,000 trees has the proper pattern to be used in our trucks.”

Let’s Keep It Authentic Out There

I am pleased to see the shift from plastics to real wood, and it is starting to align with my personal artistic vision of real wood. I live in a 100-year-old Victorian home that has unpainted oak trim throughout, so I know what real wood gives to the aesthetic. I am on board —pun intended—with the trend to authentic wood, and I am especially pleased with the move toward reclaimed lumber.

metaDescription: A Detroit Weekend with Volvo's XC60: From the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park to the apple orchard at Wasem Farms, this crossover was capable and comfortable. Read about my adventures at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It seems to have happened all at once: temperatures are dropping, the leaves are starting to change, the days are getting shorter. All signs point to fall. And while I love a good, crisp autumn day, I struggle with my yearly revelation that it will be at least six months until I feel warm again. So last weekend, in the waning days of summer, I decided to go out and drink up the last bits of warm, beautiful weather by knocking a few things off my to-do list. The items in question: attend one last Detroit Tigers baseball game, sample one of Detroit's famous Coney Island hot-dog joints, and visit Wasem Fruit Farms in Milan, Michigan.

Of course, every good weekend needs a good car to go with it, and this one was no exception. A 2014 Volvo XC60 T6 AWD was my companion for these several jaunts across southeast Michigan. This shiny white Volvo was brand spanking new, with fewer than 600 miles in the bank when it was dropped off at our office.

This XC60 crossover can be had for as little as $35,765, including destination, but the one I drove is several notches up the latter at $53,215, thanks to a powerful 300-horsepower six-cylinder engine, all-wheel drive, and optional safety technology. Even the paint, a metallic Crystal White Pearl, cost $550 extra.

And, as you might expect, this Volvo had more safety features than you could shake a stick at. Blind spot monitoring, cross traffic alert, lane change assist, and front and rear park assist came in the $900 Blind Spot Information System package. Another $1,500 got us adaptive cruise control, collision warning with full auto brake, lane departure warning, distance alerts, and other features. All that safety technology helped the XC60 earn a five-star overall safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and it’s a Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick + for 2013.

Our XC60 also boasted creamy white leather seats and elegant wood trim. (JKC's Molly was so inspired by the wood in this Volvo that she wrote a whole story about it.) The seats and wood are part of the Inscription package, a $2,300 option. Suffice it to say the XC60 was several notches up the ladder from the car I normally drive around on weekends, and I was thrilled at the substitution.

The first stop of the weekend was Comerica Park, where my parents hold truly prime season tickets to our beloved Detroit Tigers. This meant driving the twenty miles from Ann Arbor to Plymouth to pick them up so we could all drive downtown together. Traffic was slow on the freeway, so I ducked off and took dirt roads most of the way to the family seat, but the Volvo was unfazed by the rougher terrain—although I did manage to dirty up the dazzlingly white paint.

Parents collected, we headed off together to downtown Detroit. The XC60 isn’t a huge car, but we managed to squeeze four adults inside in relative comfort. I watched from the back seat as my father toggled through the electronic dashboard’s settings, which had completely flummoxed me (turns out it’s controlled by a knob on the wiper stalk. Who knew?), to call up our real-time fuel economy. The XC60 is rated at 24 mpg on the highway, 20 mpg combined. We managed 21 on that trip, the best of any of the weekend’s trips, and Volvo is anxious to point out that its cars, unlike others from luxury brands, don’t require premium fuel.

On Saturday, I made a return trip downtown for visits to the Detroit Institute of Arts and Lafayette Coney, a classic Detroit hot dog joint. I was driving with all of the Volvo’s available safety systems on, which meant that my ride was frequently interrupted by small beeps and flashing lights (You’re following too closely! There’s someone in your blind spot! You’re drifting out of your lane!).  If you’re fully focused on the task of driving, this can be a little annoying, since the car is reminding you of things you already know. But if you allow your attention to wander at the wrong moment, those little beeps could save you a lot of trouble. I found that out when I briefly turned my head to talk to my passenger as we approached a green light. Suddenly I heard loud beeping coming from the dash and turned my head back to see that the light was no longer green and the car in front of me had stopped. I hit the brakes in time to keep Volvo’s collision avoidance system from doing it for me, but for the rest of the day I kept wondering if the warning system had just saved me from a crash.

By Sunday it was officially, undeniably autumn, so I took my Volvo to Wasem Fruit Farms for apple picking and doughnut eating, a favorite fall activity. I’d been slowly familiarizing myself with the XC60’s infotainment system all weekend, but three days later I still found its combination of buttons and knobs confusing and far from intuitive. Happily, the rest of the XC60’s interior was far less troublesome. The white leather seats and attractive wood trim give it the right amount of upscale feeling, and it was a comfortable place to spend a weekend.

The Volvo’s 300-hp engine is mated to a six-speed automatic transmission and makes the XC60 feel much sportier than your average crossover. You’ll never want for power in this vehicle, but it also won’t overwhelm you. The exterior styling is different enough to stand out in the crowd of look-alike crossovers, but not outlandish enough to turn you into the pariah of the country club. In other words: it’s just the right dose of attitude in a generally sedate segment. A Swedish crossover may have been an odd choice for a thoroughly Midwestern weekend, but the XC60 was up to the task.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $21,825 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $23,250 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 24 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 131 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic

Tech features: NissanConnect with navigation, Google Send-to-Car, hands-free text messaging assistant (all part of Technology package)

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/YxpcKQ6YIpY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• This is the uplevel model. The base 2013 Nissan NV200 S starts at $20,835, including destination.
• Its only real competitor is the Ford Transit Connect. For 2013, the base Transit Connect XL van starts at $23,420, including destination.
• Fuel economy is comparable to the Ford Transit Connect. The EPA says the Transit Connect returns 21 mpg city/27 mpg highway.
• Our test car was equipped with $1,425 worth of options, including a $190 back door glass package; $190 exterior appearance package that bundles body-colored front and rear bumpers, body-colored door handles, body-colored exterior mirrors, full wheel covers and a chrome grille; $950 technology package that includes a rearview monitor, Bluetooth, Sirius XM Satellite Radio, NissanConnect with navigation, Google Send-to-Car and hands-free text messaging assistant.

• The NV200 is a “box on wheels” or a giant toolbox that is aimed squarely at commercial users, such as caterers, florists, and other small business owners.
• Nissan also collaborated with guitar maker Gibson on an NV200 mobile workshop for guitar repair.
• This vehicle is all about functionality, and it pays to compare it D-ring to D-ring against the Transit Connect. The NV200 has six D-rings in the cargo hold, while the Transit Connect has two.

• The NV200 features unusual 40/60 split rear French doors because Nissan noticed in market research that most people only open one door in the rear. So they figured it was better to make the right side large and the left side smaller so it doesn’t intrude into traffic. The Transit Connect has a 50/50 design.

• Acceleration is slow, and the 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine only delivers 131 horsepower. Plus, this work van is built on the same platform as the Nissan Cube and Versa.
• The NV200 has a small turning circle, which makes it easy to park in urban settings.

• The front passenger's seat in the NV200 folds down to serve as a table for eating or as a workstation.
• The center console can hold hanging file folders, and there’s a drawer under the passenger's seat. There's also a cubby for a tablet.
• The NV200 has flat wheel intrusions in the cabin, while the TC’s are rounded and intrude into the space.

• In addition to the basic NV200 cargo van and the NV200 taxi, there is an NV passenger van, which seats up to twelve, and the new NV200 compact cargo van, aimed at business owners who can get by with a smaller vehicle.
• By the way, Ford just rolled out the new 2014 Transit Connect Taxi in late September. This is war!

title: Classic Chevy Bonanza: Update
promoTeaserSmall: How much do you think this 1958 Cameo pickup fetched at auction?
promoTeaser: How much do you think this 1958 Cameo pickup fetched at auction?
metaDescription: Classic Chevy Bonanza: Update. Hundreds of old Chevrolets, many never driven or owned before, and many more left out in a field untended, are up for auction this weekend. See some of them at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: It was one of those "only in America" moments: thousands converged on the tiny town of Pierce, Nebraska, last weekend to bid on a bunch of dusty, rusty old Chevrolets. What made this auction unusual was that the owner, the local Chevrolet dealer, had set aside cars and trucks for decades, and many of them had only a few miles on their odometers and plastic covers still on their seats.
See the back story here.

It wasn't surprising, then, that in this authenticity-starved world, people would bid high to get unsullied cars and trucks from a simpler time--or, in the case of the really badly decomposed specimens, authentic parts cars for a song.
So, how much do you think this 1958 Chevrolet Cameo pickup, in traditional Fifties turquoise and with only 1.3 miles on its odometer, was sold for?
"A true survivor car," the auction literature read. No word on who bought it, but the History Channel televised the auction, and it made the blogs of auto collectors around the globe.

That was the top price at the weekend auction, but this 1963 Impala two-door hardtop with eleven miles on the odometer, a 327-cubic-inch V-8, and "some bird poop on the back of the deck lid....does not run at this time" went for $97,500.
This Indy Pace Car 1978 Corvette, also new (although old), sold for $80,000, as did a 1958 Apache 31 Series pickup with five miles on it.
There was cheaper stuff as well, from Chevrolet pencils and retractable rulers out of the dealership's past history to hubcaps and parts cars. Who doesn't love a garage sale?

The day may come when millennial cars are pulled out of somebody's pole barn and sold at auction, but I know one thing: this is probably the swan song for anyone hoping to find relatively untouched 1950s treasures like these. Here's hoping their new owners will respect the history.

title: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over
promoTeaserSmall: Can a beauty upgrade make a new generation of upscale buyers want to spend time in the showroom?
promoTeaser: Can a beauty upgrade make a new generation of upscale buyers want to spend time in the showroom?
metaTitle: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over: Hines Lincoln dealership of Plymouth, Michigan, gets a remake to turn the showroom into a nice-smelling, upscale-looking place where it hopes upscale buyers will want to spend some time. Read about the make-over on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that Lincoln, Ford’s nearly century-old luxury brand, has fallen on tough times. The entire marque is regularly outsold by single vehicles in the Ford brand, and Lincoln’s design chief, J Mays, was quoted in August by the Detroit News admitting that Lincoln isn’t “true luxury.”

But Ford is looking to change that. The automaker has rebranded Lincoln with a new logo and is in the process of overhauling the Lincoln product lineup; the all-new-for-2013 Lincoln MKZ is a sign of things to come. Lincoln is also working to overhaul the customer experience to attract new, younger luxury buyers. A new program for dealers, dubbed Lincoln Academy, aims to change the buying experience right down to the way a dealership smells.

So I paid a visit to Hines Park Lincoln in Plymouth, Michigan, right in the heart of Ford country and Lincoln’s “flagship” dealership. A walk through the showroom proved that the effort at change is no joke. Operations manager Ryan Kolb told me that the entire dealership has just been overhauled this spring. A new service desk is designed to recall the entrance of a boutique hotel. The interior layout is more open, and modern furniture, all in black and white, creates an upscale atmosphere.

Orchids and Earl Grey Tea

The new look comes with accessories. Tables are adorned with orchids and copies of the Wall Street Journal. There are private booths for people who need to work while waiting for a car to be serviced. A signature Lincoln smell, said to bear a hint of jasmine and Earl Grey tea, was undetectable, but I also couldn't pick up the usual dealership scents of motor oil and stale coffee, so we’ll call that a win.
Kolb says his customers love the new atmosphere. “People don’t feel like they’re in a car dealership. It’s just comfortable.”

Hospitality Upgrade Comes with a Greeter

It’s not just new furniture, either. Kolb and five other Hines Park employees traveled to Chicago this spring for a Lincoln Academy training session that focused on hospitality and the customer experience. Quarterly in-dealership visits are planned to bring that training to the rest of Hines Park’s staff. As a result of the training, Kolb brought in a new, full-time employee just to circulate around the dealership and make sure customers feel taken care of.

Will This Bring In a New Crop of Buyers?

All of this attention to the dealership experience is aimed at drawing a new kind of customer to the Lincoln brand. Kolb’s trade-in lot is full of aging domestics, many of them Ford products. He says that “probably 80 percent” of his customers are either A Plan or X Plan customers, meaning they either work for Ford, work for a Ford supplier, or are related to someone who does. Since the introduction of the MKZ, though, interest from other types of buyers has piqued. Kolb says, “We’re seeing people we never would have seen before,” including people who currently drive Lexuses and Audis. “It’s gotten us on the map.”

The revamp of this dealership was expensive. Kolb’s eyes get big and he nods vigorously when I suggest that the remodel was a big investment, but he doesn’t go into detail about money. And with Lincoln’s challenged sales numbers, it seems like a bit of a gamble.  But with the introduction of the small crossover MKC next year (which Kolb says he believes will be “huge” for his dealership), things might be looking up for Lincoln.

No one’s expecting that the scent of Early Grey tea will bring about a magical instant revival for the brand, though. J Mays said recently that Ford is looking at a ten-year investment to bring the Lincoln brand back up to par with its desired competitors. And Ryan Kolb knows his success will depend on continued support and new product development from Lincoln.
“It’s going to take a while,” he says, but he’s optimistic that his investment will pay off, and while he's waiting, his dealership is definitely a nicer place to spend time.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop). As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad.

pageElements.text: There’s something that feels uniquely American about taking a long cross-country road trip. It’s on every car-loving teenager’s to-do list, just as soon as they can shake off the oppressive parental yoke and do it on their own. The quintessential Americanness of the transcontinental journey hasn’t stopped British-born, German-owned Mini from getting in on the game, though.

The quirky car company runs a biannual two-week rally that takes thousands of Mini owners and enthusiasts on a road trip across the Lower Forty-Eight. It’s nearly a year away, but Mini is already planning for the fifth Mini Takes the States event next summer, which will lead drivers from San Francisco all the way to Boston.

Thinking of Joining Up?

The trip will start on July 26, 2014, and stop in fourteen cities on the way to its arrival in Boston on August 9. The route reaches as far south as Austin, Texas, and as far north as Buffalo, New York. (Last time, in 2012, the route went from east to west.) Mini expects thousands of Mini owners to join the caravan for all or part of the journey, which meanders through seventeen states. That's right: You can jump in (and out) along the way if you can't mark off that entire block of time next summer.

These offbeat yet ambitious events are just part of doing business with Mini. The brand prides itself in its goofy, enthusiastic attitude and encourages its drivers to participate in Mini rallies whenever possible. This spring, for example, nearly 900 Minis paraded across Michigan’s Mackinac Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in the Western Hemisphere, in an attempt to break a Guinness record for the longest parade of Minis. Although unsuccessful in that quest, the group did manage to set a record for the largest ensemble of car horns, an accomplishment any motorist would be proud of.
If spending two weeks driving cross-country in a Mini sounds like your kind of party, sign up to receive e-mail updates from Mini.

title: Understanding the New Crash Tests
promoTeaserSmall: Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's newest testing.
promoTeaser: Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's newest testing.
metaTitle: Understanding the New Crash Tests - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Understanding the New Crash Tests: Have you heard about the new crash tests? Advanced safety ratings? Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's latest testing. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a new vehicle recently, you've probably consulted some source of safety information, and you've probably been very interested in crash test results for the model you have in mind. Crash testing from the federal government's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, or NHTSA, is one of the two sources for this data. The other is the insurance industry's Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, or IIHS—the organization that hands out the Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ awards. And you probably have a mental picture of what they do, i.e., smash a car into something, wreck it, and see how the crash test dummies make out.

With that in mind, you may be shocked to discover that a new crash-avoidance rating system by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety skips traditional crash testing in which the car is totaled. But don't be dismayed; the new setup actually provides some of the best information on whether crash-prevention systems are worth the money.

Helping You See the Benefit of Anti-Crash Technology

The new IIHS testing examines modern safety systems, including forward collision warning and autobrake systems. Forward collision warning alerts a driver when the vehicle is about to crash into another vehicle in front, but the system doesn’t slow down or stop the vehicle. Autobrake systems do; they can slow down or stop the car to avoid front-to-rear crashes if the driver doesn’t respond to a warning.
Safety experts say the benefits of these fancy and expensive systems are often lost on consumers.

“Front crash prevention systems can add $1,000 or more to the cost of a new car,” said David Zuby, IIHS chief research officer. “Our new ratings let consumers know which systems offer the most promise for the extra expense.”

What Does the Testing Look Like?

The new IIHS rating system evaluates safety software and sensors in vehicles instead of structural integrity. And that’s why the IIHS did not need to total any vehicles.

Running into an actual car puts the test driver at risk and is expensive, so the IIHS used a stationary target as a stand-in. A foam dummy with a metal frame and a vinyl cover was designed to look like a car to radar and image-recognition software. A GPS system and other sensors monitor the test vehicle’s lane position, speed, time to collision, braking, and other data. The effectiveness of the systems was gauged in tests at 12 and 25 mph.
The new tests are important because they mark the first time the insurance industry-funded group has used anything besides conventional crash tests to pick its annual Top Safety Pick+ winners.

How Does IIHS Rate the Cars?

For crash-avoidance technologies, the IIHS developed a three-tier rating system—Superior, Advanced, and Basic—to show that even a basic forward collision warning system has “significant” benefits. Vehicles rated Superior have autobrake and can avoid a crash or substantially reduce speeds in the 12-mph and 25-mph tests.

In this first round of testing, an elite group of seven vehicles equipped with optional autobrake and forward collision warning systems earned Superior honors. They are the 2013-14 Cadillac ATS sedan and SRX SUV, the Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan, the Subaru Legacy sedan and Outback wagon, and the Volvo S60 sedan and XC60 SUV.

Six other models earn an Advanced rating when equipped with autobrake and collision warning. They are the 2014 Acura MDX SUV, the Audi A4 sedan and Q5 SUV, the 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee SUV, the Lexus ES sedan, and the 2014 Mazda 6 sedan. In addition, the Volvo S60 and XC60 earn an Advanced rating when they aren’t equipped with an option called Collision Warning with Full Auto Brake and Pedestrian Detection. The S60 and XC60 are the only models in the new test program with standard autobrake: Volvo's City Safety system.

Thirty models received a Basic rating; they have forward collision warning but not automatic braking. These include the 2013 BMW 3 Series sedan, which earned a Basic rating for front crash prevention.
The 2013 Toyota Prius v wagon, which, IIHS notes, "claims to have autobrake," did not qualify for an IIHS front crash prevention rating.
The new IIHS testing is expected to roll out to other vehicle categories in the coming year.

title: Save Your Car from the Kids: 5 Tips
promoTitle: Save Your Car from the Kids: 5 Tips
promoTeaserSmall: Reality-based cleaning! How to win over the Happy Meal trash and bent crayons, once and for all.
promoTeaser: Reality-based cleaning! How to win over the Happy Meal trash and bent crayons, once and for all.
metaTitle: Save Your Car from the Kids: 5 Tips
metaDescription: Save Your Car from the Kids: 5 Tips. Step away from the French fries and bent crayons! Here are tips to keep your car clean even though you have active kids on board. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Once you have children in your life, so many once-cherished habits go out the window. Your standards change because you have placed needy, messy, and utterly irreplaceable people in the center of your world. So many things that you once thought were indispensable to your happiness—like white tablecloths and immaculate floors—are tossed out like so much used Kleenex.

So let’s talk about that used Kleenex. Does being a parent mean that you can’t have a clean car ever again? Do you need to bow to the smushed French fries and the discarded Happy Meal boxes, and let the old homework sheets and the issues of Time for Kids take over the back seat?

Actually, no. I am as relaxed about cleanliness as just about anyone who isn’t out-and-out gross, but even I have some standards. So here are my five tips for making your car a reasonable environment that you could even invite a childless relative to share with you (without spending ten minutes hauling trash first).

1. Always have a place for trash disposal.

I have observed that children are willing to be tidy if there is an easy, simply understandable way of cleaning up. You can’t expect little kids to fold their disposable trash into neat quarters and carry it in to the house. Big kids, maybe (but probably not). You can expect them to stuff gum wrappers and junk into the fabric map pockets on the back of the seats, where you'll find it a month later, if you don't have a better option that's just as easy.

So have a trash bag, such as one of those thin plastic store bags with handles, right at hand. I often put one on the front passenger's-side armrest, where it won’t fall or spill and it’s under the driver’s control. I definitely dump it every time I stop for gas, and it’s my goal to take it out of the car every day. No trash on the floor or seats = 90 percent of the way to “clean.”

2. Make a place for things that need to stay in the car.

Have a closed plastic storage crate in the trunk or back hatch, where you keep changes of clothes, clean towels, extra shoes, sports equipment, or whatever else you want to leave in the car. This will prevent seeing the soccer shorts lolling around on the back seat for someone to wipe his or her nose on. This isn’t where you put dirty clothes; that’s in item 3.

3. Have a plan for wet/dirty storage.

When my kids were really small—toddler and young elementary age—many were the times I drove them home in only their diapers or underwear because they had jumped straight into the frog pond or totally covered themselves with mud on a hike. You spare yourself hours of interior detailing if you have a wet storage container that separates the muddy socks and the damp bathing suits. Make it one you can easily remove and take straight to the laundry room when you get home.

4. Have rules about food.

Don’t kid yourself that you’ll never let your kids eat in the car. If you spend any amount of time with them, whether taking road trips or just going to after-school music lessons and then soccer practice, they will at least snack in the car. But there are ways to reduce the mess. I always have small kitchen towels on board, and I hand out one per person for their laps and to use as napkins. The towels go into my wet/dirty storage once used, and they have saved the upholstery and my kids’ clothes many times. I also attempt to have everyone eat and then dispose of the trash all in one stop. When (not if) that fails on a longer trip, I go back to rule no. 1 and each person tossing his or her trash into the bag I have cleverly made sure to have on board.

5. Turn car care into “me” time.

Here, I am going against the grain of most well-intentioned advice about child rearing. (It won’t be the first time.) Yes, you can assign your children to take turns cleaning out the car, or stand over them while they remove all their stuff each day. And you should. But to really get that clean-car feeling, the most workable solution I have found over many years is to make it an activity I do for myself, alone. I go off on a Saturday or Sunday, without any kids, and I go through a car wash, vacuum out the car, and get out the Windex and Mr. Clean wipes to freshen the surfaces and get the finger marks off the side windows. It's kind of an enjoyable indulgence, especially when I go out for cappuccino afterward.

Let’s face it: kids are going to be messy, if they’re doing childhood right. Changing the way I react to it has made all the difference in everybody’s life in my family. And I don’t even care if you wouldn’t mistake my minivan for the vehicle of a tidy person.

title: In Search of Detroit
promoTeaserSmall: We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do.
promoTeaser: We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do.
metaDescription: In Search of Detroit - We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do. Read our update at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
photos by Molly Jean

We're Michiganders, and Jean Knows Cars was founded on the basis that we love Michigan, we love Detroit, and we proudly share a Midwestern sensibility. We've been proud that Automobile Magazine, our brother publication, has been in Michigan for all of its nearly thirty years.

However. You all know how people think about Detroit: a barren, crime-ridden wasteland. Its best days are behind it. "Nobody" lives there anymore. Well, we have a little trouble accepting that. And it's for that reason that Molly Jean and I are spending today at TEDx Detroit, a day of inspiring talks from some of the people who are making Detroit livable again.

So far, we've already heard from three people who have given us a lot to think about. While the federal government is shut down, this is a really good time to imagine ways in which regular old people (like us) can help grow the economy in simple ways without 'em. Here's some of what we heard today.

John Capp, General Motors Futurist: "We're looking for true 360-degree sensing around the vehicle."

John Capp only looked a little out-of-place amid the black-clad, youngish crowd of entrepreneurs in the capacity crowd of hundreds in Cobo Center. Having gone to an autonomous-driving confab in Detroit this summer, I was already prepared for what he had to say, but I loved hearing him say it to this crowd. He laid out the history of GM's autonomous-technology work, starting with Harley Earl's 1958 Cyclone concept and highlighting current products including Cadillac's Driver Assist technology and the vibrating Safety Alert Seat that I appreciated (even though it annoyed me) on the Buick LaCrosse.

"What we're moving toward," Capp told the crowd, "is sensor fusion," which he described as technology intuitive enough to assess a road situation that same way we do, when walking down the street. "We're on a journey," he concluded, promising that GM will be rolling out better autonomous technology step by step, all the way to a "chauffeured" experience eventually.

While I don't look for General Motors to be the first to market with autonomous technology, you never know. And I'm glad to think about Detroit having an important role in it. I'm also glad to see GM send someone to talk about it in this kind of venue.

Matthew Naimi, Recycle Here: "If they build it, they will stay."

Naimi, a smiling but unprepossessing guy in a baseball cap, made it clear as he stepped on stage that he was "just a garbage man," but he's a garbage man with an idea. He started a recycling program in central Detroit that, to date, has recycled 11 million pounds of trash. But that's not the most interesting part: he got people to volunteer to clean up the back lot of his facility and turned it into the Lincoln Street Art Park in a supposedly dangerous part of town. As he describes it, it's a place where people can put their art, plus a party space with a community bonfire pit. One rule: You can't exclude anybody. More than fifty artists have placed their work there, and there's no fence.
"To rebuild Detroit," he said, "we must re-create what made cities in the first place: the collective energy of citizens working to live together in a defined space."

Jackie Victor, Avalon International Breads: "In 1997, the narrative was pretty much uniform: Detroit was closed for business. We changed that narrative."

Seventeen years ago, this suburbanite and University of Michigan graduate, whose hippie past (and, likely, present) showed in her every movement, co-founded a "socially responsible" bakery in the Cass Corridor, the most blighted part of a blighted city. There was a tent city right down the street with 300 homeless people camping in the depth of a Michigan winter. Yet the bakery not only survived; it's got sixty employees, mostly Detroit residents, who are paid an average of $12 per hour and full benefits. A manufacturing facility is about to open on Detroit's East Side that she envisions could "become a live-work neighborhood once again."

Victor also enumerated several businesses and projects that are also thriving in Detroit: the urban agriculture movement, which has grown to see 1,500 gardens under cultivation in formerly abandoned lots; the James and Grace Lee Boggs School, an ambitious charter school just opened in a neighborhood that, she said, "I almost guarantee nobody here has been to";  the African Bead Museum on Grand River. "Who's been there?" she asked. "Gotta go!" As soon as we saw the slides she projected on the screen, Molly and I realized we had driven by that museum with its colorful wall murals on our way in. 
And she's right: We've gotta go there.

I used to come downtown with my grandparents as a child. I remember the excitement of a fully active city, and right now, I am squinting and trying to see it again. Looking forward to more inspiring stories this afternoon.
Your correspondents, Laura and Molly

metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend! A brief rundown of my activities on the weekend of September 29-30. Read it and see the snapshots on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Friday shouldn’t have been so chaotic. I was going to drive to Midland, in northern Michigan, to be on a panel discussion at Northwood University. Northwood is a jewel of a little school, most known for a curriculum that tunes students to be players in the retail end of the car biz. Every fall for the past fifty years, the students at Northwood put on a weekend that begins with the VIP panel and ends with a car show on the campus mall. I looked forward to this weekend all year, but suddenly discovered that the fourth Santa Fe Concorso would be honoring Denise McCluggage, and I needed to be there.

There was one answer: drive two hours north, be on the 10:30 a.m. panel, blow out of there like a freight train at high noon, book it two hours to Detroit Metro, catch a flight to Denver, jump on one of those flying cigar tubes to Santa Fe, and get a rental.

Car #1: Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Kia Cadenza Four Seasons Test Car

It made swift and sure transport for the four-hour round trip. I paired my phone, plugged it into the USB port, and quickly sorted out how to toggle between my iPhone playlist and the nav.

I did have one fistfight with the nav, when it spit me off the Interstate and onto forty miles of two-lanes running past cornfield after cornfield in the fertile outback south of Midland. The pitch black night was interrupted every few seconds by a synchronized flashing grid of red lights about 300 feet in the air, stretching for what looked like miles to the left and right of me. What the…

Aha. I’d not seen them at night, but it was the massive wind turbines—133 of them, stretching across 30,000 acres in rural Gratiot County—that had gone up over the past two years. I was looking at the aircraft warning lights atop the 330-foot towers. It was mesmerizing and worth the detour.

This Cadenza rings the cash register at $41,950. That’s a long way from the 2004 Kia Rio my brother owns. Ten years ago, Kia meant cheapo transpo. Now, they are stylish and nosing into the high-roller club. Still, I was dressed like a schlub. I had cleaned my house, paid the bills, and packed for the long trip before jumping in the car to head north. I was wearing jeans, a sweatshirt, a Detroit Tigers World Championship jacket, and flip-flops. This is a typical outfit for driving north to the cabin in the woods. Of course, the minute I arrived at the lovely H hotel in Midland, the head of Toyota, Jim Lentz, and his wife, Barbara, stepped from the back of a chauffeured sedan, dressed to the nines for dinner. The Kia looked elegant, though. (Reminder to self: Always dress for first-class travel in case they need to upgrade someone.) It was extra exciting for me to discover that I’d left the entire outfit (including shoes and jewelry) I’d planned to wear for my VIP morning hanging back home in the closet.

The subject of my remarks could be summed up thus: The automotive industry is awash in testosterone, and women would rather put their eyes out with steel needles than buy a new car or have it serviced. Jim Lentz made sure to attend. I’m sure my outfit from the previous evening suddenly made perfect sense.

Car #2: A Rental Chevrolet Impala

Nothing strikes fear in the heart of a frequent flyer more than finding out that all legs of the multi-leg adventure ahead will be handled by “our alliance partners,” as the tiny prison ships of the sky were called by the man checking me in at United. Then he said: “What the heck is Great Lakes Aviation doing in New Mexico? We’re the Great Lakes state.” For the record, Great Lakes Aviation was fine. And even though there was a two-hour delay in Denver, the Hertz counter was still open when we arrived in Santa Fe for the Concorso. With all of our bags.

The old Impala—although not as inspiring as the new one—makes an exceptional rental car. Hertz, however, ought to clean its car windows. The Impala felt tight for its 15,000-plus miles and had decent acceleration at 7,500 feet above sea level, and the steering wheel had no slop in it. There was a funny moment when our friend from Mercedes-Benz decided to forgo her sexy SLS cabrio press car and ride with us in the Impala to the tony grounds of the Club at Las Campanas for the Concorso, so she could share her VIP parking pass with us. The journalist riding with her took one look at us and said, “No.” Just like that. “No.” And talked his way in, which is probably something we couldn’t have done without that red VIP pass.

Car #3: A 2014 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT Roadster

The day before the Concorso, we found the First Lady of Racing, the honoree of the weekend, and my personal role model and heroine, Denise McCluggage, waiting at the start of the ninety-mile Mountain Tour for participants in Sunday’s show. Sir Stirling and Lady Susie Moss were there to lead the tour in the Roadster, but she had a thought in the night.
“You know, it’s been twenty-five years since you and Stirling did the Pirelli Classic Marathon in the MGB. Wouldn’t it be fun if you drove him this time?”
Hilarious. I could call him a stupid cow this time, and he could yell at me to stop tanning, put my shirt back on, and get back in the car. Hahaha.
He wasn’t laughing.

Until I write that particular story, let me just say that it was 38 degrees when we left, and we left the top down. I cannot praise Airscarf enough. With the heated seats on full burn, the side windows up, and the wind blocker behind us, the appropriately named Airscarf blew a constant stream of warm air around our necks. It was so warm in our open roadster that we actually dialed back on butt and neck warming.

The car show was a little gem of fabulosity, a “boutique” show as Lady Moss calls it. She and Stirling have been at all four. Other racing celebs included Norman Dewis, 93, who developed and tested every C-type, D-type, and XK-SS while at Jaguar, and Alma Hill, the woman who married America’s only Formula 1 world champion, Phil. Her son Derek was a judge, as was Al Unser, Sr.
Dale Chihuly, the extraordinary glass artist, brought his Austin Healey and did an art installation in the midst of the grounds.
More on that to come. Stay tuned.

title: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
promoTitle: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
promoTeaserSmall: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety crown one harness brand that can keep your dog safer in the car.
promoTeaser: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety crown one harness brand that can keep your dog safer in the car.
metaTitle: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
metaDescription: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In: Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety, after testing, name one brand of harness that can keep your pet safer in the car. Find out which one at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Center for Pet Safety, under Subaru sponsorship, has announced the results of its comprehensive safety testing of dog harnesses for use in the car. The 2013 Dynamic Testing Harness Study crowned one top tether: the Sleepypod Clickit Utility Harness. This three-point harness for pets in the car won the Top Performing Harness title for 2013. Subaru said in a press release that it intends to start offering this harness as an accessory through its Subaru Gear catalog in the near future.
To win that distinction, the Sleepypod product passed rigorous crash testing at an independent lab that also does testing for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Amazingly enough, there are currently no performance standards in place for products aiding the safety of pets riding in the car. Somehow, the stringent regulations for carrying babies and children in the car have not trickled down to apply to dogs. That's where the Center for Pet Safety and Subaru stepped in. This testing was looking to see if the crash test dummy dogs shown here, including a twenty-five-pound terrier mix, a forty-five-pound border collie, and a seventy-five-pound golden retriever, could safely ride in the car using commercially available safety harnesses. Jean Knows Cars talked to Lindsey Wolko of the Center for Pet Safety on Wednesday about the results of those tests.

As you might have seen from our videos here and here, we are strong advocates of restraining pets inside the car. It only makes sense for the safety and comfort of both your dogs and the people who ride with them. The Center for Pet Safety's 2011 pilot study showed that none of the commercially available harnesses at that time tested out as safe.

Pets Must Not Be on Too Long a Tether

The major problem: the stuffed dog used as a test dummy is launched right off the seat in a crash. Not safe for the dog, of course, but also potentially very dangerous for human passengers who could be hit by a flying pet. The problem is that dogs are literally on too long a leash: extensions that don't tie the pet securely enough into the car also risk injury.

Lindsey Wolko of the Center for Pet Safety reflected on the previous tests and the results of this summer's testing. "If you look at those original tests, we have a very clear understanding of what the products could not do.

"What pet owners have been told all these years is that they can put their dog in the car using long extensions [on harnesses or leashes] that give the dog a lot of freedom. That's very dangerous. We need to re-educate that people need to rein in their pets.
"We do know that having an adjustable tether and getting it as short as possible is going to provide a better outcome," Wolko said.

This Summer's Tests and What They Measured

In the new tests, Wolko said, products were downgraded for "catastrophic failure," if they allowed the dog to launch off the seat, or if the tether could not be shortened to six inches or less. A summary of test results, plus a full list of the brands tested, is viewable on the website of the Center for Pet Safety.

The Center's testing included eleven brands that claimed the status of a safety product. The products included the AllSafe, Bergan, Canine Friendly, Champion, Clix, EZ-Rider, PetBuckle, Ruff Rider Roadie, Snoozer, and Tru-Fit harnesses in addition to the winning Sleepypod Clickit Utility. After initial testing, seven products graduated to crash testing. Wolko noted that the manufacturers were all invited to come watch the testing, and all of them came.

"We're primarily a consumer advocacy organization, and this is something very important for consumers," Wolko told Jean Knows Cars on Wednesday. "We collected baseline data, and we're in the process of writing the standard now." Wolko said the organization is seeking out people who are "noted auto safety specialists" to review the data, and more information about that process will be released soon.
The Center for Pet Safety intends to pursue a certification process for pet safety products inside the car, but that's "down the road," Wolko told us.
In the meantime, we'll be getting some of those Sleepypod harnesses and checking them out for our own pets.

pageElements.text: You may not have a Bentley in your garage. In fact, I am pretty confident in betting you a few thousand bucks that you don’t.  But perhaps that betting money would be better spent on this: a lineup of furnishings that take the fine craftsmanship of a Bentley’s interior and apply it to your home or office. Prices haven’t been announced, but admiring, as always, doesn’t cost a thing.

The Bentley Home collection is “an exercise in subtlety rather than showmanship,” the automaker says, and that subtlety starts with the color choices: neutral ivory and taupe shades. But if you find that dull, not to worry: Bentley mixes it up with some beige and cream color choices.

Throughout the collection, you’ll see the diamond quilted pattern that is one of the signatures of the creamy,  elegant interiors of Bentley cars. Bentley’s winged logo is ever present on these furnishings but, like the most traditional butler, presents itself with the utmost discretion.

What’s in this collection? Bentley has teamed up with Italian luxury furnishings maker Clubhouse Italia to create several different product lines, each with a suitably upper-crust name. There’s Richmond: a lineup of sofas, chaises longues, and armchairs. These are notable for their leather braiding around the contours and the choice of leather, linen, or “fine cashmere velvet” for the soft parts. The bodies are wrapped in a double shell of leather or burr walnut veneer—but not just any burr walnut: they're the same wood choices you can get in a Bentley.
There’s Canterbury (top of page), a bed with an “imposing headboard” in leather or fabric. It comes with its bedding, including a high-luxury Fibra di Legno duvet cover.

For the executive boardroom (or your high-end home den), there’s Harlow: a metal coffee table with onyx or leather-coated surface. And Madeley, a large meeting table made of curved wood panels and handmade leather coated edges, to be paired with Kendal, a set of leather-trimmed chairs bearing the Bentley logo.
The Sherbourne & Kingsbridge cabinets, trimmed in leather with veneered fronts, are the crowning touch on this collection. They have tone-on-tone lacquered interiors with crystal shelves.

Does this collection “capture the elan of the Bentley driver” for you? At the very least, looking at this furniture captures the way it must feel to possess something really special and beautifully made.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Spark 2LT
promoTeaserSmall: It's small, cheap, not bad-looking...did I mention small? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: It's small, cheap, not bad-looking...did I mention small? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Spark 2LT: I think this minicar has many good qualities that belie its size. Still, it's tiny all right! What does the Peanut Gallery think? Read our reviews on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $15,895 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.2-liter four-cylinder, 84 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 32 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Chevrolet MyLink
Option I can’t live without: There were no options on board!
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Honda Fit, Smart Fortwo, Scion iQ, Toyota Yaris

See more specs on the Chevrolet Spark lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

How does a serious small-car buyer choose a size and type of car these days? It’s not hard to make a—you should excuse the expression—short list. The problem is in deciding on the many tradeoffs. There’s no shortage of cars in the subcompact segment and even the sub-subcompact niche. You’ve got your Mini Coopers, which are charming and sporty. But they can be as expensive as a much larger car, putting them more in the category of a second or third car to own for fun. If you’re going small at least partly to be frugal and not just to be fashionable, it might be out of your price range. You’ve got your Smart Fortwo, which is undeniably cheap and fuel-efficient but comically tiny; the Scion iQ and Fiat 500 are a little more reasonable—but only a little. Going up a bit in size, you’ll find the Honda Fit and the Toyota Yaris, which have more of a standard silhouette, along with decent-size engines and horsepower—but lower fuel economy to match.

And then there’s the Chevrolet Spark. This is a car that straddles the tiny space between these other tiny cars. You get your cheap price and your fuel economy; you enjoy a certain amount of sporty style. Yet you don’t feel like you’ve been folded up inside a suitcase. As my eighteen-year-old son Henry exclaimed the first time he climbed in, “It’s actually like a real car inside!”

How much like a real car? To find out, Henry and I embarked on a 200-mile round trip visit to that arbiter of all purchase wisdom, my dad. (You’ve met him before on a Buick LaCrosse car-testing expedition.) Yes, we careened up I-94 through pothole-rich Detroit in a Spark. It was an adventure! I did try to psych myself out a bit by murmuring to myself, “This is a normal-size car. This is a normal-size car. This is just as big as the other cars around me.” It was okay; Henry had his earphones in.

Seriously, though, the Spark was capable of meeting and even exceeding the 70-mph speed limit, providing as smooth a ride and as strong a performance as you have any right to expect from a 2,237-pound car on a 93.5-inch wheelbase with an 84-horsepower engine under the cute little hood. The five-speed manual transmission was smooth and enjoyable to use once we exited onto the surface roads of our destination. (Consumer Reports said the manual is to be preferred over the jerky automatic in this car, but I didn't try the automatic-transmission version, so I couldn't judge.)

And when we hauled ourselves up onto the solid ground of my dad’s driveway, what do you suppose his reaction was? Something along the lines of, “What is THAT!?!” and “You expect me to fit in here?” The candy-colored Spark did look faintly ridiculous in the suburban driveway, but I had already grown to like it.

I just laughed, knowing that I would indeed get my dad into the passenger’s seat of the Spark, and he’d end up having the same reaction Henry had.  Sure enough, the next morning we headed out to the Four Star, our favorite breakfast joint, and I enjoyed the feeling of parking the Spark next to a mammoth-looking Honda Accord and having plenty of room inside the white lines. My colleagues thought the front seating area was narrow and cramped. That didn't bother me, and it was no problem for my eighty-five-year-old father to get in or to get comfortable inside. Plus, he was impressed by the fuel economy numbers and the low price.

But Frank Brown is not the target demographic: This South Korea-sourced Chevrolet is the first minicar the GM division brought to North America, and it’s marketed for “young city dwellers.” Accordingly, it has a lot of electronics for such a small car. The standard MyLink infotainment system has a seven-inch screen, Bluetooth streaming audio,  SiriusXM satellite radio, and embedded Pandora and Stitcher apps. Henry figured it all out instantly and had nothing but praise for the display and the ease of use.

The Spark also spares you from some of the penalty details you’d have a right to expect from an entry-level car: there are power windows on all trim levels,  it has a flip-and-fold rear seat that opens up 31.2 cubic feet of storage space in back, and GM’s StabiliTrak system with traction control and brake assist is standard. There’s even a rear spoiler.  And when I took three members of the Jean Knows Cars team on an outing, it seated us all in pleasant comfort. (In the photo at top, you can see how well Annie White fit in the back seat, even though she’s way taller than I am.)

Henry complimented the Spark’s looks compared with, say, the Smart or the Scion, and he’s got a point. Although it comes in fruity shades including Jalapeno, Lemonade, and Techno Pink, the Spark has enough edges on it to keep from looking too much like a rolling jellybean. That almost makes up for the Oreo-cookie-size fifteen-inch wheels.
Why all the candy metaphors? I guess because driving the Spark was enough fun to knock a few decades off my mental age—at least while I was behind the wheel.

The Verdict:

A minicar like the Spark is not an impulse purchase, despite the tempting price point. You need to do some soul-searching first. Are you really prepared to drive something this small? Yes, four people do fit pretty nicely. There’s a decent amount of storage space. It’s not that this is not a functional and even a nice car. I’m talking about how it will feel, day in and day out, to be in a car that’s notably smaller than the other traffic around you. If that feels okay to you, and especially if you have already worked that out and are actively city-car shopping, don’t pick one based on trendy ads or word of mouth alone. The Chevy Spark may not be the hippest nameplate out there, but don’t make your final choice until you’ve had a spin in this one.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: On my first drive in the Spark, I kept mistakenly starting out in third gear. Then I realized that because first and second gears are so far left the armrest was getting in my way. Once I quit using the armrest, the gear pattern was much easier. However, driving a car this tiny with a manual can be a problem for the front seat passenger. I kept having to remind my daughter to leave me room to shift. Its sensibility reminds me of the Chevette: great price, reasonably cute, fun to drive. I will be interested to see how this little spark plug does in NHTSA's crash tests.

Annie: The Spark has a lot going for it—unique styling, good fuel economy, good infotainment—but its main characteristic will always be its diminutive size. The car is so narrow that the steering wheel obscures the driver's view of the center console, and two adults sitting in the front row will be bumping elbows. I wouldn't buy a Spark because I'm more likely to take four people on a road trip than I am to try to squeeze into a subcompact parallel parking space, but for city dwellers who can't get by with Zipcar, the Spark could be just the econobox they're looking for.

pageElements.text: Here’s an uncomfortable moment you may or may not relate to: It’s a very frank, brutally honest discussion about texting and driving with the women of our Group of Seven panel. This is hardly a happy discussion, but it’s an important one.
More than 100,000 accidents a year involve drivers who are texting, according to the National Safety Council.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/i_xBWM56vnk?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

People who never thought they would ever have a cell phone are now married to them. We eat with them, sleep with them, and can’t even go to the bathroom without taking it with us. We walk around with everything in our purses except our phones. Those stay in our hands.

We sit down at the dinner table with our phones. And while it’s annoying and truly socially disgraceful behavior, it’s not as potentially dangerous and irresponsible as texting and driving, which is possibly the worst menace on the road today.

We decided to have this roundtable because, before you can change your behavior, you have to admit that you indulge in it, not just talk about how bad it is in the abstract. If it takes watching the brutal documentary by Werner Herzog, so be it. Do it.

This is why I like the women who have been part of our Group of Seven panels. They are not shying away from talking about their faults or afraid to admit that it’s hard to break bad habits, even when these habits are so irresponsibly dangerous.

I was the first one to come clean, and the next thing I did was watch the Werner Herzog documentary. I still use my phone too much, but I don’t type messages on it. Anymore. Every time I look at my phone while I’m driving, I can’t get the image out of my mind of the really nice young man who smashed into an Amish buggy and killed most of a family. He wasn’t even texting; he was reading a text from his wife. That image makes me put it down every time.
Here’s our discussion. Can you relate to it?

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Some things we ran across on the way to finding what we were looking for. Go ahead, click on them and let these random items sidetrack you. It's fun.
1. Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr. does not drive 190 mph. Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr. is a band. And we predict that its new album, The Speed of Things, will be included in the playlist of one NASCAR driver.
Also, Daniel Zott, one of the band members, is now featured in the Free Credit Score commercials, so this band's songs may have the potential to get stuck in your head.
2. Midas hired the Hamburger Helper hand and painted it gold…I am not impressed.
3. For those who are diesel-curious, Audi steps in to show you how easy it will be to find your juice.
4. First there were crop circles that amazed and confused us; now there are circles on our bumpers. Our fellow journalists at Slate explain this phenomenon.

5. Hershey, Pennsylvania, is known for chocolate, but for the car geek it is also home to the Antique Automobile Club of America’s Eastern Division National Fall Meet. They have a little flea market, and by little I mean huge—9,000 market spaces, 1,000 car corral spaces, and 1,500 show cars. So if you would rather look at old cars than the deciduous display of autumn, try Hershey.

6. Something smells musky. It is fun to poke fun at the rich and successful, and Elon Musk’s outrageous, push-the-limits mentality is ripe for the picking. It is not bullying if the person can literally buy you, is it?

7. I daydream about decorating my car, but I don’t even have a single bumper sticker. Perhaps the Alan Moyes Art Cars and Carried Away! Wheels & Limbs collections on Pinterest that merge transportation and art will push me over the cliff.

8. Are you one of thousands of people who looked at the YouTube video this week of the Tesla Model S burning to a cinder? Don't let the YouTube commenters make you afraid of electric cars. Here's a smart analysis from our friends at MIT about What the Tesla Battery Fire Means for Electric Vehicles.

9. Out in Google territory in California, people on the street have a nickname for wearers of the Google Glass computer headgear: "Glassholes." It's still in Beta, so you might not have seen Google Glass on anyone yet. But Google demonstrated its Google Glass to Chevrolet executives this week, and they liked the high-tech specs. Better hands-free navigation, or more Glassholes out on the roads?

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $30,290 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $36,370 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 292 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Safety features: Seven airbags (including a driver’s knee airbag), stability control, rain brake support, ready alert braking; Driver Confidence Group ($1,495) includes blind spot and cross-path detection, rear park assist
Tech features: Uconnect with 8.4-inch touchscreen; navigation and rearview camera ($995)
Chief competitors: Ford Taurus, Hyundai Genesis, Kia Cadenza
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/4uCmWVZH_sk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The 2014 Charger SXT Plus is billed by the company as “the most affordable full-size car with leather and 20-inch wheels.”
• This is a midlevel model that slots in between the base 2014 Charger SE, which costs $27,290 (including destination), and the top-of-the-line 2014 Charger SRT8, which starts at $45,380 (including destination). This model is almost as expensive as the Charger R/T Max.

• Our test car is equipped with $6,080 worth of options. They include a $2,000 Customer Preferred package that bundles leather seats, heated second-row seats, and a heated steering wheel, among other things. A $1,495 Driver Confidence Group adds blind spot and cross-path detection, a rearview camera, and rain-sensitive wipers, among other things; a navigation system adds another $995.
• Fuel efficiency in this model (31 mpg highway!) is aided in large part by the eight-speed automatic transmission.
• The Charger has a top five-star overall rating in crash testing by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The 2014 model is a carryover; although it is not yet rated by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, the 2013 model is a Top Safety Pick.

• Competition in this market segment is about smaller powertrains and slimming down—for example, the 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder in the 2014 Ford Taurus, which returns 22 mpg in the city and 32 mpg on the highway.
• You can get a 2014 Charger with a Hemi, but the model with the 370-horsepower 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 and a five-speed automatic transmission returns 15 mpg city/25 mpg highway, according to the EPA. You don’t suffer much with the V-6, though, since it makes 292 horsepower.

• But the bottom line with the Charger is its muscle-car heritage. The second-generation model was Steve McQueen’s nemesis in Bullitt, and the car also served as the orange General Lee in The Dukes of Hazzard.

• And you can’t ignore the fun factor with the 2014 Charger. The car I brought home was in an ordinary Bright White clearcoat, but Dodge is offering a batch of new exterior colors, including the historically important Header Orange and Plum Crazy.
