pageElements.text: Happy anniversary to JeanKnowsCars.com! The actual anniversary was October 5, but we started partying on Friday. We went to a restaurant on the University of Michigan campus for a jolly little lunch, minus alcohol of course. We were blessed because there was a parking space right on State Street in front of the restaurant. We were all piled in a 2013 Lexus LS460 F Sport, riding in style.

The Lexus would not have been beyond the means of the students we saw dining inside with their large Louis Vuitton handbags and designer sunglasses, and all with phones smacked against their ears. It was a lot different scene than when I went to school. My typical dress would have been an India Import maxi dress to the ground, bare feet, no makeup, no underwear of any kind, but always with a very nice nail job. It’s all backward now. I’m looking down at my chipped nails, but everything else is solidly in place, including my shoes.

I was very happy to have this Lexus as a test car because, at a total price of $88,029.00, it is welllllll beyond my means. It’s pretty much the equivalent of my entire personal fleet. It costs so much money that it should have driven me up north. Yes, it was such a long week I was ready for an autonomous experience. Well, at least it was fast and fabulous with its 4.6-liter V8 engine making 360 horsepower. It also had full-time all-wheel drive with a limited-slip center diff, so the pouring rain never fazed it or me.

I was roaring up north, where my husband was at our cabin with all four dogs and a very bad head cold which prevented him from stalking the wily grouse as is his wont this time of year. I was looking forward to the fall color show. It’s so magnificent everywhere in northern Michigan this time of year. We have so many maple trees and so many beautiful pines and cedars that everywhere you look is worthy of a photo.

On Saturday, I ran my errands surrounded by these majestic woods. I stopped by the bank of the Au Sable River so I could see everything reflected in the water. The sun wasn’t out, so my photos are a little bit overcast.

After the stop at the river, I went directly to my favorite Amish bakery on Camp Ten Road, right in the heart of Amish country near Mio, Michigan. There are a couple of bakeries, but the one on Camp Ten is by far the best. It’s called “Bakery.” This is what it looks like. I loaded up on bread hot from the oven, and fresh eggs that were sitting on the counter, but passed all the diabetic-killer desserts like pies, cinnamon buns, cookies, jams, and jellies, but left a donation for Habitat for Humanity.

There is nothing else to report, other than that my one-mile dirt driveway had a half dozen major-league puddles that made me very grateful for the all-wheel drive of the Lexus, and it handled all of them perfectly. I was sad to see my big perennial flower garden put away for the winter. This is what it looked like two months ago. See why I love to come up here?

Just a little calm before the storm that is the week ahead: three days, thirty hot cars, Gingerman Raceway, and nearly the entire staff of Automobile Magazine (those who aren’t working on automobilemag.com and the 2014 Ultimate Buyers’ Guide) gathered to pick the 2014 Automobile of the Year and our short list for the 2014 All-Stars.

Have a great week!
—Jean

It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
THE MOVING ASSEMBLY LINE TURNS 100 TODAY!

Can an invention celebrate a birthday? Yes, and every person on the planet who uses manufactured goods should send a birthday card to the Moving Assembly Line that Henry Ford introduced on October 7, 1913. I am a firm believer in the assembly-line approach to pretty much everything. When I fold the laundry I fold all the T-shirts at once, and then pants, socks, underwear, etc.—it just makes sense.

In 1912, The Ford Motor Company produced 82,388 Model Ts, and the basic Touring model sold for $600. Ford set out to streamline the process so that the selling price could be reduced to a level where the rising middle class could purchase his products.

For Downton Abbey fans, this was all happening at the same time Mary had her tryst with the Turkish attaché Kemal Pamuk, and of course on the other side of the pond. Just putting things in perspective.

Anyway, on this day in 1913, Ford set up a 150-foot assembly line at his Highland Park, Michigan, assembly plant. There, 140 assemblers were stationed along the line to install parts on a chassis that engineers had constructed using a winch and a rope. From this crude beginning, the process quickly evolved. The following year, the rope was replaced by an endless chain. The time it took to produce one vehicle was reduced by over nine hours to fewer than three. Ford had created a win-win: he got filthy rich, and the middle class got to drive cars.
 
The idea of moving the product to the worker rather than the worker to the product was revolutionary, and it helped smooth out the pacing of production. By 1916, the number of Model Ts produced reached 585,388, but the big news was the price had been significantly reduced. The Touring model now sold for only $360. According to an inflation calculator, that would equate to roughly $8,500 today. I would love to buy a new car for that price.

The modern assembly line has greatly changed from 1913, but the premise of streamlining the process prevails. The auto plants of today have taken significant strides thanks to the Toyota Production Systems, but the backbone still harks back to Oct 7, 1913. So, hats off to Henry Ford and his good ol' American ingenuity.

title: Bugatti Veyron, Lang Lang Style
promoTeaserSmall: How to get the $2 million supercar some fresh attention? Display a one-off in honor of a music star.
promoTeaser: How to get the $2 million supercar some fresh attention? Display a one-off in honor of a music star.
metaTitle: Bugatti Veyron, Lang Lang Style - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Bugatti Veyron, Lang Lang Style: The French automaker creates a one-off version of the Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse named for heartthrob classical pianist Lang Lang. PR move looks like a clever way to keep the $2 million supercar in the public eye. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you were going to have a one-of-a-kind car customized in your name, which kind would you choose? Maybe you'd go for the top and pick something like the Bugatti Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse, which is really the ultimate halo car. It’s got an 8.0-liter W-16 engine that pumps out 1,200 horsepower and 1,106 pound-feet of torque. It has a governor-limited top speed of 258 miles per hour and features carbon fiber body panels and a luxurious leather interior. Even the base model Veyron (if you can call it that) retails in excess of $2 million, so it's not a vehicle for the casual collector.

You'd be choosing well for another reason: Bugatti does frequently create special editions and one-off versions of the Veyron, often featuring unique color schemes or materials or custom bodywork. Bugatti’s latest one-of-a-kind masterpiece is this Grand Sport Vitesse, customized in honor of young classical piano star Lang Lang and unveiled at a private performance at Bugatti’s chateau in Molsheim. The company has had its headquarters and manufacturing works in the small French town in Alsace, near the German border, since its founding in 1909.

Lang Lang is a thirty-one-year-old pianist from China whose talent, exuberant performance style, and heartthrob looks have made him a big name in classical music circles all over the world. He has played at a number of high-profile venues including Carnegie Hall and the White House. Now he’s added Bugatti’s factory in Molsheim to the list. This photo shows the Bugatti atelier set up for the pianist's one-off private concert.

The car, fittingly, is designed to recall a grand piano, with a black-and-white theme running throughout the car. The exterior uses black tinted carbon fiber and Blanc Atalante paint, inspired by the classic Bugatti Type 57 Atalante. The interior boasts black leather seats and white door inserts with black detailing, designed to look like note lines on sheet music. The center console has a glossy piano black finish, and the steering wheel and gas cap have gold detailing.

The car was on display at Bugatti's Chateau Saint Jean for Lang Lang's concert. After the performance, he signed two black center console inserts, which will be placed in the car for an added touch of customization. Lang said on his Facebook page after the event that he was sad Bugatti didn’t let him keep this one-of-a-kind automobile, but joked to his followers, “Maybe one of you will buy it?” Bugatti hasn’t said if the car is for sale, or how much it would cost if it were.

This year, Bugatti is launching a series called “Les Légendes de Bugatti,” which will custom design six Veyrons inspired by people who have been influential in the Bugatti brand. So far, two have been unveiled: this electric blue version in honor of Jean-Pierre Wimille, who won two Le Mans victories in Bugattis, and a sleek black version (below) named in honor of Jean Bugatti, the son of Bugatti founder Ettore. The rest of the Légendes series will be unveiled in the coming year.

A French publication, Sport Auto, reported that Bugatti’s current penchant for special editions is designed in part to use up the brand’s stock of unsold multimillion-dollar vehicles, saying that Bugatti has sold just 300 of 450 Veyrons. News of the Lang Lang-inspired model came just days after The Economist reported that the Volkswagen Group (which includes Bugatti) loses upward of $6 million on each Veyron they sell. Somehow, I doubt this one would be any exception.

title: Falling in Love with Motorcycles
promoTeaserSmall: I've ridden hundreds of thousands of miles on bikes. Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.
promoTeaser: I've ridden hundreds of thousands of miles on bikes. Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.
metaTitle: Falling in Love with Motorcycles - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Falling in Love with Motorcycles: The story of a woman who started out riding a small Suzuki and, several hundred thousand miles later, shares her experiences with us. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: My parents were teachers who drove sensible cars, so I was an unlikely candidate to ride something as frivolous or as dangerous as a motorcycle. No one in my family had, to my knowledge, even straddled one.

But when the bicycle I'd been using as my primary form of transportation was skeletonized by thieves, a motorcycle didn't only seem like a logical and low-cost upgrade. It was kismet. My stripped-to-its-skivvies bicycle had been parked outside a biker bar.

And now look. I'm the woman on the motorcycle in every photo on this page.

Twenty-one years later, I've logged a few hundred thousand motorcycle miles, only taking a break from riding when I became pregnant and thought better of resting my baby bump on the gas tank. I've owned seven motorcycles personally and formally tested 200 others as a motorcycle critic. I've biked the Isle of Man, China's Silk Road, and the twisting asphalt outside Sturgis, South Dakota.

A motorcycle has evolved from mere transportation to a form of personal empowerment and, eventually, my career. That's a trajectory I would never have predicted when I took my first, terrifying, exhilarating, scream-inducing motorcycle ride down San Francisco's Haight Street on the back of a dented, high-mileage, decade-old Suzuki that would later be mine for a mere $600.

It was my boyfriend at the time who arranged the thrill ride that would change the course of my life. Oddly, he had given up motorcycling because he said he was tired of risking his life that way. He did, however, encourage me to save my own by taking a formal safety class to learn how to tame a machine that is essentially an exposed motor balanced on two wheels.

Six hours of tedious classroom instruction, followed by a more harrowing on-bike experience that had me wobbling and swerving through cones, ended in failure. I didn't pass the riding test I needed to get my motorcycle license.

But I had already bought the bike my boyfriend called Sue's Uki, so I pushed through my fears of crashing and doubts that I would ever master the clutch. If I'd had another way to get around, that Uki would surely have stayed parked. Instead, I rode it daily—rain or shine, in city traffic and up steep hills that had me working the clutch overtime and crying in frustration.

Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.

I was intimidated by the weight of the machine, especially when negotiating corners, and dropped it while making a turn over uneven pavement within my first couple weeks of riding. I don't enjoy playing the damsel in distress, but that early incident made me recognize a corollary benefit to being a woman rider: Unprecedented amounts of male attention.

Sometimes, as with lifting a downed 400-pound machine, that's a good thing. Other times, like the many occasions over the years when I was invited on dates simply because I rode, I was pushed beyond my comfort zone to man up and ride faster and split lanes between rows of moving cars.

Each overcome obstacle propelled me to keep riding and enduring ever greater challenges, like stalling on the Bay Bridge during rush hour and learning to bump start a bike with a dead battery by rolling it down a hill and popping the clutch.

Five years and four bikes later, I was teaching the same class I had failed, having fallen in love with motorcycles, gotten properly licensed, and mastered its most essential skills. Ten years and another three bikes from there, I was reviewing motorcycles for the Los Angeles Times as its first motorcycle critic in the paper's 125 years.

What I most enjoy about motorcycles these days is the physical sensation of riding. I love the immediacy of their acceleration, the ease with which I can get through traffic and the sensory connection to my environment: the smells, the sounds, and, for better or for worse, the weather.

My most exultant and miserable experiences in life have been on board a motorcycle.

And I wouldn't trade either type for anything.

title: The Rearview Camera Fight
promoTeaserSmall: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that.
promoTeaser: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that.
metaKeywords: Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act
Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety
metaDescription: The Rearview Camera Fight: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The story of Cameron Gulbransen’s preventable tragedy is one that should touch every parent. The two-year-old woke up past his bedtime on a Saturday night, clutched his blankie, and wandered outside. Dr. Greg Gulbransen, a pediatrician, was backing his BMW X5 out of the driveway when he accidentally backed over his son and killed him.

That happened more than twelve years ago, and it's horrible to say, but little has changed, at least in the law. This terrible tragedy has gone on to happen to a lot of other people. Backing up a large vehicle is just not foolproof, especially if someone as small as a toddler is directly behind it where he or she can't be seen by mirrors.

But, you say, what about rearview cameras? Aha. Yes, Gulbransen has become a staunch advocate since his son's death, both for rearview cameras and for federal standards to mandate better rear visibility for vehicles. He had some success when, in 2008, the Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act was signed into law, mandating better rear visibility through rearview cameras on cars, among other things.
If you didn't realize that such a law was in place, that's because implementation has been repeatedly delayed, and the rule is not now scheduled to go into effect until 2015.

Gulbransen, along with safety advocates and another parent, Susan Auriemma, who backed over her three-year-old daughter in her driveway in 2005, sued the U.S. Department of Transportation in late September.

The lawsuit asks the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to direct the DOT to issue a mandatory rear visibility rule by the end of the year. The advocacy group Public Citizen is representing the plaintiffs in the suit. They are Gulbransen, Auriemma, the Consumers Union of the United States, Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, and Kids And Cars, Inc., represented in the action by Public Citizen.

“Our federal government, whose job it is to make sure we have safe vehicles to drive, needs to recognize this all too real problem and begin to inform the public about these dangers, and the automobile manufacturers need to install technology that has proven to be effective and would help warn drivers that something is behind their vehicle before backing up,” said Gulbransen.

You won't be surprised to hear that the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers opposes the law. Twelve automakers, including BMW, Chrysler, and Ford, are members of this group. The AAM sent out a Tweet saying the group believes the "decision to buy such cameras should be consumers’.” Industry experts say the addition of such cameras would add to the sticker price of vehicles.

Federal safety regulators insist they are not standing still, despite the many delays in implementing the law. The federal government last week said it will add rearview video systems to its  "recommended" features list in the New Car Assessment Program.
Safety advocates aren't buying that.

“It is time to stop delaying and start solving a dangerous safety problem with a technology that is available and absolutely essential to saving lives,” said Jackie Gillian, president of the Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will identify on www.safercar.gov vehicle models that have rearview video systems. It said it is making the move while it “researches implementation of a rear visibility rule.”

While the two sides duke it out in the courtroom, industry experts say that standard rearview camera systems are starting to become commonplace on vehicles. Such systems are available on seven in ten new vehicles, according to some industry estimates.
We'll be watching the progress of this lawsuit, fully aware that this not the only piece of momentous legislation being held up even though it has been signed into law.
